uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. Training real-time machine learning models to classify and/or predict walk modes and heel strike/toe-off timings for enhancing the control of walk assist systems such as exoskeletons or prostheses.
2. Exploring machine learning for real-time motion recognition and prediction, potentially incorporating visual behavior and analyzing its benefits.
uses_ml_approach: Yes, the dataset has been tested using machine learning approaches. The context mentions that the data can be directly used within standard machine-learning libraries such as Scikit-learn, Pandas, PyTorch, or Tensorflow. It also suggests that one application could be to train real-time machine learning models for classifying and predicting walk modes and heel strike and toe-off timings.

uses_collected_from_people: Yes, the subjects of the collection process are humans. This is mentioned in the context where it states that "Twenty healthy participants (five females, fifteen males, between 18 and 69 years old, 178.5 ± 7.64 cm, 72.9 ± 8.7 kg) wore a full-body Lycra suit with 17 IMU sensors, insoles with eight pressure sensing cells per foot, and a mobile eye tracker."
uses_biases: No. The context does not provide any information about biases issues of the data.

uses_data:
The collected data for this study is provided on the figshare data-sharing platform. The data is organized in a hierarchical file structure, with each participant having a folder containing synchronized CSV data files. The data files include eye tracker data, pressure insoles data, full-body Xsens data, labels, and the eye tracker scene video in MP4 format. The CSV files contain columns with information such as experiment time, participant ID, and experimental task. Detailed lists and explanations of all data columns are provided in the documentation folder on the data-sharing platform.

This dataset is unique compared to other available datasets in several aspects. Firstly, it combines full-body IMU data with foot pressure and gaze data, providing an extensive sensory setup. It is the first dataset to provide natural gait data that includes the visual behavior of the subjects. Additionally, the trial design of this dataset captures traits of natural everyday walks, including transitions between various gait patterns. The trials consist of several minutes of walking in a public space, covering common elements such as straight and curvy passages, slopes, stairs, and pavements. All these elements are annotated.

To facilitate the processing of the data, various tools and scripts are provided on GitHub. These tools include a Python script to join the CSV files into one single pandas data frame, as well as a visualization tool that displays all three sensor modalities. The tools also allow for filtering specific tasks, participants, and data columns, and enable the creation of custom labels or tags for additional machine learning tasks.

In summary, this dataset provides a richly annotated gait data set of natural, everyday walk scenarios. It includes whole-body data from IMU sensors, plantar foot pressure data, and gaze data. The dataset consists of 9 hours of gait data recorded from 20 healthy subjects, walking across three different courses in a public area. The data is expected to be valuable for research exploring machine learning for real-time motion recognition and prediction, incorporating visual behavior and analyzing its benefits.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected using a combination of sensors and equipment. Participants were asked to wear tightly fitting clothes and comfortable, flat, lace-up shoes with removable insoles. They also wore an Xsens suit over their clothes, which required a separate calibration recording before the actual data recording. The other sensors, such as the eye tracker and pressure insoles, did not require a calibration procedure.

The participants were instructed to complete three repetitions of walking courses A and B, and five repetitions of walking course C. They were asked to walk at their preferred, normal speed and to take a break whenever necessary. One experimenter followed them at a distance to give directions and support if needed. The experiments took place in dry weather conditions in a public space, which included common elements such as straight and curvy passages, slopes, stairs, and pavements. The participants encountered commuters and passers-by during the experiments, resulting in side-stepping maneuvers.

The data collection process involved recording data from multiple sensors. The eye tracker data, pressure insoles data, and full-body Xsens data were recorded and saved in synchronized CSV files. The eye tracker scene video was also recorded in MP4 format. The data files were organized hierarchically by experimental task and participant.

After the data was recorded on-device, it was transferred to a desktop computer for post-processing. The Xsens IMU data was post-processed using the Xsens MVN software, which computed full-body kinematic data based on a biomechanical model of the participant and sensor fusion algorithms. The FSR data from the pressure insoles was converted to voltages and synchronized using a tool provided with the insoles. The resulting data from all three sensors was down-sampled to 60 Hz and manually synchronized by experimenters using a visualization and labeling tool.

The data was labeled by walk mode and walk orientation, indicating the type of walking pattern and direction. Encounters with other persons were also annotated based on the gaze behavior from the eye tracker recordings. The data set includes segments of the walking courses, which were numbered to easily identify identical course segments across participants and repetitions.

Overall, the data collection process involved participants walking through designated courses while wearing various sensors, and the data from these sensors was recorded, synchronized, and labeled for further analysis.

collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

1. Figshare data-sharing platform: The data is provided on this platform, which includes a folder with detailed documentation on the walk courses and the processed data in a hierarchical file structure.

2. Eye tracker: The data includes eye tracker data, which is synchronized and provided in CSV data files.

3. Pressure insoles: The data includes pressure insoles data, which is synchronized and provided in CSV data files.

4. Full-body Xsens: The data includes full-body Xsens data, which is synchronized and provided in CSV data files.

5. Labels: The data includes labels for different aspects of the experiment, such as the experiment time, participant ID, and experimental task.

6. Eye tracker scene video: The data includes the eye tracker scene video in MP4 format.

7. Python script: A Python script is provided to join the CSV files into one single pandas data frame, which supports filtering for specific tasks, participants, and data columns.

8. Visualization tool: A visualization tool is provided that displays all three sensor modalities (eye tracker, pressure insoles, and full-body Xsens) together.

9. GitHub repository: Various tools and scripts are provided on the GitHub repository to streamline the processing of the data.

Overall, the collection process involved the use of various sensors (eye tracker, pressure insoles, full-body Xsens), data files in CSV format, and tools/scripts for data processing and visualization.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process done over the data involves several steps. First, the data is processed using the Xsens MVN convention, which calculates the ergonomic joint angles using the Euler sequence XZY and the ISB based coordinate system. Outliers are removed to achieve invariance against different body weights and shoe characteristics. 

To determine foot contact, a threshold is set for the maximum sensor output. If the output surpasses the threshold, the foot is assumed to be on the ground, and if it falls below the threshold, the foot is assumed to be lifted. This process considers all sensor cells because the most relevant ones can vary depending on factors such as stairs, slopes, or evasive motions. 

Heel strike and toe-off events are detected by identifying the first moment the foot switches from being lifted to being on the ground and vice versa. The thresholds for foot contact and the detected events are optimized using a random search on a small set of annotated recordings, minimizing the mean absolute error between the ground truth events and the detected ones. 

The annotation process also includes the estimation of foot contact data calculated by the Xsens software. However, it is noted that these estimates are often inaccurate, particularly for slopes and stairs, and should be treated with caution.
annotation_manual: The annotations have been done manually.

annotation_infrastructure: Yes, the annotation process involves the use of the Xsens MVN convention and the Xsens software for calculating ergonomic joint angles and estimating foot contact data.
annotation_validation_methods: Ground Truth Labels, Test re-test reliability

uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset being described is the GFPLAIN250m dataset, which is a global high-resolution dataset of Earth's floodplains. The data is derived from the SRTM dataset and does not involve the collection of data from humans.
uses_data:
The collected data is the GFPLAIN250m dataset, which is a global high-resolution dataset of Earth's floodplains. The dataset is derived from the original SRTM dataset, specifically the 250-m SRTM version 4.1 DTM. The GFPLAIN250m dataset is stored in both Esri ASCII raster and GeoTIFF formats and is provided as a seamless dataset using the World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS84) datum and geographic coordinate system. The floodplain raster layers are available for continents on Earth, excluding Antarctica.

The technical validation of the GFPLAIN250m dataset involves evaluating the quality of the dataset in terms of two main factors. The first factor is the sources of error and potential uncertainties of the DTM processing for drainage network extraction. It is acknowledged that the resolution and production method of the DTM can impact the outcomes of the stream network extraction. However, this uncertainty does not affect the floodplain zoning as the simulated channel always flows within the fluvial valley. DTM corrections and the use of updated terrain and hydrologic datasets can help mitigate this uncertainty. The second factor is the validation of the geomorphic algorithm for floodplain identification. The validation is performed by evaluating the outcomes of the GFPLAIN model with varying parameterization of the scaling law. The sensitivity of results to varying the b parameter is investigated, and the optimal b parameter is associated with floodplain modeling results that maximize the performances of the geomorphic zoning. The validation confirms the validity of the GFPLAIN algorithm in capturing the geomorphic signature of fluvial flooding dynamics.

The GFPLAIN250m dataset can be used in combination with global datasets of human settlements to support large-scale studies of human-flood interactions, human pressure on rivers, and changes over time of floodplain and wetland habitats at risk. Regional values for the scaling law parameterization can be further refined to capture local variations of geologic, climatic, and ecological properties.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected using a three-step procedure. 

First, a digital terrain model (DTM) analysis was conducted to determine flow direction, drainage area, and network identification from elevation data. This step involved analyzing the elevation data to identify the direction of water flow and the areas that contribute to each drainage network grid cell.

Second, scaling laws were implemented to associate a floodplain flow depth to the contributing area of each drainage network grid cell. This step involved using mathematical models to determine the relationship between the size of the contributing area and the depth of the floodplain flow.

Finally, a floodplain layer was derived by flagging as a floodplain those cells whose elevations were lower than the corresponding drainage network flow levels. This step involved identifying the cells in the DTM analysis that met the criteria for being considered part of the floodplain.

The quality of the dataset was evaluated by considering two main factors. The first factor was the sources of error and potential uncertainties in the DTM processing for drainage network extraction. This involved assessing the accuracy and reliability of the DTM analysis techniques used to extract the drainage network. The second factor was the validation of the geomorphic algorithm for floodplain identification. This involved evaluating the outcomes of the floodplain identification algorithm by comparing them to a reference floodplain dataset and assessing the sensitivity of the results to variations in the parameterization of the scaling law.

The dataset is available for access and download through figshare. It is stored in both Esri ASCII raster and GeoTIFF formats and is provided as a seamless dataset using the World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS84) datum and geographic coordinate system. The dataset includes floodplain raster layers for the continents on Earth, except Antarctica.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data in the provided context.
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects:
- DTM analysis for flow direction, drainage area, and network identification from elevation data
- Scaling laws implemented for associating a floodplain flow depth to the contributing area of each drainage network grid cell
- GFPLAIN250m gridded layer derived from flagging cells with lower elevations than corresponding drainage network flow levels
- SRTM dataset for superimposing floodplains of major global rivers
- Floodplain areas estimated at the continental scale
- Sources of error and potential uncertainties of the DTM processing for drainage network extraction
- Validation of the geomorphic algorithm for floodplain identification
- Varying parameterization of the scaling law to evaluate the outcomes of the GFPLAIN model
- Global fluvial landscape feature zoning to depict river channel surface water domains
- 200 years flood prone zoning based on hydrodynamic models as the only available homogeneous floodplain reference dataset at the global scale
- Global datasets of human settlements for large-scale studies of human-flood interactions
- Python script and user manual of the GFPLAIN algorithm available at https://github.com/fnardi/GFPLAIN
collection_infrastructure: The tools and devices used during the collection process include the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) digital terrain model and a fast geospatial tool for floodplain mapping. The infrastructure used includes the GitHub repository (https://github.com/fnardi/GFPLAIN) where the Python script and user manual of the GFPLAIN algorithm are accessible for generating the GFPLAIN250m dataset.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process for the GFPLAIN250m dataset involved two main factors: (1) the evaluation of the quality of the dataset in terms of error sources and uncertainties in the digital terrain model (DTM) processing for drainage network extraction, and (2) the validation of the geomorphic algorithm used for floodplain identification.

For the first factor, the sources of error in the DTM data and the assumptions of DTM analysis techniques were considered. The resolution and production method of the DTM were acknowledged to have an impact on the outcomes of the stream network extraction. However, this uncertainty did not affect the floodplain zoning as the simulated channel always flows within the fluvial valley. Uncertainties were mitigated through DTM corrections and the use of updated terrain and hydrologic datasets. The potential sources of error in the river network location and profile did not impact the validity of the GFPLAIN250m dataset.

For the second factor, the validation of the geomorphic floodplain algorithm was performed by evaluating the outcomes of the GFPLAIN model with varying parameterization of the scaling law. The sensitivity of the results to variations in the "b" parameter was investigated. The "b" parameter represents floodplain flow energy levels and was varied within a physically feasible range. The optimal "b" value was determined based on the floodplain modeling results that maximized the performance of the geomorphic zoning compared to a reference floodplain dataset. The consistency analysis confirmed the validity of the GFPLAIN algorithm in capturing the geomorphic signature of fluvial flooding dynamics.

Overall, the annotation process involved assessing the quality of the dataset in terms of error sources and uncertainties, as well as validating the floodplain identification algorithm through sensitivity analysis and comparison with a reference dataset.

uses_uses: The dataset is recommended for code availability and reproducibility of the data processing steps, for raw data processing and quality validation, for SNP discovery using multiple variant-calling methods, and for whole genome alignment against the Brassica napus Darmor-bzh reference genome.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people. The dataset is described as containing genetic information about Brassica napus genotypes.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The collected data consists of raw sequence data from 52 genotypes of Brassica napus, a plant species.
uses_data:
The collected data in this study consists of raw sequence data from 52 genotypes of Brassica napus. The raw data was processed using various software tools and algorithms. First, the quality of the raw sequence data was validated using FastQC software. Adapters were then removed using cutadapt, and low quality bases were trimmed using the fastx quality trimmer algorithm. Paired reads were synchronized using an in-house Perl script. General quality statistics of the raw and trimmed reads were generated using fastx_quality_stats.

After processing, over 3.4 billion quality-trimmed, paired-end reads were used, resulting in a total pre-processed data volume of 685 Gbp. The average G/C content changed slightly from 36.34% to 35.35% after trimming. The average sequencing depth per genotype decreased to approximately 11.7 fold, with a Q1 quartile of 10.0 fold and a Q3 quartile of 12.6 fold.

The processed data was then aligned against the Brassica napus Darmor-bzh reference genome. The average insert sizes between corresponding read pairs ranged from 158 to 319 bp for the individual genotypes. A high average mapping quality of approximately 69.1 was observed. The proportion of the reference genome with sufficient read coverage varied between genotypes, particularly between natural and synthetic accessions. Only reference positions with a minimum of 4 reads aligned per position were included in the analysis. The percentage of reference positions with sufficient read coverage ranged from 51.3% (Q1) to 68.6% (Q3). Overall, the natural B. napus accessions had sufficient coverage at 66.5% of all reference positions, while the synthetic accessions had a lower coverage of 48.4%. Among the sequences with sufficient coverage, the synthetic accessions showed a higher sequence diversity compared to the reference sequence.

The data processing scripts used in this study are available without restrictions, and the software tools and versions used are listed in the paper.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected by resequencing 52 Brassica napus accessions using an Illumina HiSeq 2000 platform. Each sample had 1 ug of gDNA fragmented into small fragments of 400 bp. The NEBNext DNA library kit was used to prepare the library, and cleaning and size selection were done using Ampure magnetic beads. Each fragment was paired end sequenced, generating short-reads of 100 bp with an average coverage of 12-15x. The full sequence data for all 52 accessions is archived at the European Nucleotide Archive under the project numbers PRJEB5974 and PRJEB6069.

The raw sequence data was validated using FastQC software. Adapters were removed using cutadapt and the reads were trimmed for low quality bases using the fastx quality trimmer algorithm. Paired reads were then synchronized using an in-house Perl script. General quality statistics of raw and trimmed reads were generated using fastx_quality_stats. Over 3.4 billion quality-trimmed, paired-end reads were used, providing a total pre-processed data volume of 685 Gbp.

Insertion-deletion polymorphisms (InDels) were called independently from the SNP calling process. A gapped alignment was constructed using Bowtie2, and BAM files of the read alignments were converted into PILEUP files using SAMtools 'mpileup'. BCFtools was used to screen for insertions and deletions. Stringent parameter settings were used to identify high quality and homozygous sites. In total, 633,844 insertions and 469,860 deletions were detected in the range between -20 and 20 bp, with the majority being 3 bp in length. The synthetic B. napus accessions had the highest number of InDels, while the oilseed forms had fewer InDels. Analysis of InDels within coding regions of B. napus genes revealed a moderate enrichment of in-frame InDels.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from B. napus accessions, including 30 adapted, 20 resynthesized, and 2 elite lines.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

- Illumina HiSeq 2000 platform for whole-genome sequencing
- Covaris standard technology for fragmenting gDNA
- NEBNext DNA library kit for library preparation
- Ampure magnetic beads for cleaning and size selection
- FastQC software for validating the quality of raw sequence data
- cutadapt for removing adapters
- fastx quality trimmer algorithm for trimming low quality bases
- SAMtools and BCFtools for processing BAM and PILEUP files
- Bowtie2 for gapped alignment
- European Nucleotide Archive for archiving the sequence data
annotation_explanation: The annotation process involved comparing the results of the variant calling method with the outcome from the Illumina 60k SNP Brassica Consortium Infinium genotyping array. Flanking sequences from the SNP markers on the genotyping array were aligned to the B. napus Darmor-bzh reference sequence using a stringent BLASTN analysis. Anchoring criteria were set requiring that 90% of the marker sequence is linked with 98% identity to the reference sequence. From the markers called by the array, different positions for unique, high-confidence markers were assigned. The annotation also involved investigating the functional effects of SNP and InDel variant positions, distinguishing between synonymous and non-synonymous variations. The functional annotation categorized the variants into different impact groups, including loss of function, moderate, low, and other. The annotation process also involved aligning the reads to the reference genome and determining the coverage of reference positions.
annotation_team_type: The context does not provide information about whether the data was annotated by an internal team, an external team, or a crowdsourcing team.
annotation_infrastructure: Yes, the following tools or infrastructures were used during the annotation process: BLASTN, SOAP2, Bowtie2, cutadapt, FastQC, FaSD, Freebayes, SAMtools, BCFtools, e!DAL, and Tablet.
annotation_validation_methods: No information provided
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1) Reviewing the database and examining patterns using the provided Python and R code.
2) Examining patterns in ice phenology among lakes by downloading the PhenologyData.csv file.
3) Joining the LakeCharacteristics.csv to the PhenologyData.csv and Definitions.csv for combining the data with remotely sensed data or downscaled climate models.
4) Testing changing patterns in lake ice using resources such as the HydroLAKES database, MODIS, Climatic Research Unit of East Anglia, and WorldClim.
5) Conducting research on lake ice phenology and climate change.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any testing of the dataset using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are lakes, not humans.
uses_data:
The collected data consists of three main files: PhenologyData.csv, LakeCharacteristics.csv, and Definitions.csv. These files contain information on ice-on and ice-off dates, physical characteristics of each lake (including geospatial coordinates), and metadata for each lake (including missing years and definitions of ice-on and ice-off). The datasets can be connected using the unique lake name column.

For those interested in studying ice phenology among lakes, the PhenologyData.csv file is sufficient. However, additional ice phenology data for lakes and rivers around the Northern Hemisphere can be obtained from the Lake and River Ice Phenology (LIAG) dataset or the Canadian Ice Database.

To combine the data with remotely sensed data or downscaled climate models, it is recommended to join the LakeCharacteristics.csv file with the PhenologyData.csv and Definitions.csv files using the "lake" column. Other relevant resources for analyzing changing patterns in lake ice include the HydroLAKES database, MODIS for remote sensing, and the Climatic Research Unit of East Anglia for climate values. Historical and future climate patterns can be obtained from WorldClim.

The uncertainty in ice-on and ice-off dates for the datasets is estimated to be in the order of magnitude of one day to several days. Factors contributing to this uncertainty include variability in personal judgement between lake ice observers, low visibility, and lakes freezing over weekends or holidays.

The code used for creating the dataset, quality assurance, and quality control is available in an open access repository. Python code was used for the creation and validation, while R code was used for technical validation and visualization. The code is freely available under the Massachusetts Institute of Technology license.

The author contributions to the project are listed, including the project lead, conceptualization, data providers, data management, data analysis, visualization, and manuscript writing.

The methods used for data collection are described, including the maintenance of original Ken Stewart dates, the criteria for recording ice-on and ice-off dates, and the documentation of changes in data collection procedures. The data for Mirror Lake in the Adirondacks has been collected since 1903, with ice-on date recorded when the lake is completely covered with ice and ice-off date recorded when the lake is mostly free of ice. Freeze-thaw events are also noted. Data collection has been done through visual observations from the lake shore, supplemented with a live feed from a webcam in recent years.
collection_explanation: The dataset was collected through visual observations made by local residents and recorded by various sources such as newspapers, diaries, scientific publications, and webcams. In some cases, observers stood on the shoreline and faced towards the lake to identify when open water was seen across most of the lake. In other cases, observers examined the lake from different locations around the shore. The data collection procedures were considered consistent throughout the entire period. In some instances, remote sensing images were incorporated to supplement missing data. However, there are limitations to the dataset due to the subjectivity of observers, inconsistent numbers of observers and observing locations, and possible historical errors associated with the early start of the dataset.
collection_team_type: Crowdsourcing team
collection_labour: No. The provided context does not mention any specific information about the labour involved in collecting the data by the crowdsourcing team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_speakers_demographics: Yes, the context provides information about the speech situation, such as the genre (scientific research), the modality (written text), and the topics (ice phenology records, data collection methods).
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects:
- Open access repository (https://github.com/afilazzola/IcePhenologyDatabase)
- Figshare
- Lake and River Ice Phenology (LIAG) dataset stored at the National Snow and Ice Data Centre (NSIDC)
- Canadian Ice Database housed at the Polar Data Catalogue
- HydroLAKES database for geomorphic data
- Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) for spectral bands to be used in remote sensing
- Climatic Research Unit of East Anglia for monthly climate values
- WorldClim for historical and future climate patterns under multiple general circulation models and four shared socio-economic pathways
- Ken Stewart
- Hart family
- Mirror Lake
- Lake Placid residents
- Judith Shea of the Lake Placid Volunteer Fire Department
- Dr. Brendan Wiltse, Adirondack Watershed Institute Water Quality Director
collection_infrastructure: The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include Python code (using numpy, pandas, and textract libraries), R code (using tidyr, dplyr, ggplot, and broom packages), an open access repository (https://github.com/afilazzola/IcePhenologyDatabase), Figshare for data storage (https://figshare.com/), the Lake and River Ice Phenology (LIAG) dataset stored at the National Snow and Ice Data Centre (NSIDC), the Canadian Ice Database housed at the Polar Data Catalogue, the HydroLAKES database for geomorphic data, Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) for spectral bands in remote sensing, Climatic Research Unit of East Anglia for monthly climate values, and WorldClim for historical and future climate patterns. Additionally, visual observations were made over the entire lake from the lake shore, and a 24/7 live feed from a webcam was used to observe the main portion of the lake.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process for the data involved several steps to ensure accuracy and consistency. The data records were reviewed by multiple team members to check for discrepancies in lake names, lake physical characteristics, and dates for ice-on and ice-off. Inconsistent lake names were standardized, and geospatial coordinates were obtained and verified. Lake characteristics and morphology were collated, and the dates of ice-on and ice-off were reviewed for consistencies among lakes and anomalies among years. The formatting of the dates was standardized, and anomalies in the dates were checked and verified with the original observers or data collectors. The duration of ice presence was also recorded, taking into account multiple freeze-thaw events. The percent coverage of lake ice was consistently recorded throughout the season, and additional information such as ice thickness was recorded when safe. The procedure for collecting data remained consistent over the time series.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by an internal team, which includes the authors of the study.
annotation_infrastructure: Yes, the annotation process for the data involved the use of tools or infrastructures.
annotation_validation_methods: Validation methods used to validate the labels include Ground Truth Labels, Inter-annotator agreement, and Expert Annotations.
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

uses_collected_from_people: Yes, the subjects of the collection process are humans. This is indicated in the context where it states that a total of 9,520 participants consented to the study and agreed to share their data with the research community.

uses_sensitivity: No. The context does not provide any information about the data being offensive or sensitive to some people.
uses_privacy: Yes, the context provides information about privacy issues of the data. The context mentions that governance structures have been put in place to respect the balance between participants' desire to share their data with qualified researchers and the respect for privacy. It also mentions that participants had the option to share their data only with the mPower study team and partners or to share their data more broadly with qualified researchers worldwide. Additionally, the context states that researchers who want to access the data need to complete several steps, including agreeing to keep the data confidential and secure.
uses_data:
The collected data in this study includes information from a total of 9,520 participants who consented to share their data with the research community. Out of these participants, 8,320 completed at least one survey or task after joining the study. Among the 6,805 participants who completed the enrollment survey, 1,087 self-identified as having a professional diagnosis of Parkinson's disease (PD), while 5,581 did not (137 chose not to answer the question). 

The data contributed by participants for each survey and activity are detailed in Table 1, and the cumulative tasks completed for each activity are presented in Figure 2. It is important to note that follow-up data collection is not uniform across individuals. However, 898 participants contributed data on at least five separate days over the first six months of the study. The number of days participants contributed data was similar between those with a self-reported diagnosis of PD and those participating as controls, as shown in Figure 3.

The data collection was facilitated through the use of an app that recorded all the data collected for the study. This app interacted with the Bridge Server, a set of web services developed and operated by Sage Bionetworks. The Bridge Server allowed for the collection and management of mobile health data from various apps. The coded study data, including survey responses and mobile sensor measurements, were exported to Synapse, a data and analysis sharing service developed and operated by Sage Bionetworks. Synapse serves as a platform for researchers to collaborate, analyze data, and share insights.

To access the data, researchers need to have a Synapse account and have their Synapse User Profile validated by the Synapse Access and Compliance Team (ACT). Additionally, researchers need to become a Synapse Certified user by completing a short quiz and submit an Intended Data Use statement. They also need to agree to the Conditions for Use associated with each data source. These conditions include commitments to not attempt to re-identify research participants, keep the data confidential and secure, use the data exclusively as described in the submitted Intended Data Use statement, and report any misuse or data release to the ACT within 5 business days.

Overall, the collected data in this study provides valuable insights into Parkinson's disease and real-world activity measurement collected via mobile phones. The release of this data aims to foster collaboration and advance human health research in the field of mobile health data analysis.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through interactions with the Bridge Server, a web services API developed by Sage Bionetworks. The Bridge Server allows for the collection and management of mobile health data from various apps. Participants were able to create accounts securely and provide consent and personal information separately from the study data. The coded study data, which included survey responses and mobile sensor measurements, was exported to Synapse for distribution to researchers. Synapse is a data and analysis sharing service developed and operated by Sage Bionetworks. It allows for collaborative work, data analysis, and sharing of insights within the health research community. In addition to mobile health data, Synapse has been used for other types of biomedical data as well. 

To access the dataset, researchers need to have a Synapse account and have their Synapse User Profile validated by the Synapse Access and Compliance Team (ACT). They also need to become a Synapse Certified user by completing a short quiz and submit an Intended Data Use statement. Researchers must agree to the Conditions for Use associated with each data source and abide by the guiding principles for responsible research use and data handling as described in the Synapse Governance documents. They are also required to keep the data confidential and secure, report any misuse or data release to the ACT, and not attempt to re-identify research participants or use the data for commercial advertisement or re-contacting participants. 

The dataset includes data from a total of 9,520 participants who consented to the study and agreed to share their data with the research community. Of these participants, 8,320 completed at least one survey or task after joining the study. Among the 6,805 participants who completed the enrollment survey, 1,087 self-identified as having a professional diagnosis of Parkinson's disease (PD), while 5,581 did not. The dataset includes information on the number of participants who contributed data for each survey and activity, as well as the cumulative tasks completed for each activity. Follow-up data collection was nonuniform across individuals, but 898 participants contributed data on at least five separate days over the first six months of the study. The distribution of the number of days participants contributed data was similar between those with a PD diagnosis and those without.
collection_team_type: External team
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from the Bridge Server, Synapse, and various surveys and activities such as the baseline survey, Parkinson Disease Questionnaire 8 (PDQ-8), Movement Disorder Society Universal Parkinson Disease Rating Scale (MDS-UPDRS), memory activity, tapping activity, voice activity, and walking activity.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the data collection process include:

1. Bridge Server: A set of web services developed and operated by Sage Bionetworks. It allows for the collection and management of mobile health data from various apps.

2. Synapse: A general-purpose data and analysis sharing service developed and operated by Sage Bionetworks. It is used for the distribution of coded study data to researchers.

3. Mobile Apps: The data collection was done through interactions with mobile apps, specifically the mPower app.

4. Web Services API: Bridge Server exposes a REST style web services API that allows for the collection and management of mobile health data.

5. iPhone: The data collection involved participants using their iPhones to complete various tasks and activities.

6. Microphone: The voice activity recorded participants' sustained phonation using the iPhone's microphone.

7. Accelerometer and Gyroscope: The walking activity collected data from the iPhone's accelerometer and gyroscope in both raw and processed formats.

8. Synapse Account: Researchers interested in accessing the data need to have a Synapse account and have their user profile validated by the Synapse Access and Compliance Team.

9. Synapse Certification: Researchers also need to become Synapse Certified users by completing a short quiz.

10. Intended Data Use Statement: Researchers need to submit an Intended Data Use statement outlining how they plan to use the data.

11. Conditions for Use: Researchers need to agree to the Conditions for Use associated with each data source, which include commitments to confidentiality, responsible research use, and data handling.

12. Governance Structures: Governance structures have been put in place to respect the balance between participants' desire to share their data and the respect for privacy.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process for the data involves several steps. First, researchers interested in accessing the data need to have a Synapse account and have their Synapse User Profile validated by the Synapse Access and Compliance Team (ACT). Once these steps are completed, researchers can access the coded study data, which consists of survey responses and mobile sensor measurements. The data is exported to Synapse, a data and analysis sharing service, where researchers can work collaboratively, analyze the data, and share insights. It is important to note that there are certain conditions for use associated with each data source, and researchers must agree to these conditions, including not attempting to re-identify research participants, keeping the data confidential and secure, and using the data exclusively as described in their submitted Intended Data Use statement. Any misuse or data release must be reported to the ACT within 5 business days.

uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset are to examine tephra occurrences in ocean drilling cores, estimate the age of tephra layers using age-depth models, filter the data according to specific needs, and compare the dataset with other global volcanic records for statistical interrogation.

uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people. The data represents information about tephra layers and drill holes.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are drill holes, not humans.
uses_data: The collected data in this study are available in .xlsx format and can be accessed through the PANGAEA online repository. The data were collected from 3,886 drill holes across various seas and oceans. The information collected includes the location, depth, thickness of the tephra, and any associated notes. The data are organized into five worksheets, which include details per tephra layer, details for each drill hole, age-depth models used in the study, and coring information for each drill hole. The "Key" sheet provides descriptions of the column headers in the data worksheets, including the name, description, allowable values, and whether data may be missing in each column. The "Age-depth models" tab documents the age-depth tie points used in the study, including the unique identifying numbers for each hole and site, age and depth measurements, references, and additional notes. The primary data collection, validation, and integration specialist was S.H.M., with assistance from N.H.B. The primary investigator leading the project was R.S.J.S., and J.C.R. validated the data and initiated formatting upgrades.
collection_explanation: The dataset was collected from 3,886 drill holes (expeditions 1-381) located in various seas and oceans. The data includes information about the location, depth, thickness of the tephra, as well as any associated notes. The data is stored in .xlsx format and can be accessed from the PANGAEA online repository. The dataset is spread over five worksheets, including details per tephra layer, details for each drill hole, age-depth models used in the study, and coring information for each drill hole. There is also a fifth sheet titled 'Key' that describes the meaning of every column in the data worksheets. The individual data sheets can be linked via the common Hole and Site ID fields. The collection method involved accurately dating the chron ages using magnetostratigraphy and biostratigraphy. The quality of the age-depth model is dependent on the quality and number of calibration points. The physical form and volcanic content of each tephra occurrence were determined by the data collection team using information from the VCD. The dataset includes unique identifying numbers for each Site and Coring data, as well as information about the type of core, top depth cored, and bottom depth recovered.
collection_team_type: External team
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from 3,886 drill holes (expeditions 1-381) and the shipboard VCDs (Volcaniclastic Core Description forms).
collection_infrastructure: The tools, devices, or infrastructure used during the data collection process include shipboard VCDs (Visual Core Description forms), physical cores stored in IODP repositories, and an .xlsx format for storing the data in the PANGAEA online repository.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process done over the data involves several steps. First, the data collection team accurately dates the chron ages of the data points using methods such as magnetostratigraphy and biostratigraphy. The team also determines the physical form of each tephra occurrence, categorizing them as layers, patches, or mixed. The volcanic content of the tephra is also described based on the information given in the VCD. 

In the Layers tab, the thickness of the tephra is recorded, with a note that the thickness of a patch is less likely to be the original deposit thickness. The age of each tephra layer is estimated by applying a linear age-depth model to the depths of the base of each layer. The most reliable thickness data are those classified as both "Value_given" and "Layer". 

The age-depth models used are documented in the Age-Depth tab, including information on the age-depth tie points, source references, and whether the data are estimated or given in numerical format. The data collection team also provides additional notes and comments on the layers in the Layers tab.

The primary data collection specialist, assisted by others, collected, validated, and integrated the data. The primary investigator guided and led the project, while another team member validated the data and initiated formatting upgrades.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by an internal team, which includes the primary data collection specialist (S.H.M.), the primary investigator (R.S.J.S.), and other team members (N.H.B., J.C.R.).
annotation_infrastructure: No, the context does not provide information about the specific tools or infrastructures used during the annotation process.
annotation_validation_methods: The context does not provide information about the validation methods used to validate the labels.
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset include: 
1. Replicating the analyses described in the manuscript.
2. Pooling the data with other researchers' sequences for further analysis.
3. Studying the signature APOBEC mutations for gag and gp41.
4. Studying the gag and gp41 sequence sets, publication summaries, and mutation prevalence files.
5. Using the Hyphy and shell scripts for dN/dS analyses on sequence pairs.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people. The dataset contains sequences of gag and gp41 genes, as well as information about amino acid changes and selection indexes.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset consists of sequences and analysis results related to HIV-1 subtype gag and gp41 genes.
uses_data:
The collected data for this study includes original and aligned pre-and post-treatment gag and gp41 sequences. These sequences are available in four FASTA files named gagOriginal.fas, gagAligned.fas, gp41Original.fas, and gp41Aligned.fas. Each sequence header in these files contains four fields: GenBank accession ID, PID, treatment time point, and treatment category. The sequence files are located in the directory data/fasta/.

In addition to the sequence files, there are several other files and tables that contain the results of various analyses. The Linux shell scripts used to perform the pairwise dN/dS analysis, FEL diversifying selection analysis, and MEDS directional selection analysis are named run-pairwise.sh, run-fel.sh, and run-meds.sh, respectively. These scripts are available in the directory scripts/. The summarized results of the pairwise dN/dS analysis are in Tables 2 and 4, while the results of FEL and MEDS are in Tables 5 and 6.

There are also files that contain information about the studies and mutation prevalence. The file data/naiveStudies/gagStudies.csv contains the list of all studies with three or more individuals from whom gag sequences were obtained for analyzing mutation prevalence. The files data/naiveStudies/gagNaiveOriginal.fas and data/naiveStudies/gagNaiveAligned.fas contain the quality-control filtered original and aligned sequences from these studies. Table 7 lists the gag signature APOBEC mutations.

Furthermore, there are figures that display the distribution of gag signature APOBEC mutations prior to quality control filtering (Figure 1), the distribution of the number of unusual amino acids per gag sequence (Figure 2), and the distribution of insertions and deletions at each position in gag (report/gagnaive-indels.pdf). Figure 3 displays the proportions of all gag amino acid variants present at 1.0% or greater frequency of one-per-person sequences.

Finally, there is a file named gagAAPrevalence.csv that lists the proportion of each amino acid at each gag position according to HIV-1 subtype in one-per-person sequences filtered for an excess of signature APOBEC mutations and unusual amino acids.

All of these files, tables, and figures are available as a Dryad data citation and on the GitHub repository. The Dryad data citation provides a stable permanent snapshot of the analyses described in the manuscript, while the GitHub repository will continue to evolve as new studies are published and more data is added. The code used in the analyses, including the Python, R, and Linux shell scripts, is also available on GitHub and can be used by other researchers for similar analyses.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected from HIV-1-infected individuals in Northern California who had genotypic resistance tests performed between April 2001 and June 2013, as well as participants in the ACTG A5202 clinical trial. The sequences were derived from plasma virus samples obtained before and after therapy from 41 previously PI-naïve subjects who had received a ritonavir-boosted PI-containing regimen, and from 20 control subjects who received an NNRTI-containing regimen. 

For the 41 PI-treated subjects, paired sequences before and after PI treatment were available for both the gag and gp41 genes in 11 individuals, for gag alone in 13 individuals, and for gp41 alone in 17 individuals. Among the 20 NNRTI control subjects, paired sequences before and after NNRTI treatment were available for both gag and gp41 in 13 individuals, for gag alone in three individuals, and for gp41 alone in four individuals.

The plasma samples were processed and underwent direct PCR Sanger sequencing. The gag and gp41 sequences were aligned using the Translation Align option with the ClustalW algorithm for multiple sequence alignment. The alignment was then manually edited using the subtype B consensus sequence. Manual edits were primarily the shifting of indels to be consistent with the remaining sequences and the subtype B consensus. Nucleotide insertions were then stripped from the sequence prior to subsequent analyses.

The original and aligned sets of FASTA sequences for gag and gp41 are available in the files gagOriginal.fas, gagAligned.fas, gp41Original.fas, and gp41Aligned.fas. The insertions in gag and gp41 are in the file insertions.csv. Neighbor-joining trees for each gene, created by HyPhy version 2.3.2 using the TN93 distance, confirmed that each pair of sequences clustered by individual.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects:
- HIV-1-infected individuals in Northern California
- Participants in the ACTG A5202 clinical trial
- 41 previously PI-naïve subjects who received a ritonavir-boosted PI-containing regimen
- 20 control subjects who received an NNRTI-containing regimen
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

- GenBank accession ID: Used to identify and access the sequences.
- PID: Used as a unique identifier for each sequence.
- Treatment time point: Indicates whether the sequence is from before or after treatment.
- Treatment category: Indicates the type of treatment received.
- FASTA files: Used to store the original and aligned sequences.
- Linux shell scripts: Used to pass parameters to Hyphy batch language scripts for analysis.
- Hyphy batch language scripts: Used to perform the pairwise dN/dS analysis, FEL diversifying selection analysis, and MEDS directional selection analysis.
- run-pairwise.sh: A shell script used for pairwise dN/dS analysis.
- run-fel.sh: A shell script used for FEL diversifying selection analysis.
- run-meds.sh: A shell script used for MEDS directional selection analysis.
- data/fasta/ directory: Location of the sequence files.
- scripts/ directory: Location of the shell scripts.
- Tables: Contain the summarized results of the pairwise dN/dS analysis, FEL analysis, and MEDS analysis.
- data/naiveStudies/gagStudies.csv: Contains a list of all studies with gag sequences for mutation prevalence analysis.
- data/naiveStudies/gagNaiveOriginal.fas and data/naiveStudies/gagNaiveAligned.fas: Contain the quality-control filtered original and aligned sequences from studies.
- gagAAPrevalence.csv: Lists the proportion of each amino acid at each gag position according to HIV-1 subtype.
- report/gagnaive-indels.pdf: Displays the distribution of insertions and deletions at each position in gag.
- Figures: Show the distribution of gag signature APOBEC mutations, the distribution of unusual amino acids per gag sequence, and the proportions of all gag amino acid variants.
- Dryad data citation: Provides access to the complete set of files, including tables, figures, sequence files, tab-delimited files, and code files.
- GitHub repository: Contains the software and code files for performing the analyses.
- Sanger sequencing: Used to obtain the gag and gp41 sequences from plasma virus samples.
- Geneious R11 software: Used for multiple sequence alignment and manual editing of the sequences.
- ClustalW algorithm: Used for multiple sequence alignment.
- Neighbor-joining trees: Created using HyPhy version 2.3.2 to confirm clustering of sequences by individual.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process done over the data involved several steps. First, the authors retrieved complete group M HIV-1 gag and gp41 sequences from previously published studies submitted to GenBank. They then performed additional analyses to address concerns such as sequence and annotation errors, alignment errors, and the presence of APOBEC-mediated G-to-A hypermutation or other biological artifacts. Sequences containing large gaps, multiple frame shift mutations, an excess of signature APOBEC mutations, and high numbers of unusual mutations were removed. 

Pairwise sequence comparisons and dN/dS analyses were performed on the pre- and post-treatment gag and gp41 sequences. A custom HyPhy script was used to estimate the dN/dS ratio by maximum likelihood using the MG94xREV codon substitution model. The analysis was optionally restricted to a specific protein domain. The results showed no difference in median proportions of pairwise nucleotide and amino acid changes and pairwise dN/dS ratios between PI- and NNRTI-treated patients. However, there was a significant reduction in the median proportion of ambiguous nucleotides in gag between baseline and follow-up among the PI-treated patients. The amino acid changes that occurred at gag cleavage sites were also listed.

uses_data:
The collected data consists of a micro-CT dataset of 19 lumbar spine image sets of female C57BL/6 mice up to 2 weeks after birth. The dataset also includes 2 hydroxyapatite phantoms for calibration of mineral density values. Each image set contains between 1000 and 2300 8-bit BNP images. The datasets are publicly accessible on Figshare.

The data was acquired using standard imaging protocols and analyzed using open-source software such as ImageJ (FIJI) and BoneJ. The reconstructed datasets were reoriented and cleared from soft tissue using ImageJ (Fiji). The comparison of micro-CT and histology was achieved using the oblique slicing function in Amira.

To validate the accuracy of the 3D analysis and imaging protocols, the micro-CT data was compared and matched to standard non-decalcified histomorphometry. The samples were embedded in Technovit 9100 PMMA, cut into 5 µm thick sections, and stained with von Kossa/Toluidine blue. The 3D data of the reconstructed micro-CT scans were matched with the stained 2D slices using the oblique slice function of Amira. The architectural details were identified and matched in the high-resolution images and histological stained sections. There was a high correlation between standard 2D histomorphometric measurements and virtual slices in the 3D datasets, confirming the technical reliability and accuracy of the data.

Overall, the imaging and data-processing protocols used in this experiment are robust and accurate in documenting the mineralized material deposition process in the lumbar spine of normal mice.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected by extracting lumbar spine segments from 19 female C57BL/6 mice at different ages (1, 3, 7, 10, and 14 days). The mice were obtained from healthy litters at the Max Planck Institute of Molecular Genetics in Berlin, Germany. The animals were not used in any animal experiments and were discarded from a previous study. Therefore, no ethical approval was required. The body weights of the animals were recorded.

To remove the spines, the frozen carcasses were thawed in fixation medium (4% PFA / 70% EtOH) for 24 hours at 4 °C. Each animal was gently fixated on a polystyrene board with hind-and forelimbs extended to minimize strain on the soft tissue. Microsurgery was performed under a stereomicroscope and a cold light source. The samples were repeatedly irrigated throughout the procedure.

The extracted spine segments (vertebral bodies L1-L6) were stored in 70% EtOH at 4 °C until scanning. The samples were scanned using a Skyscan 1172 benchtop micro-CT. A custom-made specimen holder was used, which contained a polyethylene tube with each sample in an EtOH atmosphere. The samples were mounted and supported between two polystyrene rings. The region of interest (L3-L5) was identified by radiography.

High-resolution scanning was performed using specific parameters: 50 keV and 198 µA, a 0.5 mm aluminum filter, sample rotation of 360°, image rotation steps of 0.1° (3600 images per segment), frame averaging of 3, and exposure times of 1.45 s. The younger animals' spine segments were scanned within a single field of view, while older animals with larger spine segments required overlapping stacked sub-scan segments.

After scanning, the samples were stored in 70% Ethanol at 4 °C until further histological embedding and conventional optical microscopy. Reconstruction of the scanned images was performed using the manufacturer software (NRecon, Version 1.6.8.0, Bruker MicroCT) with specific settings to avoid saturation of higher densities. The resulting images were stored as 8-bit PNG images.

In addition to the mouse spine datasets, two hydroxyapatite phantoms with densities of 0.25 g/cc and 0.75 g/cc were scanned and reconstructed using the same setup and protocols.

The dataset consists of 19 lumbar spine image sets of female C57BL/6 mice up to 2 weeks after birth, as well as the two hydroxyapatite phantoms for calibration. Each image set contains between 1000 and 2300 8-bit PNG images. The datasets are available on Figshare.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from lumbar spine segments of female C57BL/6 mice, as well as hydroxyapatite phantoms for calibration.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

1. Skyscan 1172 benchtop micro-CT (Bruker Micro-CT, Kontich, Belgium): This device was used to scan the lumbar spine segments of the mice. It was set to perform high-resolution scanning using specific parameters such as 50 keV and 198 µA, a 0.5 mm aluminum filter, sample rotation of 360°, and image rotation steps of 0.1°.

2. Custom-made specimen holder: A custom-made specimen holder was used to center the samples on the rotating stage of the micro-CT. It contained a polyethylene tube with each sample in an EtOH atmosphere.

3. Polystyrene rings and board: The animals were gently fixated on a polystyrene board with hind-and forelimbs extended during the dissection process. The spine segments were supported between two polystyrene rings.

4. Fixation medium: The frozen carcasses were thawed in fixation medium, which consisted of 4% PFA (paraformaldehyde) and 70% EtOH (ethanol).

5. Ethanol: The extracted spine segments were stored in 70% EtOH at 4 °C until scanning and further histological embedding.

6. Technovit 9100: The samples were embedded in Technovit 9100, a embedding material provided by Kulzer GmbH, Hanau, Germany.

7. NRecon software: The manufacturer software NRecon, Version 1.6.8.0, provided by Bruker MicroCT, was used for the reconstruction of the micro-CT data.

8. Figshare: The datasets were made available on Figshare, a data sharing platform.

It is important to note that no custom code was used in the data acquisition process.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involved comparing and matching the micro-CT data to standard non-decalcified histomorphometry. After the micro-CT scans, the samples were embedded in Technovit 9100 PMMA, cut into 5 µm thick sections, and stained with von Kossa/Toluidine blue to distinguish mineralized material and soft tissue. The 3D data of the reconstructed micro-CT scans were then matched with the stained 2D slices using the oblique slice function of the 3D visualization program Amira. Architectural details were identified and matched in the high-resolution images and in the histological stained sections. Additionally, a series of 3 obliquely-resliced micro-CT images were used to quantify the correlation between standard 2D histomorphometric measurements and virtual slices in the 3D datasets. The technical reliability and accuracy of the data were confirmed through this annotation process.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by the authors themselves.
annotation_infrastructure:
Yes, the tools or infrastructures used during the annotation process are:
- Amira (3D visualization program)
- ImageJ (Fiji) (open-source image analysis software)
- BoneJ (ImageJ plugin)
annotation_validation_methods: Inter-annotator agreement, Expert Annotations
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people. It represents meteorological variables, microbial indicators of water quality, prokaryotic taxa, and coefficients of correlation between microbiological indicators.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The data collected includes taxonomic data, meteorological variables, longitudinal measurements of microbial indicators of water quality, relative frequency of prokaryotic taxa, coefficients of correlation between microbiological indicators, and sample information.
uses_data:
The collected data for this study includes taxonomic data, meteorological variables, longitudinal measurements of microbial indicators of water quality, relative frequency of prokaryotic taxa, coefficients of correlation between microbiological indicators, and sample information. 

The taxonomic data, including raw data of 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing, has been deposited in the Dryad repository and is listed in Table 2. The 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing data can be accessed through the BioProject accession number PRJNA565393 in the NCBI BioProject database.

Meteorological variables, such as air temperature and rain precipitation amounts, were recorded at the time of sampling from the Albany, NY, office of the National Weather Service. The data for these variables can be found in the "Sampling_site_metadata_table.csv" available at Dryad.

Longitudinal measurements of microbial indicators of water quality are shown in Figure 2 of the document. These measurements include E. coli concentration, coliform concentration, Enterococcus sp. concentration, integron 1 relative abundance, and endotoxin concentration. The data points in the figure represent the raw values for each sample, with surface water samples presented in blue, sediments in black, and outflow in red.

Figure 3 of the document shows the relative frequency of prokaryotic taxa at the class level in samples of outflow, sediments, and water. The 10 most abundant classes and their prevalence in each sample type are shown. The specific sites and dates of collection for each sample can be found in the "Sample_type_date_site_season_name.csv" available at Dryad.

Table 1 of the document displays the coefficients of correlation between microbiological indicators. This table provides information on the relationships between different indicators.

The "Combined_Scripts.rmd" file in the Dryad repository contains the commands used for QIIME2, phyloseq, ggplot2, and fantaxtic. This file is available in r-markdown format and can be used to reproduce the analysis.

Overall, the collected data includes taxonomic data, meteorological variables, longitudinal measurements of microbial indicators, relative frequency of prokaryotic taxa, coefficients of correlation, and sample information. The data and materials are available in the Dryad repository.
collection_explanation: The dataset was collected by sampling various meteorological variables. The air temperature at the time of sampling was recorded from the Albany, NY, office of the National Weather Service. Additionally, rain precipitation amounts in the 12, 24, 38, 48, and 72 hours prior to sampling were gathered from the same office. The data collection process involved taking samples at four different sites and from the Bard Water treatment plant outflow. The samples were evaluated for various microbial indicators of water quality, including E. coli concentration, coliform concentration, Enterococcus sp. concentration, integron 1 relative abundance, and endotoxin concentration. The raw value for each sample was recorded for outflow and water samples, while the average of two biological replicates was recorded for sediment samples. The dataset includes longitudinal measurements of these microbial indicators, as well as the relative frequency of prokaryotic taxa at the class level. The specific sites and dates of collection for each sample are provided in a comma-separated file available at Dryad. The dataset also includes coefficients of correlation between microbiological indicators and a list of data and materials available with the study.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from taxonomic records, 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing, DNA sequencing, raw data analysis, water samples, sediments, outflow, microbiological indicators, coefficients of correlation, meteorological variables.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

- 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing for DNA sequencing
- Dryad repository for depositing data and outputs
- NCBI BioProject database for depositing raw data
- Albany, NY, office of the National Weather Service for recording air temperature and rain precipitation amounts
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involved several steps. First, the raw data of 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing was deposited in the NCBI BioProject database. Then, the data was analyzed using QIIME2, phyloseq, ggplot2, and fantaxtic. The analysis included identifying and classifying prokaryotic taxa at the class level. The results of the analysis were used to generate figures and tables, which were deposited in the Dryad repository. No custom code was used in the data generation or processing.

authoring_funding: Yes, this work was supported by the NORMAN network, the Danish Environmental Protection Agency, and The Aarhus University Research Foundation.
authoring_funding_grant_id: There are no grant reference numbers mentioned in the provided context.
authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. Assessment of the impact of method transfer on the explored chemical space of the samples and the quality of the generated spectra.
2. Development of NTA algorithms and workflows by providing a collection of successfully identified compounds and retention time indices obtained over a wide range of instruments and analytical conditions.
3. Evaluation of individual laboratory practices.
4. Assessment of the impact of different data processing strategies on the identified features and the level of confidence associated with the identifications.
5. Benchmarking for future developments of algorithms and workflows for NTA experiments.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any testing of the dataset using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people. The dataset consists of raw data, converted files, and identified features related to chemical analysis of samples such as blank, drinking water, and river water.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset consists of samples related to river water and drinking water, which were analyzed using different methods. The participants in the study were given the same samples and were requested to analyze them using a pre-defined method and their own in-house methods. The dataset includes raw data from 21 different laboratories.
uses_data:
The collected data in this study consists of three different data records. 

Record 1 includes mzXML files for samples related to river water and drinking water, analyzed using the pre-defined method. These samples were exposed for 2 and 4 days. There are a total of 157 mzXML files in this record.

Record 2 includes mzXML files for samples related to river water and drinking water, analyzed using the in-house method. These samples were also exposed for 2 and 4 days. There are a total of 134 mzXML files in this record.

Record 3 consists of an excel file that includes the details of participants and the experimental conditions associated with each mzXML file. This file also includes information about the software packages used for data acquisition and pre-processing.

The dataset was collected during an international collaborative Inter-Laboratory Study (ILS) organized through the Norman Network. The study aimed to assess the uncertainty in the identified compounds caused by different NTA workflows and spectral databases. Passive sampling (PS) strategy was used to sample river water at a drinking water intake and post-treatment for the production of drinking water. PS devices were used to accumulate chemicals through diffusion over time. The participants in the study were given the same "ready for injection" samples and were requested to analyze them using a pre-defined method and their own in-house methods. The dataset includes raw data from 21 different laboratories, using different LC columns, instrumentations, chromatographic gradients, and MS acquisitions.

This dataset can be used to assess the impact of method transfer, chromatographic conditions, and data processing workflows on the results of NTA approaches. It can also serve as a benchmark for the future development of algorithms for NTA workflows. The script for the extraction of the IS signal and the plots in this data descriptor is available in a specific repository.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through an international collaborative Inter-Laboratory Study (ILS) organized by the Norman Network. The study aimed to assess the uncertainty in the identification of compounds caused by different Non-Target Analysis (NTA) workflows and spectral databases.

The data collection process involved the use of passive sampling (PS) devices to sample river water at a drinking water intake and post-treatment for the production of drinking water. PS devices accumulate chemicals through diffusion over time when deployed in water. This allows for the pre-concentration of chemicals from a complex matrix while leaving behind unwanted matrix components. The use of PS enables the sampling of chemicals often found at trace levels in water and the environment.

All participants in the ILS were given the same "ready for injection" samples consisting of two surface water and two drinking water PS extracts. They were requested to analyze these samples using a pre-defined method for liquid chromatography (LC) and mass spectrometry (MS). Participants were also required to analyze the samples using their own "in-house" methods.

The dataset includes raw data from 21 different laboratories, each using different reversed-phase LC columns and instrumentations, chromatographic gradients, and MS acquisitions. This allows for the assessment of the impact of method transfer, chromatographic conditions, and data processing workflows on the results of NTA approaches.

The participants were asked to provide the raw data in vendor format, converted files in mzXML format, raw feature lists associated with each sample, and the top 50 identified features with the level of confidence in the identifications based on the Schymanski scale.

The experimental design of the study allows for the systematic assessment of the impact of method transfer, chromatography approach, and data acquisition on the explored chemical space. It also enables the evaluation of the impact of different data processing strategies on the identified features and the level of confidence associated with the identifications.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an external team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from participants in the international collaborative ILS organized through the Norman Network. The participants used a pre-defined method and an individually developed in-house method for the analysis. The data includes raw data from 21 different laboratories using different LC columns and instrumentations. The participants were also asked to analyze the samples using data independent acquisition (DIA) mode.
collection_infrastructure: The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include NTA/extended suspect screening workflow, RPLC coupled with HRMS, vendor format for raw data, mzMXL format for converted files, chromatography approach, data acquisition, method transfer, chromatographic conditions, data processing strategies, Thermo Fisher Scientific instruments (Orbitraps), instruments relying on the time-of-flight (TOF) principle, data independent acquisition (DIA), Waters MSE, Bruker broadband collision-induced dissociation (bbCID), Agilent all-ions MS/MS, Thermo Q-Orbitrap instruments (All Ion Fragmentation or variable Data-Independent Analysis), AB Sciex Sequential Window Acquisition of All Theoretical Mass Spectra (SWATH-MS), and in-house methods.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process done over the data involves performing a complete non-target analysis (NTA) or extended suspect screening workflow using two different experimental approaches. The first approach is a pre-defined method, which includes liquid chromatography (LC) separation and mass spectrometric data acquisition. The participants are given detailed instructions on how to set up the exact conditions on their instruments. The second approach is an individually developed in-house method. 

The participants are requested to provide the raw data in vendor format, converted files in mzXML format, raw feature lists associated with each sample, and the top 50 identified features including the level of confidence in the identifications based on the Schymanski scale. The experimental design allows for the systematic assessment of the impact of method transfer, chromatography approach, and data acquisition on the explored chemical space. It also enables the evaluation of the impact of different data processing strategies on the identified features and the level of confidence associated with the identifications.

uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. Signal peak detection in apple leaves.
2. Optical signal intensity assessments in apple leaves.
3. Depth intensity profile analysis of persimmon and apple leaves.
4. Quantified thickness-based thresholding for leaf abnormalities detection.
