authoring_funding: No
authoring_funding_grant_id: No, there are no grant reference numbers mentioned in the provided context.
authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset are to analyze biodiversity change at the level of local communities and individual species, and to gain insights into vegetation-plot resurveys and their methodological challenges.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any testing of the dataset using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: Yes, the context mentions that the dataset cannot be considered representative of Germany's vegetation, neither spatially, nor temporally. It also mentions that the dataset faces various methodological challenges and is not fully representative of the vegetation of Germany. Therefore, there are generalization limits and non-recommended uses of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The context does not provide any information about the data representing people.
uses_collected_from_people: No, the subjects of the collection process are not humans. The context mentions that the data collected is vegetation data, specifically vegetation-plot records.
uses_data:
The collected data for the ReSurveyGermany dataset was compiled by U.J. and H.B. All authors were involved in collecting the datasets, which were then harmonized by U.J. and H.B. The first draft, figures, and tables were produced by H.B. All authors discussed and commented on the manuscript and contributed to the revised versions.

The data underwent a quality check during the import process into the Turboveg 2 database. This check included taxonomical harmonization of the data, which was adjusted to GermanSL 1.3 during data entry.

The data is available under the terms specified by CC BY 4.0. A separate database was created for each project that contributed data using the Turboveg 2 data-management software. The database consists of two main tables, following the structure of Turboveg and common practice in vegetation science. The plot-species-abundance table contains six fields, including the unique Plot observation ID, the observed taxon name, the vertical layer in which the species was observed, and the taxon's cover in the plot.

Within each project, the field RS_PLOT holds a plot resurvey ID that connects plot observations from different times made on the same plot. The field LOCALITY provides more details on the locality in German. In some cases, the previously provided location was not precise enough, leading to the use of several plots to match one previous plot in resurveys. This results in a one-to-many relationship. If a set of plots at the same site was compared with plot records from another point in time, several plot records in the same year might have the same RS_PLOT code. The unique code of the one-time observation is a combination of RS_SITE, RS_PLOT, and the year when the plot was surveyed. The exact date of each record is reported if available. The field YEAR lists the year in which the plot was (re)surveyed, and if available, the year of the underlying publication is also reported.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through a collaborative effort involving multiple authors and data contributors. The idea for the project and the compilation of the data were conceived by U.J. and H.B. All authors were involved in collecting the datasets, which were then harmonized by U.J. and H.B. The first draft of the manuscript, as well as the figures and tables, were produced by H.B. All authors discussed and commented on the manuscript and contributed to the revised versions.

The surveyors who recorded vegetation in the field and provided the data are acknowledged and thanked. The dataset also includes data contributed by others who made their data available or helped in recording the data. The names of these data contributors are listed in the acknowledgements section.

In terms of the collection process, in the ideal case, plots are permanently marked using poles, metal tent pegs, or magnets, and metal detectors are used to retrieve their position. This is indicated as "01" in the LOC_METHOD field of Table 3. However, in other cases, plots may only have exact coordinates obtained through GPS ("03" or "04") or other descriptions of the exact locality, such as from maps ("05"). These plots are referred to as semi-permanent plots as they are not marked on the ground.

The dataset also includes information on the cover scale used for the record, a reference to the data source or publication ID, and the specific table and column from which the data were taken. The orientation of the plot can be determined from the SLOPE (inclination) and slope ASPECT (compass directions) variables.

The dataset was archived with the assistance of the iDiv Data & Code Unit and the support for the project was provided by the German Centre for Integrative Biodiversity Research (iDiv) Halle-Jena-Leipzig, funded by the German Research Foundation (DFG-FZT 118, 202548816). The manuscript also benefited from the comments of reviewers and the contributions of Javier Gamarra.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from surveyors who recorded vegetation in the field and provided the data. The data contributors who made their data available or helped in recording the data include Thea Dittmann, Alexandra Erfmeier, Bernd Gerken, Kerstin Günther, Sabine Heinz, Wilfried Hakes, Heike Heklau, Alfons Henrichfreise, Elisabeth Hüllbusch, Andreas Huwer, Anneke Immoor, Sophie Luise Kühn, Benjamin Krause, Sebastian Leonhardt, Thomas Meineke, Jutta Rach, Jennifer Reinecke, Ulrich Scheidel, and Immo Vollmer.
collection_infrastructure: The tools and devices used during the collection process include surveyors recording vegetation in the field, data contributors who made their data available or helped in recording the data, and the data-management software Turboveg 2.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process involves marking the plots with permanent markers such as poles, metal tent pegs, or magnets and using metal detectors to retrieve their position. This is indicated by the "01" code in the LOC_METHOD field. In some cases, plots may only have exact coordinates (using GPS coordinates, "03" or "04") or other descriptions of the locality (such as from maps, "05"), but they are not marked on the ground, which are referred to as semi-permanent plots. The annotation process also includes rounding the longitude and latitude coordinates to two decimal digits, resulting in a mean uncertainty of 371 m. The annotation process is linked to the plot metadata through a unique Plot observation ID, which includes information on the observed taxon, the vertical layer in which the species was observed, and the taxon's cover in the plot. The taxon names in the plot-species-abundance table are standardized using German SL 1.3, and the nomenclature for vascular plants follows Wisskirchen et al. with additional aggregations to higher taxonomic levels according to German SL 1.3.
annotation_team_type: The context does not provide information about whether the data was annotated by an internal team, an external team, or a crowdsourcing team.
annotation_infrastructure: Yes, the annotation process involves the use of permanent markers such as poles, metal tent pegs, or magnets, and metal detectors.
annotation_validation_methods: Not mentioned
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

uses_data:
The collected data consists of three datasets, labeled Dataset 1, Dataset 2, and Dataset 3. The datasets have been anonymized and are available in XLSX and CSV formats on the Open Science Framework platform. The datasets include responses from participants who passed attention checks and did not skip any sections of the survey.

In Dataset 1, there were a total of 813 participants, with 93 female, 122 male, 3 reporting "other," and 1 skipping the gender question. The participants' ages ranged from 20 to 66 years, with a mean age of 36.6 and a standard deviation of 8.5. The participants were asked for their age, rather than the year in which they were born.

Dataset 2 consists of responses from 219 respondents from Japan. The specific details of this dataset are not provided in the given context.

The collected data also includes information on the differences between the datasets, as summarized in Table 1. Additionally, Table 2 presents the results of principal axis factoring of DAQ in Dataset 1, and Table 3 shows the split-half reliability and correlation of DAQ and EDAS.

The technical validation of the datasets involved examining the reliability and convergent validity of the Existential Death Anxiety scale (EDAS) and the brief form of the Supernatural Belief Scale (SBS). The EDAS and DAQ were found to be highly correlated, with a correlation coefficient of 0.77. The split-half reliability for the EDAS was 0.96. The SBS also showed high levels of reliability, with a split-half reliability of 0.96. Multiple convergent validity checks were conducted, including analyzing the relationship between religious affiliation and SBS scores.

In summary, the collected data includes information on participant demographics, such as age and gender, as well as the results of various analyses conducted on the datasets, including reliability and convergent validity checks.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through an online survey using the Qualtrics platform and Amazon Mechanical Turk. The survey was conducted in multiple countries, including the specified countries of Brazil, South Korea, the Philippines, and Russia. A total of 2,058 participants attempted to start the survey, but 37 were disqualified for not being from the specified countries and 408 did not provide informed consent. 

An attention check was included in the survey, where participants were asked to respond to the PANAS by checking only "none of the above". 684 respondents failed this attention check, and an additional 129 participants did not complete the survey. 

After data collection was completed, participants' free-list responses were translated into English using Qualtrics. The dataset consists of almost equal numbers of males and females, with some variation in individual samples from different countries. 

The age ranges of the participants were similar across samples, with an average age of 35.4 and a standard deviation of 10. 

The dataset has been anonymized and is available in XLSX and CSV formats on the Open Science Framework platform, along with the questionnaires. Abbreviation guides for variable names are also provided. 

In another dataset, participants were asked for their age instead of the year of birth. This dataset included 93 female and 122 male participants, with a few participants reporting "other" or skipping the gender question. The ages ranged from 20 to 66 years, with an average age of 36.6 and a standard deviation of 8.5. 

In Dataset 1, which was collected from Amazon Mechanical Turk in the USA, 813 individuals participated. The study was advertised on Amazon Mechanical Turk and participants were paid $1 for completing the survey. A total of 892 individuals attempted to participate, but some did not provide consent, failed the attention check, or did not complete the survey. The attention check was disguised as the PANAS, where participants were asked to only check "none of the above". The questionnaires included demographic information and were presented in a specific order.

collection_sources: The data has been collected from Brazil, South Korea, the Philippines, Russia, Japan (3lancers dataset), and participants from unspecified countries.

Additionally, the document mentions the use of questionnaires such as the DAQ (Death Anxiety Questionnaire) and EDAS (Existential Death Anxiety Scale) for data collection.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process done over the data involved several steps. First, the datasets were anonymized and made available in XLSX and CSV formats on the Open Science Framework platform. The datasets only included participants who passed attention checks and did not skip any sections of the survey.

To validate the Existential Death Anxiety scale (EDAS) and the brief form of the Supernatural Belief Scale (SBS-6), preliminary reliability and convergent analyses were conducted. The EDAS was validated by inspecting the correlation between EDAS and the Death Anxiety Questionnaire (DAQ). The EDAS showed high split-half reliability and was found to have a single factor solution.

The SBS-6 also showed high split-half reliability and a single factor solution. Multiple convergent validity checks were conducted, including analyzing the relationship between SBS scores and participants' religious affiliations. ANOVA tests found that stated religion predicted SBS scores.

The annotation process also involved analyzing the internal reliability and convergent validity of the measures in different contexts represented in the datasets. The DAQ, EDAS, and SBS consistently showed high levels of internal reliability and convergent validity, with some variations in correlations with religious behaviors and self-attributed religiosity and spirituality in certain countries.

Overall, the annotation process involved validating the measures, analyzing their reliability and validity, and examining their relationships with other variables of interest.

uses_data:
The collected data is a dataset on the affiliation of venture capitalists (VCs) in China between 2000 and 2016. The dataset is available from figshare.com and consists of two plain text files with csv formatting: "VCAC.csv" and "Alias.csv". 

The "VCAC.csv" file contains information on the affiliations of 6,379 VCs in terms of VC_fullname. It includes a total of 108,443 VC-year observations. It should be noted that although the dataset appears to be a balanced panel data with each VC having 17 years of records, this is not the case in reality due to VCs being established in different years. To account for this, the dataset includes cases where VCs may have invested before they were formally founded. These cases are denoted by the variable "Cross_sectional".

The csv files are in UTF-8 and are comma separated. The VC names are in Chinese. The authors of the dataset mention that they will continue to maintain the dataset and may add new features or variables in the future based on their research or suggestions from dataset users. In such cases, a log file will be provided to explain any new features.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected by compiling information from the CVSource database, which is a reliable database of investment deals in China. The dataset includes information on VCs that have invested in China between 2000 and 2016. The information collected includes VC name, age, location, records of investments and portfolio ventures, syndication partners, and VC affiliation. VC affiliation information was gathered from public sources such as Tianyancha, Qichacha, Bloomberg, and Crunchbase. Information for domestic VCs was mainly collected from Tianyancha and Qichacha, while information for foreign VCs was gathered from their official websites, Bloomberg, and Crunchbase. In cases where information was inconsistent across sources, additional information from all potential public sources was used to triangulate the data. 

To compose the dataset, the names of the VCs from the CVSource database were used to search for their 1st-level shareholders in public sources such as Tianyancha and Qichacha. Initially, this step was done using machine algorithms, resulting in 28,968 unique 1st-level shareholders. However, due to inconsistencies in VC names, manual double-checking and correction were done to ensure alignment between the names from CVSource and those collected from public sources. Duplications in VC names were also checked to avoid treating former and current names as different VCs. This process resulted in 22,757 unique 1st-level shareholders for 6,379 unique VCs.

The dataset is available in two plain text files with CSV formatting, namely "VCAC.csv" and "Alias.csv". The "VCAC.csv" file contains affiliation information for the 6,379 VCs that have made investments in China between 2000 and 2016. The dataset includes a total of 108,443 VC-year observations. It should be noted that although the dataset appears to be a balanced panel data with each VC having 17 years of records, this is not the case in reality due to VCs being established in different years. However, a format of balanced panel data is used to account for cases where VCs may have invested before they were formally founded. The dataset also includes a variable called "Cross_sectional" to denote the inclusion of such cases.

To ensure the quality of the dataset, measures were taken for technical validation.

collection_sources: CVSource, Tianyancha, Qichacha, Bloomberg, Crunchbase
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

- CVSource database: Used to generate a list of VCs who have invested in China between 2000 and 2016.
- Tianyancha and Qichacha: Public sources used to collect information on the 1st-level shareholders of the VCs.
- Machine and algorithm: Initially used to collect information on the 1st-level shareholders, but manual double-checking and correction were done to ensure accuracy.
- Public sources (Tianyancha, Qichacha, Bloomberg, Crunchbase): Used to gather information on VC affiliation, including shareholder name, equity ratio, and year.
- Media reports: Checked for information on VCs that were not captured by the above sources.
- Additional public sources (VC websites, press releases, media reports, IPO prospectuses): Triangulated data with additional information to address inconsistencies.
- figshare.com: Platform used to make the VCAC dataset available.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process for the data involved several steps. First, the authors developed a coding scheme for classifying VCs. Then, data was collected from various sources, including CVSource, Qichacha.com, and Tianyancha.com. The coding process was overseen by the second author, who organized human coders and checked and classified the affiliation of VCs. The third author specifically coded for the nature of SOE (State-Owned Enterprise) on Layer-II and checked the Layer-I coded results for all types of shareholders. The authors also compared their coding results with prior studies to ensure consistency. In cases where the judgement was not obvious, the first and third authors provided independent opinions and made final decisions. The dataset was further validated by merging VC affiliation data from VCAC.csv with investment deal information from CVSource. This validation process involved comparing the attributes of VCs in the dataset with those reported in prior studies.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by a combination of an internal team (the authors) and external team members, specifically 17 senior students and master students from two famous universities in China who were recruited as part-time research assistants. The coding process was overseen by the authors, who provided training and double-checked the results manually. In cases of disagreement, the first author was involved to give an independent opinion, and the team would discuss to achieve consensus.
annotation_infrastructure: No, the context does not provide information about the specific tools or infrastructures used during the annotation process.
annotation_validation_methods: Unknown
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset are taxonomic, phylogenetic, or genomic purposes, as well as data integration, database creation, species comparison design, and sequence-based phylogenetic analysis.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The context does not explicitly state that the data represents people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are cyanobacterial strains, not humans.
uses_data: The collected data consists of a dataset of cyanobacterial strains, which is stored in an online database called CyanoType. The dataset includes 371 strains and is the first version of the database (CyanoType v.1). Each strain in the dataset is associated with various information, including strain synonymy and/or co-identity, strain categorization, habitat, accession numbers for molecular data, taxonomy and nomenclature notes, hierarchical automatic classification, phylogenetic placement, and important bibliographic references. The dataset has been extensively checked for double entries, errors, or inconsistencies, and the data or metadata for each entry has been revised. Whenever available, bibliographic references are provided for each entry. The dataset will be periodically updated by adding new strains and revising and adding up-to-date metadata for existing strains. The dataset, sequence alignments, and tree files are deposited at FigShare. The dataset file (CyanoType_data_v1.0.csv) is a semi-comma separated values file containing taxonomic and phylogenetic-related data, as well as other useful information for each cyanobacterial strain. The information for each strain includes the accession number of the nucleotide sequence, strain ID, taxonomic synonyms or other strain names, and co-identical strains or other strain codes. The strains are categorized based on various criteria, such as being the type strain, reference strain, strain with a sequenced genome, or strain studied from exsiccata. The dataset is intended to be a valuable resource for taxonomic, phylogenetic, and genomic studies of cyanobacteria.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through a combination of literature searches, online database searches, and data mining. The criteria for inclusion of cyanobacterial strains in the dataset were established, with three main groups of strains considered: (1) strains that were used as Type strains for the proposal or establishment of a new taxon, (2) strains that are included as Reference strains in Bergey's Manual of Systematic Bacteriology, and (3) strains that have their genome sequenced and publicly available. 

For Type strains, the literature search was guided by information from the work of Komárek et al., which lists cyanobacterial genera for which the holotype (Type species) was described using a modern, polyphasic taxonomic approach. 

For Reference strains, searches were performed in the Bergey's Manual to identify strains from all clusters or subclusters defined in the manual. If the 16S rRNA gene sequences for the Reference strains were not available, known relatives (as indicated in the Manual) were included.

Data and metadata acquisition were performed through manual data mining in public molecular and taxonomic databases, as well as searches on websites of Culture Collections. 

Strains with available cyanobacterial genomes were also included in the dataset. The work of Shih et al. was used as a reference, and the Assembly database and other NCBI resources were used to search for genomes and obtain accession numbers and 16S rRNA gene nucleotide sequences.

A total of 251 out of 372 strains with available genomes in NCBI were included in the dataset. Prochlorococcus spp. were not included due to overrepresentation and phylogenetic redundancy.

All strains with available 16S rRNA gene nucleotide sequences were subjected to a phylogenetic study. The sequences were obtained through searches in the NCBI Nucleotide database, and the adequacy of the sequences length for multiple alignment and further analyses was checked. The 16S rRNA gene sequences were also submitted to the RDP Naive Bayesian rRNA Classifier pipeline for hierarchical classification.

The strains were classified at higher taxonomic levels (Order and Family) and the nomenclatural status of taxon names was verified according to taxonomic concepts followed in Komarek et al. (at the Genus level) and in AlgaeBase (Species level). Additional taxonomy or nomenclature notes/clarifications were added to the dataset when relevant.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects:
- Type strains for the proposal or establishment of a new taxon
- Reference strains in Bergey's Manual of Systematic Bacteriology
- Strains with publicly available genome sequences
- Literature searches
- Online databases (such as NCBI and AlgaeBase)
- Culture Collections
- Cyanobacterial genomes available in NCBI
- 16S rRNA gene nucleotide sequences from strains
- RDP Naive Bayesian rRNA Classifier v2.6 pipeline for classification
collection_infrastructure: The tools, devices, or infrastructure used during the collection process include literature and online database searches, data mining in public molecular and taxonomic databases, searches on websites of Culture Collections, and the use of the NCBI Nucleotide database and other NCBI resources.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process for the data involved extensive checking for double entries, errors, and inconsistencies. The data and metadata for each entry, particularly the category attribution, were revised. Bibliographic references were provided for each entry. Users of the dataset or the database were encouraged to assess the validity and accuracy of the data and provide feedback. The information was updated after curation by the team. In the future, the information for each entry may be curated on a voluntary basis, with quality control procedures implemented. Users would need to request permission to become contributors and have user accounts. Observations made by contributors would be flagged and sent to the administrator for approval. Once approved, the observations would be recorded and accessible to other users as updated information for that strain.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by an internal team (the authors) and may be curated on a voluntary basis in the future.
annotation_infrastructure: No
annotation_validation_methods: Ground Truth Labels, Inter-annotator agreement, Expert Annotations
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

authoring_funding: Yes, this work has been funded by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation via the Vector-borne Disease Network (VecNet).
authoring_funding_grant_id: No, the grant reference numbers are not provided in the context.
authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. Assessing the impact of vector control measures on malaria transmission.
2. Allocating malaria control resources.
3. Identifying knowledge gaps in the behavior and life history characteristics of the DVS.
4. Testing specific hypotheses relating to the DVS of Africa.
5. Geolocating sites and providing contextual information.
6. Evaluating human biting rate.
7. Analyzing bionomics data for malaria transmission.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No, the data of the dataset does not represent people. The dataset is focused on collecting data on mosquitoes and their biting rates.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are mosquitoes, specifically the vector species of human malaria.
uses_data:
The collected data consists of bionomics data for the DVS (vector species) of human malaria. This dataset is the first comprehensive global database of published bionomics data for these vector species. The dataset is valuable for researchers and policy makers in assessing the impact of vector control measures on malaria transmission and allocating malaria control resources. The dataset allows users to search for data related to specific vector species, geographic locations, or bionomic parameters. It also helps identify knowledge gaps in the behavior and life history characteristics of the vector species across their geographic ranges.

The dataset includes data records from a total of 1,837 published sources and 6 unpublished sources. These data records are for unique site-date-species combinations. The dataset covers a wide range of geographic locations, as shown in Figure 2. Table 2 provides a list of countries for which at least one data record is available. The dataset also spans a wide range of years, as shown in Figure 3, with no clear pattern in the number of published bionomic studies from each year.

Table 1 provides summary metrics for the dataset, including the total number of data sources reviewed, the number of data records available for the most commonly reported bionomic parameters, and the number of individual sampling sites. Table 3 presents the number of data sources, individual sites, and data records for a selection of the most important vector species for malaria transmission.

The dataset is publicly available online as comma delimited files and can be accessed through the Malaria Atlas Project (MAP) website and the VecNet digital library. Each survey included in the dataset has been disaggregated to individual sites, dates, and vector species. The dataset includes various bionomic parameters such as the number of parous females, daily survival rate, fecundity, and gonotrophic cycle duration.

It is important to note that the published studies included in the dataset did not use consistent units for each parameter, and no attempt has been made to standardize the units. Users are advised to examine the sampling methods and units fields provided for each parameter when using the data.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through a multi-step process. 

First, the sites were geolocated using a protocol detailed in a previous study. The site location was determined by searching for the site name in online gazetteers or other geolocational resources. Contextual information provided in the original reference was used to confirm the correct site. The data locations were then attributed to different area types, including point locations, wide areas, small polygons, or large polygons, depending on the extent of the sampling area.

The bionomics datasets were obtained from a total of 1,837 published data sources. Data were abstracted from 871 of these sources, and additional data were incorporated from 6 unpublished sources through author contacts. A data record was defined as a data point for a unique site-date-species combination. Table 1 provides information on the total number of data sources reviewed and the number of data records available for the most commonly reported bionomic parameters.

Figure 2 shows the locations of the bionomics data study sites, indicating the global spread of the data. Table 2 lists the countries for which at least one data record is available. Figure 3 displays the temporal spread of the data, showing the starting year of the sampling period for each data source.

Table 3 presents the number of data sources containing bionomics data for a selection of the most important disease vector species (DVS) for malaria transmission, along with the number of individual sampling sites. The table also shows the number of data records available for these species for a selection of key parameters. It is important to note that the number of data records is summed for members of a species complex in the summary table, but they are recorded separately for each sibling species in the bionomics datasets if reported in the primary data source.

The dataset also includes information on the resting location preference of the vectors. This includes data on indoor resting behavior, outdoor resting behavior, and other relevant sampling methods. The data includes the total number of unfed, fed, and gravid mosquitoes collected for each sampling method, as well as the total number of mosquitoes collected, including unfed, fed, and gravid females. The dataset also provides information on the unit of measurement for the resting data, such as raw count data, percentage, or per man hour. Additionally, the dataset includes the fed to gravid ratio, calculated as the total number of fed specimens divided by the total number of gravid specimens.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from published data sources, unpublished sources, MAP DVS database, PubMed, and Web of Science.
collection_infrastructure:
Based on the given context, the tools, devices, or infrastructure used during the collection process include:

- Data sources: A total of 1,837 published data sources were reviewed, and data were abstracted from 871 of these. Additional data were incorporated from 6 unpublished sources as a result of author contacts.
- Published data searches: Searches were conducted using the MAP DVS database, PubMed, and Web of Science to identify publications detailing occurrence data for the DVS.
- Literature review: Articles written in English, French, Portuguese, and Spanish were read to identify publications with useful bionomics data.
- Digital copies: Full text digital copies of all publications were obtained.
- Geographic spread: Figure 2 shows the locations of the bionomics data study sites, indicating the global spread of the data.
- Temporal spread: Figure 3 displays the starting year of the sampling period for each data source, showing the temporal spread of the data.
- Tables: Table 1 provides summary metrics for the datasets and most commonly reported bionomic parameters. Table 2 lists the countries for which bionomics data are available. Table 3 presents the number of data sources and individual sites for the most commonly reported bionomic parameters for a selection of the most important DVS in each region.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process for the bionomics data involved several steps. First, all data were reviewed and checked by a second data abstractor to ensure accuracy and consistency. The values recorded were also checked to ensure they fell within the possible ranges and had associated units. The geo-locations of the data were confirmed by a second data abstractor, and coordinates were plotted to ensure they were accurate and fell within the correct country. 

Additionally, the dataset compiled data from various published sources, totaling 1,837 data sources. Data abstracted from 871 of these sources were included, and additional data from 6 unpublished sources were incorporated through author contacts. The data records were defined as unique combinations of site, date, and species. The number of data records available for the most commonly reported bionomic parameters for each species was reported in Table 1. 

The site geo-positioning process involved geolocating the majority of sites using online gazetteers and other geolocational resources. Site names were searched, and contextual information provided in the original reference was used to confirm the correct site. The data locations were attributed to different area types, such as point locations, wide areas, small polygons, or large polygons, depending on the extent of the sampling area.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by an internal team (e.g the authors) and additional data was incorporated from 6 unpublished sources through author contacts.
annotation_infrastructure: No, the context does not provide information about the specific tools or infrastructures used during the annotation process.
annotation_validation_methods: The context does not provide information about the validation methods used to validate the labels.
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide any information about the demographic characteristics of the team who annotate the data.

uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset include conservation analysis, genotype file processing, and evaluation of coding potential of lncRNAs.
uses_ml_approach: Yes, the dataset has been tested using the machine learning method Random Forest (RF) in the FEELnc tool.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people. The context mentions gene expression, genome browser, gene annotation, gene and transcript level quantification, eQTL results, trait association, genotype file processing, and functional characterization of lncRNA. These terms indicate that the dataset is related to genetic information and not specifically about people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The data collected in this study includes information on the conservation of exons between protein-coding genes and long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs).
uses_data:
The collected data in this study includes information on the conservation of exons between protein-coding genes and long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs). The analysis was performed using the bigWigAverageOverBed and cons30way tracks downloaded from the UCSC genome browser. The cons30way track provides multiple alignments of 30 vertebrate species and measurements of evolutionary conservation using two methods (phastCons and phyloP) from the PHAST package. The multiple alignments were generated using the multiz tool in the UCSC/Penn State Bioinformatics comparative genomics alignment pipeline.

To create an exon-level BED file, the lncRNAKB GFF annotation file was used separately for protein-coding genes and lncRNAs. Overlapping exons within transcripts were merged to avoid counting conservation scores of overlapping base pairs more than once. The bigWigAverageOverBed function was used to calculate the average conservation score across all base pairs for each exon.

Line graphs were used to visualize and compare the average conservation score differences between lncRNAs and protein-coding exons. The data was visualized using Highcharts software and plotly.

The code used to perform the analysis and generate the data displayed and deposited on lncRNAKB is available through the GitHub repository: https://github.com/seifudd/lncRNAKB.

In addition to the conservation analysis, the dataset also includes information on SNPs that alter gene expression, transcripts in the gene, trait associations, and network and pathway information. Dynamic tables and visualizations are provided for these data as well.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through a multi-step process. First, a literature search was conducted to identify widely used lncRNA annotations and databases. A total of six databases were selected for integration into the knowledgebase: CHESS, LNCipedia, NONCODE, FANTOM, MiTranscriptome, and BIGTranscriptome. GFF annotation files from these databases were downloaded and parsed to the same format. The annotations were required to be according to the hg38 genome build, and annotations from the previous hg19 build were updated using the UCSC liftOver tool. The gene and transcript records were split into individual files by chromosome and labeled with location information. Redundant records between annotation files were removed.

The integration of the annotations was performed using a cumulative stepwise intersection method. The reference annotation used was CHESS, which contains both protein-coding and lncRNA genes. The other five lncRNA annotations were merged with CHESS in a specific order: FANTOM, LNCipedia, NONCODE, MiTranscriptome, and BIGTranscriptome. For each gene entry in CHESS, genes from the other annotations that had full overlap or were enclosed within the boundaries of the CHESS gene were kept. Genes from the other annotations that had partial overlap with CHESS genes were discarded. The resulting intersection of genes was shown in orange. The transcript records from the intersecting genes were compared, and transcripts whose start and end were within the gene boundaries were included. Transcripts that fell outside the gene boundaries or had no overlap with transcripts in CHESS were removed. For genes that had no overlap in CHESS, all the transcripts and corresponding exons were added to the merged annotation as a lncRNA entry.

After the integration of the annotations, conservation analysis was performed using the bigWigAverageOverBed function and the cons30way track downloaded from the UCSC genome browser. The conservation scores were calculated for exons of both protein-coding genes and lncRNAs. Overlapping exons within transcripts were merged to avoid counting conservation scores of overlapping base pairs more than once. The average conservation score was calculated for each exon, and line graphs were used to visualize and compare the average conservation score differences between lncRNAs and protein-coding exons.

The dataset and the code used for the analysis are available through the provided GitHub link.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data in the provided context.
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects:
- UCSC genome browser
- GTEx portal
- PubMed database
- lncRNAKB annotation database
- MySQL open source relational database management system
- NoSQL document storage
- PLINKv1.9
- vcftools v0.1.15
- bcftools v1.9
- Highcharts software
- plotly
- R (for density function and PCA)
- Figshare (for supplementary data)
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

- bigWigAverageOverBed and cons30way (hg38) tracks downloaded from the UCSC genome browser
- PHAST package for evolutionary conservation measurements (phastCons and phyloP)
- multiz and other tools in the UCSC/Penn State Bioinformatics comparative genomics alignment pipeline
- MySQL open source relational database management system (RDBMS) with a NoSQL document storage
- AJAX, jQuery, and PHP for the presentation tier
- Highcharts software and plotly for generating graphs
- PLINKv1.9, vcftools v0.1.15, and bcftools v1.9 for processing VCF files
- UCSC liftOver tool for updating coordinates and changing SNP IDs
- CentOS 7 operating system and Apache web server for hosting the web server
- R for generating density plots and performing PCA analysis
- Figshare for hosting supplementary data
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involves integrating multiple lncRNA annotation databases to create a comprehensive annotation for lncRNAKB. The process starts with a literature search to identify widely used lncRNA annotations and databases. Six lncRNA databases are selected for integration: CHESS, LNCipedia, NONCODE, FANTOM, MiTranscriptome, and BIGTranscriptome. The GFF annotation files from these databases are downloaded and parsed to the same format. The annotations are then merged using a cumulative stepwise intersection method, with CHESS as the reference annotation. The resulting merged annotation includes both protein-coding and lncRNA genes. The final merged annotation in lncRNAKB comprises 99,717 genes, 530,947 transcripts, and 3,513,069 exons. Users can search lncRNAKB using various criteria and access detailed information about the genes, including tissue-specific expression, network and pathway enrichment, exon conservation scores, and coding potential. The annotations are hosted under the GTF/Annot component in OSF.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by an internal team (the authors) and external teams (the six lncRNA annotation databases: CHESS, LNCipedia, NONCODE, FANTOM, MiTranscriptome, and BIGTranscriptome).
annotation_infrastructure:
Yes, the following tools or infrastructures were used during the annotation process:

- CHESS
- LNCipedia
- NONCODE
- FANTOM
- MiTranscriptome
- BIGTranscriptome
- GFF annotation files
- UCSC liftOver tool
- MySQL RDBMS
- NoSQL document storage
- Apache web server
- Highcharts software
- plotly
- GitHub

authoring_funding_grant_id: No grant reference numbers are mentioned in the provided context.
authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. Research questions related to policy efficacy of national-level decisions made during a crisis, such as investigating the effectiveness of travel restrictions in reducing viral spread.
2. Combining the dataset with other country-level datasets to control for other measures introduced at the same time and underlying differences between countries, for experimental design.
3. Facilitating epidemiological analyses by providing the number of COVID cases and deaths for each country over time.
4. Tracking the spread of specific viral strains to a 'host' or 'origin' location.
5. Assisting policymakers in determining the timing of border closures compared to other measures like testing and quarantine requirements.
6. Assisting biomedical scientists with modeling viral transmission patterns for future pandemics.
7. Assisting social scientists and policymakers in assessing the effectiveness of prior travel restrictions.
8. Visualizing other datasets with more granular data on governmental responses at different levels (state, county, city).
9. Comparing policy efficacy with SARS-CoV2 data by combining the dataset with HIT-COVID's category of internal movement restrictions.
10. Providing a reliable and verified source of data on international border closures, compared to other sources like GardaWorld.
11. Filling the gaps and addressing the limitations of other datasets like the ACAPS COVID-19 Government Measures Dataset and the CoronaNet Research Project.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people. The dataset is focused on recording international border policies.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are policies and data related to international border policies, not humans.
uses_data:
The collected data was obtained through a standardized data collection process using a Qualtrics survey. The survey included a decision set and predefined definitions to ensure consistency in data collection. The dataset includes information on policy content, such as exceptions to complete closures and specific populations targeted by partial restrictions. The data verification process prioritizes valid start and end dates of policies. The sources for each interpreted policy text are recorded. 

Before launching the data collection effort, a review of other data sources was conducted. Existing datasets for tracking government responses to COVID-19 were found to have different approaches to data collection, such as a broader or less systematic collection of travel restrictions, bias towards specific travelers, or an incomplete time horizon of public information and scope of modes of movement. The COBAP dataset differs from these existing projects in terms of the scope of countries covered, source prioritization, and precision in recording actual restrictions on entry and restricted population groups.

The raw outputs of the Qualtrics surveys are processed weekly to remove corrected or updated policies. Each policy is assigned a unique ID and attached with a standardized ISO 3/ISO 2 country code for easy country identification. A Python script is used to automate the output of survey responses in a machine-readable data framework. The script also appends new policy end dates from different sources. The verified version of the COBAP dataset is hosted on Harvard Dataverse and is used for data validation and production of other data outputs, including an interactive, time-based visualization on the project website.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through a two-phase process. In the first phase, a team of eighteen trained data collectors used a Qualtrics survey to record all international border policies from January to August 2020. To ensure consistency, each data collector was assigned to record the policies of at least five specific countries, including countries outside of their knowledge base and language expertise. For countries where the data collector did not read the official language(s), a policy expert and/or language consultant was assigned to answer questions about policies that could not be resolved using Google Translate.

Before launching the data collection effort, an extensive review of other data sources was conducted. Existing datasets for tracking government responses to COVID-19 were reviewed, which showed a trend towards a broader approach to data collection of travel restrictions, a less systematic collection of travel restrictions, a bias towards the needs of particular travelers, or an incomplete time horizon of public information and scope of modes of movement. The earliest resource available was the ACAPS COVID-19 Government Measures Dataset, which provided policies in five categories.

The data collection process was designed with a standardized decision set built into a Qualtrics survey. The survey included pre-set definitions to guide the data collectors in prioritizing source quality. The dataset includes important information for designing experiments, such as exceptions to complete closures and specific populations targeted by partial restrictions. Internal data verification prioritized valid start and end dates to examine the correspondence between policy durations and drops in case and mortality data for SARS-CoV-2. The sources for each interpreted policy text were recorded, and the process was visualized in an overview flow chart.

The data collection process began with a country-level search for new policy restrictions related to international border travel or immigration. The policies were then categorized into two overarching categories: "complete closures" and "partial closures." The complete definitions for each sub-category can be found in an online table. The data collection process was documented using the Wayback Machine or Permalink for transparency and the capacity for further data scraping.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data in the provided context.
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects:

- Wayback Machine (https://archive.org/)
- Permalink (https://perma.cc/)
- Qualtrics survey (Qualtrics.com)
- Online-only Table 1
- ACAPS COVID-19 Government Measures Dataset 5
- Google's search engine (Google.com)
- Government sources
- Reputable media sources
- Crowdsourcing
- Country experts
- Professional networks
- Public entities
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the data collection process include:

1. Wayback Machine (https://archive.org/) or Permalink (https://perma.cc/): Used for lasting transparency of the data collection process and preserving capacity for further data scraping.

2. Qualtrics survey (Qualtrics.com): A carefully designed survey used to collect data, with a standardized decision set built into it. The survey prompted research assistants (RAs) to prioritize source quality and rely on pre-set definitions.

3. Google's search engine (Google.com): Used for conducting searches to verify end dates of policies recorded by RAs.

4. Slack channel (slack.com): A central channel used for addressing real-time questions and discussions among the team.

5. Crowdsourcing and country expert outreach: The team reached out to country experts through personalized emails, news publications, and Twitter to verify data for countries that couldn't be verified internally. RAs also utilized their professional networks and reached out to public entities directly for clarifying questions.

6. Government sources and reputable media sources: Used as the primary sources for policy information and verification. Government sources were preferred for end dates, and reputable media sources indicating borders were opened were also considered.

7. Data quality ranking: The data quality for each country was ranked based on the availability and reliability of governmental or proxy sources. Countries with reliable governmental sources were ranked as "very sure," countries with reliable proxy sources were ranked as "sure," and countries without governmental or proxy sources were ranked as "less sure."

Overall, the data collection process involved a combination of online tools, surveys, communication platforms, and external outreach to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the collected data.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process for the data involves several steps. First, the raw outputs of the Qualtrics surveys are processed each week to remove corrected or updated policies. The standardized ISO 3/ISO 2 country code is attached to each policy for easy identification. This results in a complete list of policies with a unique ID per policy.

Next, a Python script is used to combine the sanitized output of the Qualtrics surveys, automate the output of survey responses, and create a more machine-readable data framework. The script also appends new policy end dates from different sources.

The verified version of the dataset is hosted on Harvard Dataverse. This process also assists with the verification of new end dates and web links, as well as the production of other data outputs for the project's interactive visualization.

The data collection process includes a standardized decision set built into a Qualtrics survey, which prompts research assistants (RAs) to prioritize source quality and rely on pre-set definitions. The dataset includes important information such as exceptions to complete closures and specific populations targeted by partial restrictions.

To ensure data quality, a small team covers multiple countries, with each trained RA assigned at least five countries for data collection and verification. Real-time questions are addressed through a central Slack channel, and forced question responses in the Qualtrics surveys contribute to high initial data quality.

Coding decisions are verified by a second RA by checking the source link and ensuring the information is correct. Disputes are discussed and resolved between RAs, with the PI reviewing unresolved issues. The data review process includes end date verification, policy content verification, database updates, and PI review.

In cases where data verification is challenging, the PI reaches out to country experts and utilizes professional networks to resolve issues or omissions in the database. The data quality is ranked per country based on the reliability of the sources used.

Overall, the annotation process involves careful data collection, verification, and review to ensure the accuracy and quality of the COBAP dataset.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by an internal team (e.g the authors) and external team.
annotation_infrastructure:
Yes, the following tools or infrastructures have been used during the annotation process:

- Qualtrics surveys
- Python script
- Harvard Dataverse
- Slack channel
- Google search engine
- Carto library
- JavaScript
- R programming language
- GitHub
annotation_validation_methods: Inter-annotator agreement, Expert Annotations, Test re-test reliability, Proxy-labels
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. To provide a benchmark for improving the spatio-temporal information representation and few-shot learning capability of SNNs without encoding static data in a way that makes information lost.
2. To tackle the problems and fulfill the gap in datasets for SNNs, burdening the development of the SNN algorithm.
3. To evaluate the separability of samples and provide a benchmark for other algorithms to compare, such as the nearest neighbor method.
4. To be used as a dataset for training and testing SNN few-shot learning algorithms, either by using the provided improved SNN algorithms or by developing new algorithms suitable for neuromorphic datasets.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any testing of the dataset using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset represents characters, not people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset consists of handwritten characters from 50 different languages, which suggests that the data was collected from written text rather than human subjects.
uses_data: The collected data is the N-Omniglot dataset, which is a neuromorphic dataset for few-shot learning using spiking neural networks (SNNs). The dataset is based on the Dynamic Vision Sensor (DVS) and contains 1,623 categories of handwritten characters from 50 different languages. Each character has only 20 samples. The data is stored in aedat4 files, which record the entire event of the stroke instead of saving color image frames. The dataset is available for download from Figshare (https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.16821427). The dataset is organized into different directories, maintaining the same structure as the original Omniglot dataset. The dataset also includes a CSV file that contains the beginning and ending timestamps of each sample. The dataset provides a benchmark for improving the spatio-temporal information representation and few-shot learning capability of SNNs without losing information. Preprocessed code is provided to adapt the dataset to current algorithm applications. The dataset can be loaded using three different data interfaces, and four improved SNN learning methods are provided for verification. Researchers can also develop new algorithms to preprocess the dataset and propose novel few-shot learning algorithms suitable for neuromorphic datasets.
collection_explanation: The dataset was collected using a DVS (Dynamic Vision Sensor) acquisition platform. The writing strokes of 20 samples of each character were merged into a video file, with a blank sequence inserted between each sample. The DVS camera captured videos that were played on a monitor, and the Robotic Process Automation (RPA) software was used to automatically collect the data. The corresponding sample data was then split out. The stroke data was preprocessed and reconstructed into a video of writing tracks, using a linear interpolation algorithm to complete the data in milliseconds. The Davis346 device was used for automated capture, with a black box covering the screen and DVS camera to prevent external light changes from interfering with the data collection. The DV software was used to process the captured event data, with background activity time parameter set to 4,000 and exposure parameter fixed to 8000. The RPA software UiBot was used to automate the data collection process. The collected DVS event data was segmented and preprocessed, with a 500 ms gap between each sample. The event data was saved in the form of (x, y, t, p), where x and y are the pixel coordinates of the event, t is the timestamp of the event, and p is the polarity indicating the increase or decrease of brightness. The event data was then processed into image data with a resolution of DVS346 (346*260), with two channels representing the two polarities. The pixels without events were filled with 0. The dataset can be downloaded from Figshare and is organized in the same structure as the original Omniglot dataset.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data in the provided context.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from the N-Omniglot dataset, DV software, aedat4 file, CSV file, NumPy format samples, and four neuromorphic datasets.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

1. DV software: The data is collected using DV software, which stores the data in aedat4 file format.

2. Figshare: The N-Omniglot dataset can be downloaded from Figshare (https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.16821427).

3. CSV file: The beginning and ending timestamps of each sample are saved in a CSV file.

4. NumPy format: The dataset is converted into NumPy format samples and stored in a folder with the same structure as Omniglot.

5. Neural network: The dataset can be directly input into a neural network for processing.

6. SNN learning methods: Four improved SNN (Spiking Neural Network) learning methods are provided for processing the N-Omniglot dataset.

7. ANN network model: An ANN (Artificial Neural Network) network model is also designed for comparison.

8. RPA software: Recording is done using RPA (Robotic Process Automation) software.

9. Equipment environment: The equipment environment is built for recording.

10. Labeling and segmentation: The data is labeled and segmented using time stamps.

11. Neuromorphic datasets: The N-Omniglot dataset is compared with other neuromorphic datasets.

12. Encoding methods: Different encoding methods are used for static images and event data.

13. Baseline methods: Four few-shot learning baseline methods are used for the proposed data descriptors.

14. LSTM: Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) is used as a machine learning algorithm to extract time features.

15. Siamese Net: The Siamese Net compares the spiking convolution feature representation of two samples.

16. MAML: The MAML (Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning) method optimizes the learning process for stronger generalization.

17. Statistical properties: The statistical properties of the N-Omniglot dataset are analyzed.

18. Classification accuracy: The classification accuracy of different methods on the N-Omniglot dataset is evaluated.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process for the N-Omniglot dataset is described in the document. In Phase C of the data generation process (Figure 2), the beginning and end of each character in the video are labeled. This labeling is done using time stamps. The labeled data is then used for segmentation, which involves separating the characters from the video. The segmentation is also done using time stamps. The resulting segmented characters make up the N-Omniglot dataset.
annotation_team_type: The context does not provide information about whether the data was annotated by an internal team, an external team, or a crowdsourcing team.
annotation_infrastructure: Yes, the annotation process for the N-Omniglot dataset involves labeling the beginning and end of each character in the video using time stamps. The labeled data is then used for segmentation, which also involves using time stamps.
annotation_validation_methods: The context does not provide information about the validation methods used to validate the labels.
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide any demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. Surgical training and simulation, specifically for temporal bone surgery, as it provides high-quality models with color information.
2. Use in surgical simulators or any other application that requires high-quality models of the human temporal bone.
3. Overcoming the limitations of low-quality datasets based on Computed Tomography (CT) or micro CT imaging, which lack detail and color information.
4. Providing a valuable addition to existing datasets in the field of surgical simulation, with a higher level of detail and coverage of delicate soft tissue structures.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: Yes, the context mentions that most of the currently available simulation systems are limited by the fact that they are based on low-quality datasets acquired by Computed Tomography (CT), which results in low detail models and lack of information on soft tissue structures such as membranes. Additionally, it mentions that micro CT imaging-based data might be able to overcome the lack of details, but current Micro CT machines only allow scanning of small specimens, making it impossible to model a sufficiently big portion of the anatomy for surgical simulation. Furthermore, it states that for both CT and micro CT-based datasets, there is no color information available, and texturing of models for simulation is performed manually, resulting in quite unnatural coloring. Therefore, the context implies that the data has limitations and is not recommended for certain uses or generalizations.
uses_represents_people: Yes, data represents people as is collected from people
uses_collected_from_people: Yes, the subjects of the collection process are humans. The dataset was created using eight three-dimensional models of the human temporal bone obtained from human temporal bone specimens donated by patients for medical education and research.
uses_biases: Yes, the context provides information about biases issues of the data.
uses_sensitivity: No. The context does not provide any information about the data being offensive to some people.
uses_privacy: No. The context does not provide any information about privacy issues of the data.
uses_data:
The collected data for the OpenEar dataset consists of eight three-dimensional models of the human temporal bone. The dataset was created using a combination of multimodal imaging techniques, including Cone Beam Computed Tomography (CBCT) and micro-slicing. 

The raw data for the dataset was captured by Daniel Sieber, who also developed the methodology for reconstruction and registration. Sieber performed segmentation and 3D modeling of all the datasets. Peter Erfurt supported the creation of the datasets and performed sampling of the specimens, as well as preparation for micro-slicing and acquisition of CBCT images. Samuel John contributed to the development of methods to reconstruct micro-slicing and helped create custom-made software for image alignment. Gabriel Ribeiro Dos Santos supported the segmentation of some datasets. Daniel Schurzig contributed to the compilation of data and manuscript creation. Mads Sølvsten Sørensen, who has experience from the Visible Ear dataset creation, contributed his scientific and technical expertise and performed validation of the datasets and references. Thomas Lenarz provided scientific advice, access to facilities, and performed validation of the datasets.

The OpenEar dataset is a valuable addition to the field of surgical simulation, as it provides a higher level of detail compared to datasets created using clinical CT imaging. It is particularly useful for delicate soft tissue structures such as the tympanic membrane or basilar membrane. The dataset also provides a sufficient model size to cover all aspects of middle and inner ear surgery, similar to temporal bone specimens used in clinical education courses. Like the Visible Ear dataset, the OpenEar dataset includes high fidelity volumetric geometry data with color information, allowing for realistic texturization in surgical simulators. This eliminates the need for manual false color texturing used in simulations based on data from CT/micro CT imaging.

The data was collected from eight fresh human temporal bone specimens obtained from the Institute of Pathology of the Hannover Medical School. The specimens were donated by patients who contributed their corpses to medical education and research. As the specimens were used anonymously, no approval from the institutional ethical board was required.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was created using eight fresh human temporal bone specimens from four adult subjects. These specimens were donated by the Institute of Pathology of the Hannover Medical School, obtained from patients who had donated their corpses for medical education and research. The specimens were used anonymously, so no approval from the institutional ethical board was required.

The creator of the dataset, Daniel Sieber, captured all the raw data for the dataset and developed the methodology for reconstruction and registration. He also performed segmentation and 3D modeling of all the datasets. Peter Erfurt supported the creation of the datasets, performed the sampling of the specimens, and prepared them for micro-slicing. He also acquired CBCT images. Samuel John supported the development of methods to reconstruct micro-slicing and contributed to the custom-made software for image alignment. Gabriel Ribeiro Dos Santos supported the segmentation of some datasets. Daniel Schurzig contributed to the compilation of data and the creation of the manuscript. Mads Sølvsten Sørensen, who had experience from the Visible Ear dataset creation, contributed his scientific and technical expertise and performed validation of the datasets and references. Thomas Lenarz provided scientific advice, access to facilities, and performed validation of the datasets.

The dataset was validated technically. The numerical representation of the human temporal bone in the dataset is limited to reproducing the color and structures found in ex-vivo and postmortem temporal bone specimens. These may differ from the colors and structures found in patients intraoperatively in-vivo. The dataset creation process may also introduce technical inaccuracies. Dehydration of specimens during preparation for embedding may cause shrinkage of certain soft tissue structures. Mechanical forces applied for fixation of the embedded specimens in the grinding machine holder may result in geometric deformations. The stitching of images with the optical microscope may lead to minor inaccuracies. The measurement of remaining overmould height after each grinding step involves a certain measurement error. The 3D reconstruction of the micro-slicing data relies on algorithmic identification of the outline of the embedding and the overmould height measurement, which may introduce inaccuracies. Interpolation of the reconstructed micro-slicing data to create a homogeneously spaced image stack may result in image artifacts. The registration of the micro-slicing and computed tomography images may also have inaccuracies due to the above-mentioned factors. The accuracy of the ACCUITOMO CBCT device used in the experiment is assumed to be below the voxel size of 0.125 mm. The accuracy of the micro-slicing data is more difficult to quantify due to the high number of process steps and influencing factors. A comparison of the geometric and volumetric properties of the micro-slicing data with the CBCT as a reference was performed, and the results are summarized in Table 3. The accuracy of the CBCT and micro-slicing datasets is considered acceptable for the pixel resolution of computer simulations. However, the OpenEar dataset may be limited for applications requiring higher levels of detail and accuracy.

In summary, the dataset was created using donated human temporal bone specimens. The data was captured, reconstructed, registered, and segmented by the authors. The dataset was validated technically, and certain limitations and potential inaccuracies were identified.
collection_team_type: Internal team
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from eight fresh human temporal bone specimens from four adult subjects.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

- AutoMet250 Grinder-Polisher (BUEHLER, Lake Bluff, IL, USA) for grinding the specimens
- Silicon carbide (SIC) grinding paper with a Grit of P 800
- VHX-2000 measurement microscope (KEYENCE Corporation, Osaka, Japan) equipped with a VH-Z20UR zoom lens at 20x magnification mode for microscopic documentation
- Custom-made software using Python scripting and the packages of the Anaconda collection for alignment of the images from micro-slicing
- Graphics processing unit (GPU) for performing the computational operations
- Meshlab software for the Hausdorff distance analysis and volumetric error calculation
- 3D Slicer software for visualization and segmentation of the datasets
- NRRD (.nrrd) file format for storing the data
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process done over the data involves the following steps:

1. Multimodal imaging: The datasets are created using a combination of Cone Beam Computed Tomography (CBCT) and micro-slicing imaging techniques.

2. 3D reconstruction: The micro-slicing images are reconstructed in 3D and then registered to the CBCT images.

3. Segmentation: The registered images are segmented to identify and delineate various anatomical structures such as inner ear compartments, middle ear bones, tympanic membrane, nerve structures, blood vessels, and the temporal bone.

4. Geometric and volumetric analysis: The datasets undergo geometric and volumetric analysis to assess the accuracy and error of the reconstructed models.

5. Annotation and data storage: The annotated datasets are stored in compressed specimen subfolders, with each subfolder containing specific data content. The data includes transformation matrices, accuracy assessment results, screenshots, text files with analysis results, and segmentation files.

Overall, the annotation process involves capturing raw data, reconstructing and registering images, segmenting anatomical structures, analyzing geometric and volumetric errors, and organizing the annotated data for use in surgical simulators or other applications requiring high-quality models of the human temporal bone.
annotation_manual: The annotations have been done manually.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by an internal team, which includes the authors of the document.
annotation_infrastructure:
Yes, the tools or infrastructures used during the annotation process are:

1. Cone Beam Computed Tomography (CBCT)
2. Micro-slicing imaging techniques
3. 3D reconstruction using 3D Slicer
4. Registration using 3D Slicer's built-in BRAINSfit algorithm
5. Segmentation using 3D Slicer
6. Meshlab for visualization and analysis
7. Graphite for geometric and volumetric analysis
8. Meshmixer for postprocessing of image data
9. Data storage in compressed specimen subfolders
10. Transformation matrices for registration
11. Accuracy assessment using Meshlab
12. Text files with analysis results
13. NRRD (.nrrd) file format for segmentation files
14. DICOM series for importing CBCT imaging data
annotation_validation_methods: The context does not provide information about the validation methods used to validate the labels.
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.
