authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses: The dataset is recommended for analyzing temporal information flow in the human brain and for mapping out functional connectivity and making inferences about effective connectivity. It is also recommended for testing and narrowing down causal models using es-fMRI in conjunction with other fMRI datasets. Additionally, the dataset can be used to guide strategies for using deep brain stimulation (DBS) to treat psychiatric and neurological disorders. Preprocessing the raw data should involve using the pre-op session's anatomical images to co-register the post-op session's functional data to reduce noise.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention of the dataset being tested in any machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: Yes, the context mentions that there are limitations and considerations to be aware of when using the data. It mentions limitations regarding interpreting the BOLD signal, preprocessing and analysis considerations, additional noise created by implanted electrodes and electrical stimulation, and strategies for handling this noise.
uses_represents_people: Yes, data represents people as is collected from people
uses_collected_from_people: Yes, the subjects of the collection process are humans.
uses_biases: Yes, the context provides information about biases issues of the data.
uses_sensitivity: Yes, the context suggests that there are some sensitive issues with the data. The data quality of the es-fMRI technique is lower compared to the preop resting-state fMRI, with a loss of signal quality and increased movement. These issues need to be considered when analyzing the es-fMRI dataset.
uses_privacy: No. The context does not provide information about privacy issues of the data.
uses_data: The collected data in this dataset is es-fMRI (electrical stimulation functional magnetic resonance imaging) data. The dataset includes both pre-op and post-op sessions, with anatomical, functional, and electrode information. The data quality of the es-fMRI is assessed using quality control metrics, comparing it to pre-op resting-state fMRI data from the same patients and to a broader fMRI dataset from healthy participants. The es-fMRI data shows a loss of signal quality compared to pre-op resting-state fMRI, with increased movement. Attention to motion confounds is important when analyzing the es-fMRI dataset. It is recommended to use the pre-op session's anatomical images to co-register the post-op session's functional data during preprocessing. There are limitations to interpreting the BOLD signal in this dataset, and caution should be exercised when making inferences. Future analyses may explore novel analytic approaches to infer causal interactions between regions in the BOLD data. Group analyses should treat data obtained on the SKYRA and on the TRIO as equivalent. There is ongoing work on creating masks of "good voxels" per subject, and this dataset may require rigorous censoring of time-points and exclusion of runs with high movement during analysis.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected using es-fMRI (electrical stimulation functional magnetic resonance imaging) in the human brain. The data collection process involved obtaining stimulation contact information for each subject's es-fMRI runs. This information includes the stimulation parameters used (amplitude and duration), the anatomical labels of the electrode contacts (in DTK and Destrieux coordinates), the standard coordinates of the electrode contacts (with respect to two versions of the MNI template), and the hemisphere that was stimulated. The electrode contact-pairs are listed for each es-fMRI run in chA-chB format, with the first contact (chA) receiving the leading positive phase of the stimulation. In some cases, two distant sites were stimulated simultaneously.

The dataset also includes preprocessed data. The BOLD (blood-oxygen-level dependent) time-series, which measures brain activity, were resampled to surfaces on different spaces. The BOLD runs were slice-time corrected using AFNI software. The resampled BOLD time-series were then transformed to correct for head-motion and susceptibility distortions, resulting in preprocessed BOLD in the original space. The BOLD time-series were also resampled into standard space, generating spatially normalized, preprocessed BOLD runs.

It is important to note that the type of data obtained with es-fMRI is fundamentally different from other approaches to fMRI data analysis. Es-fMRI allows for direct intervention on the nodes of a causal model, providing unique insights into causal relationships in the brain. Standard fMRI data can infer causal models based on statistical relationships, but es-fMRI goes further by making predictions about the effects of interventions on the causal graph.
collection_team_type: External team
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: BOLD time-series, fsnative, fsaverage5, AFNI, MNI152NLin2009cAsym, fMRIPrep, Nipype, ANTs, OASIS30ANTs, fast (FSL 5.0.9), CSF, WM, whole-brain masks, CompCor, temporal (tCompCor), anatomical (aCompCor), head-motion estimates, confounds file, Lanczos interpolation, antsApplyTransforms, mri_vol2surf, voxelwise GLM analysis.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the data collection process include:

- AFNI 20160207 34 (RRID:SCR_005927) for slice-time correction
- fMRIPrep 1.5.1rc1 (19,20; RRID:SCR_016216) for preprocessing
- Nipype 1.2.0 (21,22; SCR_002502) for preprocessing
- ANTs 2.2.0 24 (RRID:SCR_004757) for intensity non-uniformity correction and skull-stripping
- OASIS30ANTs as the target template for skull-stripping
- FSL 5.0.9 (RRID:SCR_002823) for brain tissue segmentation
- antsApplyTransforms (ANTs) for gridded (volumetric) resampling
- mri_vol2surf (FreeSurfer) for non-gridded (surface) resampling
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involves considering the limitations and general usage notes of the dataset. These limitations include the brief duration of the stimulation in the protocol, the noise created by implanted electrodes and electrical stimulation, and the fundamental difference in the type of data obtained with es-fMRI compared to other approaches to fMRI analysis. Preprocessing the raw data involves using the preop session's anatomical images to co-register the postop session's functional data to reduce noise. Strategies for handling the noise caused by stimulation include considering only the contralateral hemisphere and creating masks of "good voxels" per subject. The annotation process also takes into account the unique opportunity to map out functional connectivity and make inferences about effective connectivity in the human brain using es-fMRI. It provides direct causal intervention and permits stronger inferences about causal mechanisms. Additionally, es-fMRI provides valuable information about the causal effects of focal DBS and has a whole-brain field-of-view.

authoring_funding: Yes, the dataset was funded by Genome Canada, Genome BC, and the NSF Plant Genome Program.
authoring_funding_grant_id: The mentioned grant reference numbers in the context are LSARP2014-223SUN (funded by Genome Canada and Genome BC) and IOS-1444522 (funded by the NSF Plant Genome Program).
authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset include conducting genome-wide association studies (GWAS) for analyzing phenotypic data, developing new phenotype prediction methods, developing novel machine learning and computer vision methods for automatic phenotyping, and studying the genetic basis of phenotypic diversity and domestication in sunflowers.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any testing of the dataset using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The dataset represents sunflower plants, not people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are plants, specifically sunflowers.
uses_data: The collected data in the HeliantHOME database includes both raw and extracted phenotypic data. This includes a large collection of high-resolution images of different plant organs, architectural and developmental trait measurements, as well as complementary environmental variables such as climate and soil data for the population of origin of the individuals included in the datasets. The database also includes phenotypic data for the UGA-SAM1 (SAM) population, which is a collection of 288 cultivated sunflower lines that capture nearly 90% of the allelic diversity present within cultivated sunflower. The SAM population consists mostly of modern oil or confectionary cultivars, but also includes a few open-pollinated varieties, landraces, and prebred lines. The corresponding re-sequencing data for most of the individuals is also linked and available for public download. The data in the database follows the 'minimum information about plant phenotyping experiments' standards checklist to ensure universality and reproducibility. The data is provided in commonly used formats such as PLINK and CSV files for GWAS analysis, and can also be accessed through the REST API for additional meta-data. Overall, the dataset in HeliantHOME is a comprehensive and extensive collection of population-scale phenotypic data for wild and cultivated sunflowers.
collection_explanation: The dataset was collected through a common garden experiment conducted in Vancouver, Canada. Phenotypic data was collected for 1,510 individuals belonging to 151 populations of wild sunflower species. The experiment also involved re-sequencing the genomes of most of these individuals, resulting in sets of high-quality single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) for each of the four species. The dataset includes both raw and extracted phenotypic data, which encompasses a large collection of high-resolution images of different plant organs, architectural and developmental trait measurements, as well as complementary environmental variables such as climate and soil data for the population of origin of the individuals. Additionally, phenotypic data for a collection of 288 cultivated sunflower lines, known as the UGA-SAM1 (SAM) population, is also included in the dataset. These cultivated sunflower lines capture nearly 90% of the allelic diversity present within cultivated sunflower and are publicly available through the Agricultural Research Service from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA-ARS) and the French National Institute for Agricultural Research & Environment (INRAE). The dataset is stored in the digital library of the Technical University of Munich and can be accessed through the HeliantHOME web interface, which allows for easy access, filtering, and download of the phenotypic and genotypic sunflower data. The dataset follows the 'minimum information about plant phenotyping experiments' standards checklist to ensure universality and reproducibility of the data. It is provided in commonly used data formats such as PLINK and CSV files for GWAS analysis, and it also offers a REST API for accessing additional meta-data.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from:
- High-resolution images of different plant organs
- Architectural and developmental trait measurements
- Complementary environmental variables (climate and soil data)
- Re-sequencing data for most individuals
- Phenotypic data for the UGA-SAM1 (SAM) population
- Agricultural Research Service from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA-ARS)
- French National Institute for Agricultural Research & Environment (INRAE)
- Wild sunflowers dataset
- Inbred lines of the SAM population
- High-quality images for individual plants and plant organs
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:
- High-resolution imaging devices for capturing images of different plant organs
- Devices for measuring architectural and developmental traits
- Climate and soil data collection devices for collecting complementary environmental variables
- Re-sequencing devices for obtaining corresponding re-sequencing data
- The HeliantHOME database, which serves as a web interface for accessing and downloading the phenotypic and genotypic sunflower data
- The Agricultural Research Service from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA-ARS) and the French National Institute for Agricultural Research & Environment (INRAE), which provide access to the phenotypic data for the UGA-SAM1 (SAM) population
- The digital library of the Technical University of Munich, where the phenotypic data and images are deposited and can be downloaded.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involves following the 'minimum information about plant phenotyping experiments' standards checklist (MIAPPE) to ensure the data is universal and reproducible. This includes providing unique identifiers, detailed descriptions of experimental procedures, measurements, units, and other relevant information. The data is provided in commonly used formats such as PLINK and CSV files for GWAS analysis, as well as through a REST API for convenient access to additional meta-data. Both raw and extracted phenotypic data, including high-resolution images of plant organs, architectural and developmental trait measurements, and environmental variables, are incorporated into the database. The data can be explored, searched, filtered, and downloaded through the public web-application called HeliantHOME. The web-application provides various views to summarize information about different species, populations, and phenotypes, and allows users to download data in various formats. The database also includes a REST API for programmatic access to the data. Additionally, the phenotypic data and images are deposited at the digital library of the Technical University of Munich. The database is implemented using the Python Django web-application framework and the backend is based on SQLite. Various third-party Python libraries are used for efficient filtering and data handling. The web-application frontend is based on HTML5 and Bootstrap, and interactive visualizations and plots are integrated using JavaScript libraries. A guided and interactive tour is provided to help users navigate through the web interface.
annotation_team_type: The context does not provide information about whether the data was annotated by an internal team, an external team, or a crowdsourcing team.
annotation_infrastructure:
Yes, the following tools and infrastructures have been used during the annotation process:

- Python Django web-application framework
- SQLite database backend
- Third-party Python libraries (numpy, scipy, pandas)
- Django REST framework
- HTML5 and Bootstrap CSS framework
- jQuery
- JavaScript libraries (Chart.js, jVectorMap)
- intro.js for guided and interactive tour
annotation_validation_methods: Unknown
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide any information about the demographic of the team who annotate the data.

authoring_funding: Yes, this work has been funded by the EcoSSSoil Project, Korea Environmental Industry & Technology Institute (KEITI), Korea (Grant No. 2019002820004).
authoring_funding_grant_id: The grant reference number mentioned in the context is Grant No. 2019002820004.
authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
- To evaluate the prediction capacity of a model for pre-2000 and post-2000 datasets.
- To test the forecasting capacity of a GPR model using pre-2000 data and WorldClim historical data.
- To estimate soil displacement under alternative scenarios at a country-scale using an Excel spreadsheet.
- To perform spatially explicit estimates of rainfall-runoff erosivity using a GPR geostatistical model.
uses_ml_approach: Yes, the dataset has been tested using a machine learning approach. The GPR model was fitted on the pre-2000 data and used to predict values for the post-2000 period. The prediction capacity of the model was evaluated and reported as 0.85 R2 for the pre-2000 training set and 0.6 R2 for the post-2000 validation set.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The dataset does not represent people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset collected in this study is related to soil displacement by water and cropland cover.
uses_data:
The collected data in this study is the GloSEM 1.3 dataset, which contains present and future scenarios of soil displacement by water and cropland cover. The dataset is available through the European Soil Data Centre (ESDAC) and Figshare data repositories. The data is provided in GeoTIFF format, which is a common GIS extension, and is georeferenced using the World Geodetic System (WGS84). The cell size of the data is 0.00099 decimal degrees, which is approximately equivalent to 100 meters near the Equator. 

The dataset consists of five layers. Four of the layers provide estimated rates of soil displacement by water (SOIL_DISPLACEMENT_ESTIMATE_"scenario".tif) in Mg ha-1 yr-1, while the fifth layer provides the fractional cropland cover (ESA100_Cropland_fraction.tif) expressed as a percentage. The scenarios considered in the dataset include the reference year 2019 and future climate scenarios for the year 2070 obtained from 14 General Circulation Models (GCMs) using the RCP2.6, RCP4.5, and RCP8.5 scenarios.

The technical validation of the dataset revealed that the model used in the study had good prediction capacity for the pre-2000 training set and the post-2000 validation set. However, the model tended to be less effective with data that had very high R-factor values, particularly those above 10,000 MJ mm h-1 ha-1 yr-1, leading to underestimation of predicted R-factor values. Additionally, the resolution of the WorldClim data used in the model was coarse, which could result in a mismatch between station-measured data and WorldClim data, especially in areas where topography strongly influences precipitation. Furthermore, the pre-2000 and post-2000 datasets were spatially mismatched, meaning that the stations from the pre-2000 dataset did not necessarily overlap with those of the post-2000 dataset. This introduced more error in the model's predictions, as it lacked full spatial coverage and had to extrapolate to more diverse climatic conditions. Nevertheless, the model showed little bias when predicting the post-2000 R-factor values, which were comparable to those of the training data.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected using a combination of meteorological station data and WorldClim climatic data. The R-factor values, which represent rainfall-runoff erosivity, were calculated using data from 3,625 meteorological stations. The equation used to calculate the R-factor values took into account the rainfall-runoff erosivity of a single event, the number of years observed, and the erosive events during a given year. 

The WorldClim climatic data included various variables such as average monthly precipitation, average minimum and maximum monthly precipitation, average monthly temperature, precipitation in the wettest month, precipitation in the driest month, and precipitation seasonality. These climatic data were used as spatially exhaustive covariates in both the present and future climate scenarios.

For the future scenarios, the R-factor values were estimated using climate projections from 14 general circulation models (GCMs) and considering three different Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) and Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs). The SSPs and RCPs represent different scenarios of future socioeconomic development and greenhouse gas emissions.

It is important to note that the dataset includes data from different time periods. The training set used for model development and validation included data from before the year 2000, while the validation set included data from after the year 2000. The resolution of the WorldClim data is relatively coarse, which may result in a mismatch between station-measured data and WorldClim data, especially in areas where topography strongly influences precipitation. Additionally, the stations from the pre-2000 dataset may not necessarily overlap with those from the post-2000 dataset.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects:
- European Soil Data Centre (ESDAC)
- Figshare data repositories
- WorldClim (GCMs)
- FAOSTAT database
- Monfreda et al. (for spatially explicit harvested areas)
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, or infrastructure used during the collection process include:

- GeoTIFF format: The dataset is provided in GeoTIFF format, which is a common GIS extension used for storing georeferenced data.
- GIS open-source software: The GeoTIFF data can be accessed and analyzed using GIS open-source software.
- World Geodetic System (WGS84): The data is referenced to the World Geodetic System coordinate system.
- European Soil Data Centre (ESDAC): The GloSEM 1.3 dataset is made available through the European Soil Data Centre.
- Figshare data repositories: The dataset is also available through Figshare data repositories.
- Global Climate Models (GCMs): Future climate scenarios used in the dataset were obtained from 14 GCMs.
- WorldClim data: The WorldClim dataset was used to obtain climate data for the future scenarios.
- FAOSTAT database: Crop yield data for the years 2001-2012 were obtained from the FAOSTAT database.
- Remote-sensing data: Remote-sensing data was used to estimate harvested areas for the statistical downscaling of national crop statistics.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involved a technical validation and the use of external validation datasets. The procedure resulted in a good prediction capacity for both the pre-2000 training set and the post-2000 validation set. However, the model tended to be less effective with data that had very high R-factor values, leading to underestimation of predicted R-factor values. Additionally, the resolution of the WorldClim data used in the annotation process was coarse, which could result in a mismatch between station-measured data and WorldClim data, especially in areas with strong topographical influences on precipitation. It is also important to note that the pre-2000 and post-2000 datasets used in the validation process may not have overlapping station locations.
annotation_team_type: The context does not provide specific information about whether the data was annotated by an internal team, an external team, or a crowdsourcing team.
annotation_infrastructure: No, the context does not provide information about the tools or infrastructure used during the annotation process.
annotation_validation_methods: The validation methods used to validate the labels include external validation with different time periods, cross-comparison with continental studies, comparison with empirical data, comparison with river sediment load, comparison with past UN global assessments, comparison with field/plot measurements, uncertainty estimation of climate erosivity, GPR forecasting capacity analysis, and sensitivity analysis of input parameters.
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

uses_data:
The collected data for the Fox Insight study includes patient-reported outcomes (PROs) from routine longitudinal assessments, one-time questionnaires about environmental exposure and healthcare preferences, and genetic data. The dataset is generated through regular cycles of health and medical questionnaires, as well as one-time surveys. The genetic data includes approximately 600,000 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). 

The dataset is quite large, with over 30,000 individuals enrolled in the study. Of these, 72.9% are people with Parkinson's disease, making Fox Insight the largest prospectively followed Parkinson's disease cohort worldwide. The average age of the Parkinson's disease cohort is 66, and they have been diagnosed for over 6 years on average. 

In terms of data completion, 90.5% of people with Parkinson's disease have answered at least one questionnaire, and 47.7% have continued participating in routine longitudinal assessments. People without Parkinson's disease show a similar trend in assessment completion. Optional one-time questionnaires are completed by a lower proportion of the study population, with 34.8% of people with Parkinson's disease and 14.2% of people without Parkinson's disease participating in these surveys. 

In terms of genetic data collection, as of 03-06-2019, a total of 5,880 participants agreed to genetic data collection, and 5,092 participants have been genotyped. 

Overall, the Fox Insight dataset is a rich source of data for Parkinson's disease research, providing valuable information for discovery, validation, and reproducibility in the field.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through various methods, including routine longitudinal assessments, one-time questionnaires, and genetic data. Participants were recruited through digital channels and on-the-ground recruitment efforts. Upon registration, participants were divided into two primary cohorts: those with Parkinson's disease and those without. Participants with Parkinson's disease responded to health, non-motor assessments, motor assessments, quality of life, and lifestyle questionnaires, while participants without Parkinson's disease responded only to health and lifestyle questionnaires. Optional, one-time questionnaires were also offered to participants who met certain eligibility criteria. Participants with Parkinson's disease who completed at least twenty questionnaires in a routine longitudinal assessment were invited to participate in genetic research. 

Routine longitudinal assessments were collected through a custom survey application developed by Mondo Robot. One-time questionnaires were deployed using Qualtrics survey software. Genetic data were collected in collaboration with 23andMe, Inc. 

The participant answers to routine longitudinal assessments, one-time questionnaires, and genetic data were centralized in a public repository managed at the USC Laboratory of Neuro Imaging. Dates associated with participant answers were converted to participant ages to protect patient confidentiality. The total number of days used to complete each survey was also recorded for each participant. Textual answers were quarantined from the general public dataset, and derived variables were defined for certain questions to filter out arbitrary or patient-identifying responses. Derived variables were also added to standardize responses for questions that allowed participants to answer in different ways.

collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_speakers_demographics: Yes, the context provides information about the speech situation, such as the genre (online health study), the modality (online surveys), and the topics (Parkinson's disease, data collection, genetic data).
collection_sources: The data has been collected from routine longitudinal assessments, one-time questionnaires, and genetic data.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

1. Fox Insight website: Participants provide informed consent and register through the website.
2. Digital channels: Recruitment efforts include social network ads, search engine marketing, and email newsletters.
3. On-the-ground recruitment: Research events and clinician referrals are used to recruit participants.
4. Mondo Robot survey application: Custom survey application developed by Mondo Robot is used for routine longitudinal assessments.
5. Qualtrics survey software: One-time questionnaires are deployed through Qualtrics survey software.
6. 23andMe: Collaboration with 23andMe, Inc. for genetic data collection.
7. Fox DEN User Interface: Investigators use the Fox DEN interface to explore, select data, and apply statistical methods.
8. Saliva collection kit: Eligible participants provide a sample using 23andMe's saliva collection kit.
9. Genotyping platforms: Genotyping is done on various platforms, including V3, V4, and V5, which contain different numbers of SNPs.
10. Illumina OmniExpress + BeadChip: The V3 platform is based on this chip and contains about 950,000 SNPs.
11. Custom array: The V4 platform is a fully custom array of about 570,000 SNPs.
12. Illumina Infinium Global Screening Array: The V5 platform is a customized Illumina array of about 690,000 SNPs.
13. Fox Insight's public repository: Phenotypic data and relevant genetic variants are available in tabular form in the public repository.
14. Data access and interpretation: SNP data is available upon request to qualified researchers.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process for the data in Fox Insight involves several steps. First, there is technical validation, which includes reviewing the caveats associated with collecting patient reported outcomes and comparing sex chromosome to self-reported sex for genetic data validation. This ensures the accuracy and reliability of the data.

Next, the data is centralized in a public repository managed at the USC Laboratory of Neuro Imaging. Participant answers to routine longitudinal assessments, one-time questionnaires, and genetic data from key variants are integrated into this repository. Dates associated with participant answers are converted to participant ages to protect patient confidentiality. Unrestricted and free form textual answers are quarantined from the general public data set, and derived variables are defined for certain questions to filter out arbitrary or patient-identifying responses. Derived variables are also added to standardize responses when participants are allowed to answer a question in different ways.

For the genetic data specifically, genotyping is done through 23andMe for eligible participants with Parkinson's disease. The genotyping platforms used include the Illumina OmniExpress + BeadChip, a fully custom array, and the Illumina Infinium Global Screening Array. Several genetic variants relevant to Parkinson's disease research are included in the dataset, along with phenotypic data, in the public repository.

Overall, the annotation process ensures the quality and integrity of the data in Fox Insight, making it accessible for analysis and interpretation by researchers.

uses_data:
The collected data in this study includes soil water content (SWC) and soil water potential (SWP) measurements. The soil sampling was conducted in the 50-ha plot on Barro Colorado Island (BCI), Panama, during the dry seasons of 2015 and 2016. Samples were taken at depths greater than 15 cm within the plot and down to a depth of 40 cm and 100 cm around the plot perimeter. The sampling locations and depths are shown in Figure 1.

Figure 2 shows the SWC measured in the 50-ha plot during the four sampling periods, represented by box and whisker plots. The SWC was also monitored 1.25 km from the plot, and the data is shown as lines. The width of the boxes in the box plots represents the number of days in the sampling period. The colors indicate daily rainfall, and the grey shading indicates dry seasons. The rainfall and SWC monitoring data are from the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute (STRI) Physical Monitoring Program.

Figure 3 presents the SWP in the 50-ha plot on BCI. The SWP is modeled using a Random Forest algorithm at a 5 m resolution and at a depth of 15 cm at 12 PM. The SWP is shown for different dry season conditions and for a regular year and a drought year. The monitored SWC values correspond to the percentiles of monitored SWC during specific months from 1972 to 2018, as well as the median monitored SWC during the soil moisture measurements in March 2016, which was part of an El Niño drought.

Figure 5 assesses the performance of the Random Forest model in predicting SWP. The model performance is evaluated using single decision trees and aggregated decision trees. The predictions of the full model are compared to the observed SWP values. The model performance and predictions are shown for different sampling periods.

Table 1 provides information on the variables used in the Random Forest models, while Table 2 presents the number and percentage of samples taken in each habitat and soil type, as well as the percentage of the plot area covered by each habitat and soil type.

The data records are available from Figshare and include soil moisture sampling data, soil water potential maps for different dry season conditions, the Random Forest model, and the soil type map digitized from a previous study. The data is provided in various formats, such as pdf files, text files, and TIFF images.

The technical validation of the Random Forest model is performed using out-of-bag (OOB) data. The model's goodness of fit is assessed using error metrics, including the proportion of variance explained (R2), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and Mean Absolute Error (MAE). The model's performance is evaluated for different sampling periods, and the accuracy of the predictions is discussed.

Overall, the collected data includes soil moisture measurements, SWP modeling, and the evaluation of the Random Forest model's performance. The data is freely available for further analysis and visualization.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through soil sampling at various locations within the 50-ha plot on Barro Colorado Island (BCI), Panama. In April 2015 and 2016, samples were taken down to a depth of 40 cm at 100 sites along north-south transects in the plot. Additionally, samples were taken at 41 sites with steep slopes or rare habitats such as treefall gaps, the swamp, and streamsides. At 22 sites around the plot perimeter, samples were taken down to a depth of 100 cm in the three sampling periods in 2015. In total, 1299 samples were collected, covering all soil types and habitats in the plot.

The soil samples were collected using soil augers with diameters ranging from 1-3 cm, depending on the sampling depth. The auger was inserted into the soil until the desired depth was reached. The lowest 1 cm of the soil core was sealed in airtight plastic vials for soil water potential measurements, while the 9 cm above it was placed in zip lock bags for soil water content measurements.

The dataset also includes information on the sampling locations and depths. Figure 1 shows the sampling locations and depth of soil sampling in the plot during the dry seasons of 2015 and 2016. Samples taken at depths greater than 15 cm within the plot and around the plot perimeter were taken down to a depth of 40 cm and 100 cm, respectively. Figure 2 displays the soil water content measured in the plot during the four sampling periods, along with monitored data from a location 1.25 km away from the plot. Figure 3 shows the soil water potential in the plot at different depths and dry season conditions. Figure 5 compares the observed soil water potential with the predicted values from a Random Forest model.

The dataset also provides information on the variables used in the Random Forest models and the number and percentage of samples taken in each habitat and soil type. Additionally, the dataset includes information on the temporal variation of soil water potential caused by differences in drought intensity, using monitored soil water content data.

Overall, the dataset provides comprehensive information on the collection process, including sampling locations, depths, and methods used to collect and measure soil samples.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects:
- 100 sites along north-south transects in the plot
- 41 sites with steep slopes or rare habitats such as treefall gaps, the swamp, and streamsides
- 22 sites around the plot perimeter
- 8 seed traps
- Soil samples
- Rainfall and soil water content monitoring data from the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute (STRI) Physical Monitoring Program
- Tree census data
- Topographic and edaphic information
- Surveys of light availability and soil chemistry
- Long-term censuses of flowers, seeds, seedlings, and trees
- Remote sensing datasets such as airborne imaging spectroscopy and light detection and ranging (LiDAR) data
- SWC monitoring data collected at 10 locations in a catchment 1.25 km from the plot
collection_infrastructure: The tools and devices used during the collection process include 1-3 cm diameter soil augers for collecting soil samples, airtight plastic vials for soil water potential measurements, and zip lock bags for soil water content measurements. Additionally, there were maps and data records in various formats such as .txt, .pdf, and .tif.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involved using a Random Forest model to predict soil water potential (SWP) based on various variables such as soil monitoring data, topographic and edaphic information, and data from a tree census. The model was validated using out-of-bag (OOB) data, which is similar to setting aside a test set. For each bootstrapped iteration, the model used a tree created based on the bootstrapped sample to predict SWP for the OOB data. The mean predicted SWP across iterations was used to calculate error metrics such as the proportion of variance explained by the model (R2), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and Mean Absolute Error (MAE). The model performance was assessed for different sampling periods, and predictions were compared to observed SWP values. The importance of predictors and their relationship with SWP was also analyzed.

authoring_funding: Yes, the dataset was funded by the European Commission 'Seventh Framework Program' through the enviroGRIDS, PEGASO, IASON, and EOPOWER projects.
authoring_funding_grant_id:
The grant reference numbers mentioned in the context are as follows:

- enviroGRIDS: no. 227640
- PEGASO: no. 244170
- IASON: no. 603534
- EOPOWER: no. 603500
authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset are for national to regional assessments, comparing countries, prioritizing environmental protection projects and investments, assisting decision makers for environmental policies planning, environmental resource management, support assessment processes of regional to local environmental agencies, and contributing to web-based environmental platforms.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: Yes, the context mentions that the datasets should not be used for local planning and local decision-making. They are intended for national to regional assessments and for comparing countries or helping funding agencies prioritize environmental protection projects and investments.
uses_represents_people: No. The dataset does not represent people. The dataset represents population per region and includes urban and total population trends over a specific period of time.
uses_collected_from_people: No, the subjects of the collection process are not humans. The data collected in this dataset includes climate data such as temperature and precipitation, and population data for different regions.
uses_data:
The collected data in this dataset includes estimated values for monthly averages of maximum and minimum temperatures, as well as precipitation. These estimates cover the time period between 1961 and 1990. The interpolation method used to estimate these values is the integrated nested Laplace approximations.

In addition to the historical data, the dataset also provides estimated values for the monthly averages for two future scenarios: HB1 and HS1. These estimates cover the time period between 2071 and 2100. The estimation for these future scenarios was done using the Delta method.

Furthermore, the dataset includes estimated values for the time period between 2025 and 2071 for both the HB1 and HS1 scenarios. These estimates were obtained using a linear regression model.

It is important to note that the resolution of the datasets used in the analysis is not suitable for local planning or decision-making. These datasets are intended for national to regional assessments and can be used for comparing countries or prioritizing environmental protection projects and investments.

The data is freely available and accessible in various formats, including a dedicated geoportal, web services endpoints, and a static copy in the Dryad Repository. The geoportal allows users to visualize and download datasets related to land use scenarios, climate scenarios, demographic scenarios, hydrology, water for agriculture vulnerability, water scarcity, and beach retreat. The data is available in vector formats such as ESRI Shapefile, GML, and KML, as well as raster formats like Geotiff, ArcGrid, Gtopo30, and ImageMosaic. Metadata is available in various formats including ATOM, DIF, Dublin Core, EBRIM, FGDC, and ISO19115.

The method used to derive downscaled climate projections is the Delta method, which perturbs observed time series with changes that increase over time. Decile changes were applied to perturb monthly rainfall and temperature probability distribution functions. The validation of the Delta method was done using the HIRHAM dataset. The differences between the daily averages of the future scenarios and the present-day period were divided into deciles and grouped into monthly deciles. This calculation was repeated for each climate scenario and for the monthly precipitation and maximum and minimum temperature values. The same methodology was applied to the gridded surfaces to obtain the climate change scenarios for the BSC for the time period between 2071 and 2100.
collection_explanation: The dataset was collected from 18 different sources, with Eurostat and National statistical offices being the main sources. The data on population per region was collected for all available years. The data collected was heterogeneous and occasionally incomplete. To address this, a three-step process of harmonization was applied. First, the data was formatted and translated from the National statistical offices. Then, the statistical and geometric data (boundaries) were matched together. Finally, linear interpolation was used to fill in any gaps for missing years. This process allowed for the completion of population data for the two base years (2001 and 2008) used in the landuse change analysis. Missing values in the time series were extrapolated linearly to cover the period 2000-2010.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: Eurostat, National statistical offices, HIRHAM, PRUDENCE, BSC, Global Runoff Data Centre, National Institute of Hydrology and Water Management (INHGA), Danube Delta National Institute for Research and Development (DDNI), Turkish Ministry of Forest and Water Affairs (MEF), International Commission for the Protection of the Danube River (ICPDR), McGill University, Global Historical Climatology Network (GHCN), European Climate Assessment & Dataset (ECA & D), R-INLA, Regional Climate Models (RCMs), Danish Meteorological Institute (DMI)
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

- Eurostat and National statistical offices as the main sources of data
- Formatting and translating data from National statistical offices
- Matching statistical and geometric data together
- Interpolating linearly to fill in gaps for missing years
- Delta method for downscaling climate projections
- Network of 50 Linux computers for calibration runs
- Global Runoff Data Centre, National Institute of Hydrology and Water Management, Danube Delta National Institute for Research and Development, Turkish Ministry of Forest and Water Affairs for obtaining river discharge data
- International Commission for the Protection of the Danube River for obtaining nitrate concentration data
- McGill University for obtaining crop yield data
- Global Historical Climatology Network and European Climate Assessment & Dataset for obtaining meteorological station data
- R-INLA for interpolation and downscaling of Regional Climate Models outputs from the PRUDENCE program.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process for the data involved several steps. First, the data was made freely available and accessible in various formats on the public domain, including a dedicated geoportal for data discovery, visualization, and downloads. The data was also made available in different vector and raster formats, such as ESRI Shapefile, GML, KML, Geotiff, ArcGrid, Gtopo30, and ImageMosaic.

Metadata for the data was provided in formats such as ATOM, DIF, Dublin Core, EBRIM, FGDC, and ISO19115. Additionally, several OGC-compliant web service endpoints were available to access graphical/cartographic representations of the data.

The annotation process also involved cautioning users about the resolution of the datasets. The datasets were analyzed using global/regional datasets, which may not be relevant for local planning or decision-making. However, they were intended for national to regional assessments and could be used for comparing countries or prioritizing environmental protection projects and investments.

Some of the datasets were based on models and depicted plausible scenarios. However, these scenarios were limited in spatial, temporal, and thematic resolution due to computing capacities at the time.

Overall, the annotation process ensured that the data was easily accessible, available in various formats, and accompanied by relevant metadata.

uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
- To allow better integration times in Lagrangian moisture transport analyses used to identify moisture sources and sinks.
- To compare precipitation obtained from reanalyses with precipitation calculated by Lagrangian methods.
- To approximate the precipitation of terrestrial origin in other studies.
- To compare results with other methodologies and studies.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The context does not mention anything about the data representing people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset collected in this study includes datasets of optimal integration times and precipitation data from reanalysis databases.
uses_data:
The collected data in this study includes datasets of optimal integration times using ERA-I as a reference reanalysis on an annual and monthly basis. These datasets are freely available in the Zenodo repository under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. The accompanying 'Readme.pdf' file provides information on the format of the data and its contents.

The purpose of this database is to allow for better integration times in Lagrangian moisture transport analyses, which are used to identify moisture sources and sinks. The generic 10-day integration time typically used in these analyses is improved upon in this database. The method used in this study, based on Stohl and James, is the most widely used approach for determining sources and sinks in the last semi-decade.

The database also allows for a distinction to be made between precipitation originating from global terrestrial and oceanic sources, with a resolution of 0.25°. The data includes continental precipitation from ERA-I, GPCP, and MSWEP reanalysis data, as well as precipitation calculated using the Lagrangian method for different integration times.

Figures 2, 3, 4, and 6 in the document provide visual representations of the data. Figure 2 shows continental precipitation from reanalysis data and the Lagrangian approach using different integration times. Figure 3 shows gridded annual optimum integration times and precipitation calculated from the Lagrangian outputs. Figure 4 shows gridded monthly optimum integration times. Figure 6 provides technical validation for derived precipitation data, including the difference between annual climatology and the optimum integration time, root mean square error, mean absolute error, and monthly spatial correlations.

In addition to ERA-I, monthly precipitation data from GPCP and MSWEP databases were also used for comparison. GPCP is a well-known initiative of the Global Energy and Water Cycle Exchanges (GEWEX) activity and has been used in numerous papers. The GPCP version used in this study has a spatial resolution of one degree and a daily temporal resolution, derived from the integration of satellite data sets and rain gauge data.

Overall, the collected data in this study provides information on optimal integration times for Lagrangian moisture transport analyses and includes precipitation data from ERA-I, GPCP, and MSWEP databases.
collection_explanation: The dataset was collected using a Lagrangian approach to estimate monthly precipitation. In addition to monthly precipitation data from the ERA-I reanalysis, data from two other databases, GPCP and MSWEP, were also used for comparison. The GPCP database is a well-known initiative of the Global Energy and Water Cycle Exchanges (GEWEX) activity and has been used in numerous papers. The GPCP version used in this study has a spatial resolution of one degree of latitude-longitude and a daily temporal resolution. It is derived from the integration of various satellite data sets over land and ocean, as well as analysis of rain gauge data over land. The dataset is freely available at the provided link from the Zenodo repository and is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. The accompanying 'Readme.pdf' file contains information about the data format and contents. The estimation of optimal integration times using GPCP and MSWEP base data was only done for comparison purposes and is not included in the data records.
collection_team_type: External team
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: ERA-I, GPCP, MSWEP
collection_infrastructure: The tools, devices, or infrastructure used during the collection process include ERA-I reanalysis, GPCP base data, and MSWEP base data.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involves calculating precipitation using the Lagrangian method with different integration times. The integration times used range from 3 to 15 days. The data is compared with reanalysis data from ERA-I, GPCP, and MSWEP. The optimal integration times for each dataset are determined and used to calculate continental precipitation. The results are validated through technical validation measures such as the difference between annual climatology, root mean square error (RMSE), mean absolute error (MAE), and monthly spatial correlations. The datasets, including the optimal integration times, are freely available for download. The estimation of optimal integration times using GPCP and MSWEP data is done for comparison purposes but not included in the data records.

uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset are to understand the accuracy of the refined pixels, to compare the acreage data for specific crops with NASS estimates, and to improve the acreage estimation for croplands in the United States.

uses_data:
The collected data consists of the Refined Cropland Data Layer (R-CDL), which is available on the In-season CROP Mapping Explorer System (iCrop) developed by the Center for Spatial Information Science and Systems at George Mason University. The R-CDL data can be accessed and downloaded through the iCrop web-services at no cost. Additionally, the annual R-CDL data is available for download from the Zenodo repository.

The R-CDL data is stored in .tif format, with supportive information about the data stored in other files within the folder. For example, georeferencing information is stored in the .tfw file. The annual R-CDL layers are compressed and stored in .zip format to reduce file size.

The collected data was validated through a pixel-level cross-class assessment. Changing pixels were identified by comparing the CDL and R-CDL classifications. Five hundred validation samples were randomly selected based on their geographic locations. The validation samples provided a balanced representation of various crop classes, with non-cropland classes grouped into one category to simplify the analysis. In total, 149 sample pixels were non-cropland to non-cropland, and 351 pixels contained at least one cropland classification.

The collected data was also compared to the "ground truth" provided by the National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) estimates. The coefficient of determination (R2) was calculated for both R-CDL and CDL with NASS estimates to assess their correlation. The results were compared to determine if R-CDL had the same correlation to the "ground truth" as CDL. Additionally, the R2 values were checked for major crops (corn and soybean) to identify any unbalanced post-classification for different crop classes.

Furthermore, the acreage differences were calculated for both CDL and R-CDL with NASS estimates. The planting area percentage variation for corn and soybean of R-CDL and CDL to NASS data was evaluated to assess the accuracy of the data in terms of crop acreages.

Overall, the collected data includes the R-CDL dataset, which was validated through pixel-level assessments and compared to NASS estimates for correlation and accuracy. The data is available for download through the iCrop system and the Zenodo repository.
collection_explanation:
The collection process of the dataset involved several steps. First, the Refined Cropland Data Layer (R-CDL) was made available on the In-season CROP Mapping Explorer System (iCrop), which is operated by the Center for Spatial Information Science and Systems at George Mason University. The iCrop system allows users to view, operate, and download the R-CDL data through web services at no cost. Additionally, the annual R-CDL data is available for download from the Zenodo repository.

The R-CDL data is stored in .tif format, with supportive information about the data stored in other files within the folder. For example, georeferencing information is stored in the .tfw file. To reduce the file size, the folders of annual R-CDL layers are compressed and stored in .zip format. The data can be viewed using various GIS software such as ESRI ArcGIS Pro and QGIS.

To validate the accuracy of the R-CDL post-classifications, a pixel-level cross-class assessment was conducted. Changing pixels were identified by comparing the Cropland Data Layer (CDL) and R-CDL. From these changing pixels, 500 validation samples were randomly selected based on their geographic locations. The validation samples provided a balanced representation of various crop classes. It is important to note that non-cropland classes were grouped into one category to simplify the analysis.

The technical validation results showed that the refining algorithm used in this research improved the accuracy of the R-CDL compared to the CDL. However, it is important to acknowledge that not all pixels and classification categories were validated. Therefore, the authors recommend users to read the limitations section and consider validating the data before using it for their studies.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects:

- Reference satellite observations
- CDL (Cropland Data Layer)
- R-CDL (Refined Cropland Data Layer)
- U.S. Census TIGER reference data
- NASS (National Agricultural Statistics Service)
- In-season CROP Mapping Explorer System (iCrop)
- Zenodo repository
collection_infrastructure: The tools and devices used during the collection process include ESRI ArcGIS Pro software, U.S. Census TIGER reference data, and satellite observations. The infrastructure used includes the In-season CROP Mapping Explorer System (iCrop) developed by the Center for Spatial Information Science and Systems at George Mason University.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process for the data involved a technical validation process. The researchers compared the Cropland Data Layer (CDL) with the refined algorithm results (R-CDL) to assess the accuracy. They identified changing pixels and randomly selected 500 validation samples based on geographic locations. They used reference satellite observations to validate the R-CDL classifications at the pixel level. The validation samples provided a balanced representation of various crop classes. The researchers also compared the county-level planting area estimates from the National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) with the R-CDL results. They concluded that the algorithm effectively removed misclassifications in the CDL while causing minimal damage to correct classifications. However, they noted that the validation sample size was not broad enough and that the NASS acreage estimates were not ground truth data. They acknowledged limitations in the decision tree algorithm and R-CDL, including reliance on other satellite images and NASS acreage estimates, which could introduce uncertainties in the product.

3. Reference satellite observations
4. National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS)
5. In-season CROP Mapping Explorer System (iCrop)
6. ESRI ArcGIS Pro

uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset are optimizing the assembly strategy for de novo transcriptome projects, searching for single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in transcriptionally active genome regions, boosting functional annotation of specific genes, and downstream bioinformatics applications such as experimental validation of transcript expression, reconstruction of single gene phylogenies, quantitative RNA-seq analyses, comparative genomics/transcriptomics, and phylogenomic surveys.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: Yes, the context mentions that the assembly pipeline used may not produce good results for other RNA-seq datasets.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset includes transcriptome assembly results, RNA-seq sample similarity analysis, and other analysis related to transcriptome data. There is no mention of human subjects in the context.
uses_data: The collected data in this study includes transcriptome assembly results, RNA-seq sample similarity analysis, description of samples used for RNA-seq data acquisition, assembly statistics generated by various pipelines, OrthoMCL statistics, and functional annotation results. The transcriptome assembly results include Nx curves computed for RNA-seq assemblies, which show the best strategy to generate high-quality de novo transcriptome assembly. The N50 graph by expression percentiles is also shown for the best assembly generated by the "merge reads → assemble with Trinity" strategy. The RNA-seq sample similarity analysis includes clustering and principal component analysis, which show that samples are grouping by biological replicates and experimental design. There is a sharp difference between NExp and DSLT groups, while the samples split into two subgroups inside DSLT depending on whether a culture was exposed to light. The description of samples used for RNA-seq data acquisition is provided in Table 1. The assembly statistics generated by various pipelines are summarized in Table 2, including information on the strategies used to generate the assembly and the number of transcripts. OrthoMCL statistics are presented in Table 3, showing the number of proteins having the best BLAST hits with F. radians transcriptome ORFs. The functional annotation results are summarized in Table 4, including the best blastx and blastp hits. The data records section provides additional information on the analysis of all-against-all sample distances and the identification of differentially expressed transcripts between NExp and DSLT conditions. The methods section explains the metrics used to evaluate the assembly variants, including DRAP report metrics, Nx metrics, BUSCO analysis, and Transrate scores.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected by obtaining 69.5 million 125 bp paired-end Illumina reads from seven cDNA libraries. These libraries were generated from non-normalized polyA-enriched RNA. The raw sequencing reads are available at NCBI Sequence Read Archive (SRA) under accession SRP156385. 

The best strategy for assembling the RNA-seq data was the DRAP/Trinity workflow applied to merged, cleaned, and normalized raw sequencing reads. This strategy, referred to as "MA-Trinity", resulted in the longest and most contiguous transcriptome assembly. It also had the highest Transrate score and contained the greatest number of complete eukaryotic BUSCO genes. Only 29 core eukaryotic genes were missing from this assembly according to the BUSCO analysis.

The transcriptome assemblies, as well as the accessory data associated with the assembly used for annotation and further analysis, were uploaded to figshare as a file set. The draft genome sequence of F. radians is available at the European Nucleotide Archive (ENA) under accession CAAAJI010000000, and the Transcriptome Shotgun Assembly project has been deposited at DDBJ/EMBL/GenBank under accession GGVJ00000000. The version described in the paper is the first version, GGVJ01000000.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from RNA-seq samples and cDNA libraries.
collection_infrastructure: The tools and devices used during the collection process include BBMap v.37.01 package for filtering and normalizing raw sequencing reads, Trinity v.2.5.1 and Velvet v.1.2.10/Oases v.0.2.09 as DBG-assemblers, and DRAP v.1.91 pipeline for transcriptome assembly and evaluation. The data was obtained from seven cDNA libraries and the raw sequencing reads are available at NCBI Sequence Read Archive (SRA) under accession SRP156385.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process done over the data involved several steps. 

First, hits with a KEGG orthogroup assigned and belonging to protists were used to confirm gene descriptions of F. radians transcripts. This was done to validate the gene descriptions obtained from the transcripts.

Next, the presence of annotations was checked for transcripts with significant blastp-hits against NCBI NR. Hits with a KEGG orthogroup assigned and belonging to protists were used to further confirm gene descriptions of F. radians transcripts.

For the rest of the Trinotate transcripts with a KEGG orthologous group, annotations were left unaltered, and a specific tag was assigned to show that the transcript has no similar sequences within the protists.

To validate the F. radians transcriptome annotations, they were compared with annotations of the closest orthologous genes belonging to diatoms and other protists. F. radians transcripts encoding ORFs were subjected to blastp analysis against proteins of T. pseudonana, P. tricornutum, and F. cylindrus. Transcripts with significant hits were annotated using the annotations from diatom genes.

Mercator analyses were performed using all available reference databases except for InterProScan. TRAPID analysis used PLAZA 2.5 as a reference database. Annotations generated by TRAPID and Mercator were compared with Trinotate results, and new GO terms were aggregated with the existing ones.

Overall, the annotation process involved confirming gene descriptions using hits with KEGG orthogroups, comparing annotations with orthologous genes from diatoms and other protists, and using different annotation tools like Trinotate, TRAPID, and Mercator.
annotation_manual: The annotations have been done manually.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by an internal team (e.g the authors) using annotation tools like Trinotate, TRAPID, and Mercator.
annotation_infrastructure: Yes, the annotation process involved the use of Trinotate, TRAPID, and Mercator.
annotation_validation_methods: Types: Inter-annotator agreement, Expert Annotations, Proxy-labels
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset are to visualize potential hot-spot areas and evaluate drinking water systems that may be susceptible to PFAS contamination, as well as to promote the reuse of this dataset and others like it.

uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset represents potential hot-spot areas and drinking water systems that may be susceptible to PFAS contamination, not people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset consists of information extracted from publicly available sources and includes maps related to potential hot-spot areas and drinking water systems. The data was collected from the Toxic Release Inventory, KDEP-supplied data for hazardous sites, airport location data, and the Kentucky Geoportal. The drinking water sampling results were collected by trained staff from KDEP.
uses_data: The collected data in this study consists of a dataset from Kentucky that allows decision-makers to visualize potential hot-spot areas and evaluate drinking water systems that may be susceptible to PFAS contamination. The dataset includes information extracted from publicly available sources and is used to create five different maps in ArcGIS Online. These maps include a hot-spot map, drinking water map, sewer map, SWAPP (Source Water Assessment and Protection Program) map, and a comprehensive map that links to the individual maps. The data and associated metadata for these maps are stored within a downloadable zip archive, which is part of a Figshare item that includes a descriptive draft MIAGIS-compliant JSON metadata file. The hot-spot map was created using data from the Toxic Release Inventory (TRI), KDEP-supplied data for hazardous sites, and airport location data. The data for the drinking water map, sewer map, and SWAPP map were extracted from the Kentucky Geoportal, which provides information about all the water systems in Kentucky. The layer data and metadata for the maps are available in Figshare.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected using a combination of data sources and tools. The author, S.O., gathered the data sources and created the ArcGIS maps. K.G.P. developed the study design, obtained access to data sources, and provided support for the study. S.O. initially gathered the data files with the help of CDP, and then P.T.T. converted them into a draft MIAGIS-compliant deposition. 

The data and associated metadata are stored in JSON format within a downloadable zip archive. The methodology for creating the ArcGIS maps and deposition should be downloaded and carefully read. The dataset can be accessed and downloaded from the Figshare item, which has a DOI. 

Five different maps were created in ArcGIS Online: Hot-spot map (Map-1), drinking water map (Map-2), Sewer map (Map-3), SWAPP (Source Water Assessment and Protection Program) map (Map-4), and a comprehensive map (Map-5) that provides directions to the individual linked maps. The data for Map-1 was obtained from three different publicly available sources: Toxic Release Inventory (TRI) from DOD and industries, KDEP-supplied data for hazardous sites, and ourairports.com for airport locations and coordinates. The data for Map-2, Map-3, and Map-4 were extracted from the Kentucky Geoportal, which provides information about all the water systems of Kentucky.

The metadata description of the maps adheres to a proposed draft Minimum Information About Geospatial Information System (MIAGIS) standard. The dataset is saved in a FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) way, enabling its use by other PFAS stakeholders.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from publicly available sources.
collection_infrastructure: The tools and infrastructure used during the collection process include ArcGIS Online, Figshare, and the proposed draft Minimum Information About Geospatial Information System (MIAGIS) standard.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involves creating metadata descriptions of the maps in javascript object notation (JSON) format. These metadata descriptions adhere to a proposed draft Minimum Information About Geospatial Information System (MIAGIS) standard that has been developed. The metadata, along with the data, are stored in JSON format within a downloadable zip archive. The ArcGIS map creation and deposition methodology should be downloaded and carefully read, and all steps should be applied in the correct order. The goal is to ensure data permanence and make the data findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable (FAIR) according to the guiding principles for managing publicly available datasets.
annotation_team_type: The context does not provide information about whether the data was annotated by an internal team, an external team, or a crowdsourcing team.
annotation_infrastructure: Yes, the ArcGIS tool and infrastructure have been used during the annotation process.
annotation_validation_methods: The context does not provide information about the validation methods used to validate the labels.
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. Testing novel methods within passive BCI research or related fields.
2. Estimating mental workload.
3. Developing and testing classification pipelines.
uses_ml_approach: Yes, the dataset has been tested using a machine learning approach. The MDM Riemannian classifier was used to classify epochs of EEG data between three levels of mental workload. The obtained average accuracy of over 65% confirms that the dataset may be useful for developing and testing classification pipelines.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: Yes, data represents people as is collected from people
uses_collected_from_people: Yes, the subjects of the collection process are humans. This is indicated in the context where it mentions that subjective, behavioral, and physiological data were collected from participants.
uses_biases: No. The context does not provide information about biases issues of the data.
uses_sensitivity: No. The context does not provide any information about the data being offensive or sensitive to some people.
uses_privacy: No. The context does not provide any information about privacy issues of the data.
uses_data: The collected data in the COG-BCI database 18 includes subjective, behavioral, and physiological data from participants. The data was acquired using an experimental protocol that involved administering subjective questionnaires, conducting tasks, and using acquisition devices. The subjective questionnaires were coded and administered using MATLAB v.2021a, and presented on a computer screen. The questionnaires assessed demographics, handedness, and sleepiness. The database also includes EEG data, which was processed using a pre-processing pipeline. The data was down-sampled to 250 Hz and a 1 Hz high-pass FIR filter was applied. The dataset does not include any code for generating the data, but code for the subjective questionnaires is available on GitHub. The data was validated using MATLAB and JASP software, and statistical analyses were performed using GLM contrast analyses and t-tests. Overall, the dataset is a useful asset for testing novel methods in passive BCI research or related fields.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected by acquiring subjective, behavioral, and physiological data from participants using an experimental protocol. The subjective questionnaires were administered using MATLAB v.2021a and presented on a computer screen. The demographics questionnaire included questions about age, gender, level of education, and occupation. The shortened version of the Edinburgh Handedness Inventory was used to assess handedness. The Karolinska Sleepiness Scale was also administered to participants. 

During the data acquisition process, subjective, behavioral, and physiological data were recorded throughout each session for each participant. Data synchronization and stimuli recording were performed using the LabRecorder of the LabStreaming Layer software. Stimulus presentation and response acquisition for the tasks were coded in MATLAB v.2021a with the PsychToolBox-3.

The dataset does not include any code for generating the data. Researchers can work on their own pipelines with custom preprocessing steps using the raw data provided. The technical validation of the dataset was performed using Matlab and JASP software. The code for the subjective questionnaires is available on GitHub.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from the COG-BCI database, which includes recordings of 29 participants over 3 separate sessions with 4 different tasks (MATB, N-Back, PVT, Flanker) designed to elicit different mental states. The data includes open EEG data and was validated on a subjective, behavioral, and physiological level.
collection_infrastructure: The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include computer interfaces, passive Brain-Computer interfaces (pBCI), EEG data recording, MATLAB software with EEGlab toolbox, JASP software, KSS and RSME subjective scales for mental workload and vigilance assessment, ECG for cardiac activity measurement, and BIDS structure for data organization.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involved using an MDM Riemannian classifier to classify epochs of EEG data between three levels of mental workload. This classification was performed on both the MATB and the N-Back task. The obtained average accuracy of over 65% in this 3-class problem confirms that the COG-BCI database 18 may be useful for developing and testing classification pipelines. Additionally, on a cerebral level, it was observed that errors result in stronger deflections of the ERN, FRN, and P300 components. The collected data was also tested for its ability to be used for mental workload estimation.
annotation_team_type: The context does not provide information about whether the data was annotated by an internal team, an external team, or a crowdsourcing team.
annotation_infrastructure: No, the context does not provide information about the specific tools or infrastructures used during the annotation process.
annotation_validation_methods: Ground Truth Labels, Expert Annotations, Test re-test reliability, Proxy-labels
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide any demographic information about the team who annotate the data.
