authoring_funding: Yes, this work has been supported by the NIH grant R01 DC016807 from the NIDCD, the National Natural Science Foundation of China grants (#81600798 and #81770996), and the Béllucci Depaoli Family Foundation.
authoring_funding_grant_id:
The mentioned grant reference numbers in the context are:

- NIH grant R01 DC016807 from the NIDCD
- National Natural Science Foundation of China grants #81600798 and #81770996
- Béllucci Depaoli Family Foundation
authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. To examine the reproducibility of biological and technical replicates of IHCs and OHCs using correlation coefficient analysis and principal component analysis (PCA).
2. To assess the sequencing accuracy of RNA-sequencing data using FastQC analysis.
3. To perform RNA-sequencing and bioinformatic analyses to generate genome-wide transcriptome libraries and assess gene expression profiles.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people. The dataset is focused on gene expression profiles of different cell populations, specifically inner hair cells (IHCs) and outer hair cells (OHCs) in the cochlea of mice.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset includes RNA-sequencing data from inner hair cells (IHCs) and outer hair cells (OHCs) in mice.
uses_data:
The collected data in this study includes RNA-sequencing data from biological replicates of inner hair cells (IHCs) and outer hair cells (OHCs). The data was generated using the SMART-Seq V4 Ultra Low Input RNA kit in combination with the Nextera Library preparation kit. The libraries were sequenced using the HiSeq 2500 Sequencing System, generating approximately 100 million reads per sample. The raw fastq sequencing files have been deposited in the NCBI Sequence Read Archive.

In addition to the RNA-sequencing data, the study also includes gene expression values of IHCs and OHCs in an excel file. These values are provided as RPKM (Reads Per Kilobase Million) values. The expression values were aligned with microarray-based transcriptomes of IHCs and OHCs from a previous study, as well as transcriptome datasets of neonatal cochlear hair cells from two published studies. The alignment was done using Ensembl annotated gene names.

The quality of the sequencing reads was assessed using the FastQC app, which compared the read signals to the probability of accurate base-reading. The analysis showed that all sequencing runs had a Phred quality score of ≥ 30, indicating a high-quality and unambiguous sequencing.

Overall, the collected data includes RNA-sequencing data, gene expression values, and quality assessment information. It provides insights into the reproducibility of biological and technical replicates of IHCs and OHCs, as well as the similarity and differences in gene expression profiles between these cell populations.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected by isolating hair cells from CBA/J mice aged between 28 and 35 days old. The basilar membrane and organ of Corti were isolated, and the sensory epithelium was transferred to an enzymatic digestion medium. After incubation, the tissue was transferred to a chamber containing enzyme-free medium. Hair cells were separated by gentle trituration of the basilar membrane. The hair cells were then mounted onto a microscope stage and perfused with medium to wash out debris. Solitary inner hair cells (IHCs) and outer hair cells (OHCs) were identified based on their morphology and collected using pulled glass pipettes. Each pipette was designated for one cell type to prevent contamination. The hair cells were transferred to a microcentrifuge tube containing RNAlater. Approximately 50 to 80 IHCs and 100 to 150 OHCs were collected from each mouse, with a total of 30 mice used for the collection of two biological replicates of IHCs and three replicates of OHCs.

After collection, total RNA, including small RNAs, was extracted from approximately 1,000 cells using the Qiagen miRNeasy mini plus Kit. DNA contamination was eliminated, and the quality and quantity of RNA were examined using an Agilent 2100 BioAnalyzer. The RNA was then reverse transcribed into cDNA and amplified using the SMART-Seq V4 Ultra Low Input RNA kit.

For RNA-sequencing, genome-wide transcriptome libraries were produced from the biological replicates of IHCs and OHCs. The SMART-Seq V4 Ultra Low Input RNA kit was used in combination with the Nextera Library preparation kit. The libraries were sequenced using the HiSeq 2500 Sequencing System, generating approximately 100 million reads per sample. The resulting fastq files representing each library and quality control data were generated.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from RNA-seq transcriptomic analysis of IHCs and OHCs isolated from adult mouse cochleae, immunocytochemistry and confocal microscopy, and RT qPCR validation.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

- SMART-Seq V4 Ultra Low Input RNA kit (Clontech) for generating cDNA
- Nextera Library preparation kit (Illumina, Inc.) for library preparation
- Bioanalyzer 2100 and Qubit fluorometer (Invitrogen) for assessing library size and concentration
- HiSeq 2500 Sequencing System (Illumina) for sequencing the transcriptome libraries
- Inverted Olympus IX71 microscope equipped with a video camera for visual observation
- 200 μL Eppendorf pipette tip for gentle trituration of the basilar membrane
- Two pulled glass pipettes with a diameter of ~30 μm for picking up and transferring hair cells
- Narashigi micromanipulators (Narashigi, Japan) for holding the pipettes
- Micrometer-driven syringe for providing positive or negative pressure to draw in or expel the cells
- Microcentrifuge tube for transferring hair cells
- RNAlater (Thermo Fisher Scientific) for preserving RNA in the collected cells
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process done over the data involved several steps. First, the sequencing accuracy was assessed using the FastQC app, which compared the read signals to the probability of accurate base-reading. A Phred quality score of 20 was used as the cutoff for high-quality reads. 

Next, the reads were mapped to the mouse genome using the CLC Genomics Workbench software. Gene expression values were generated in the form of reads per kilobase of transcript per million mapped reads (RPKM) values. The reads were mapped to exonic, intronic, and intergenic sections of the genome. 

Functional annotation was performed using the Ingenuity IPA program and DAVID. Verification, reference, and analyses were done using the Entrez Gene, HGNC, OMIM, and Ensembl databases. 

Reproducibility of biological samples was assessed using correlation coefficients. The correlation coefficients between biological replicates and technical repeats of the samples were calculated. Principal component analysis (PCA) was used to measure levels of variation and similarity among gene expression datasets. 

Overall, the annotation process involved assessing sequencing accuracy, mapping reads to the genome, generating gene expression values, performing functional annotation, verifying and analyzing the data, and assessing reproducibility using correlation coefficients and PCA.
annotation_manual: The annotation process described in the context was done manually.
annotation_team_type: The context does not provide information about whether the data was annotated by an internal team, an external team, or a crowdsourcing team.
annotation_infrastructure:
Yes, the following tools or infrastructures were used during the annotation process:

- FastQC app
- CLC Genomics Workbench software
- Ingenuity IPA program
- DAVID
- Entrez Gene
- HGNC
- OMIM
- Ensembl databases
- HTSeq count
- Illumina cloud computing interface
- Phred quality score
- Illumina HiSeq 2500 Sequencing System
- Bioanalyzer 2100
- Qubit fluorometer
- Agilent 2100 BioAnalyzer
- RIN (RNA integrity number) software algorithm
annotation_validation_methods: Unknown

authoring_funding: Yes, this work has been funded by the National Institute of Mental Health.
authoring_funding_grant_id: The mentioned grant reference numbers in the context are PAA R34MH100466, T32MH0182607, and K24MH074717.
authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset are for researchers to access and analyze the data to advance understanding of mental health, while respecting participant confidentiality and privacy.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention of the dataset being tested in any machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people. The data collected through the device include communication metadata and mobile data such as activity type and distance traveled. The dataset does not collect personal and identifiable communication data such as the actual text of SMS or the phone numbers for incoming and outgoing calls. The dataset also includes daily descriptive summaries of phone-based communications and intraday GPS-based locations, but the raw GPS data from participants cannot be shared broadly due to data privacy.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The data collected consists of self-assessment of mood, depression, anxiety, and passively gathered phone-based behavioral data streams in real-world settings.
uses_data: The collected data consists of a longitudinal dataset from over two thousand individuals across the US. The data were generated as part of two NIMH-funded randomized clinical trials conducted to assess the effectiveness of delivering mental health care continuously remotely. The dataset includes self-assessment of mood, depression, anxiety, and passively gathered phone-based behavioral data streams in real-world settings. The purpose of sharing this dataset is to provide a resource for evaluating analytical approaches for developing digital behavioral markers and understanding the effectiveness of remote mental health care. The data can be accessed by qualified researchers through the study data portal, but researchers must complete several steps to ensure data privacy and confidentiality. The dataset is expected to have long-term value for researchers interested in digital mental health, enabling cross-study data integration, benchmarking analytical approaches, studying app use signatures and their relationship to outcomes, modeling individualized behavioral trajectories, and exploring the impact of traditional treatment on outcomes.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through passive data collection methods. In the V1 study, an app developed in collaboration with Ginger.io was deployed. This app automatically launched background data gathering processes once the user logged in. The data collected through the app included communication metadata (such as time of call/SMS, call duration, SMS length) and mobile data (such as activity type and distance traveled). However, personal and identifiable communication data, such as the actual text of SMS or phone numbers, were not collected.

In the V2 study, an in-house app named Survetory was developed to collect more fine-grained behavioral data. The passive data streams included a daily descriptive summary of phone-based communications (such as number of calls and texts) and intraday GPS-based locations. The app recorded the latitude and longitude every ten minutes or when there was a movement of more than 100 meters from the previously recorded spot. However, the raw GPS data from participants cannot be shared broadly due to data privacy concerns. Instead, granular intraday level summaries of features derived from the raw GPS data are shared. These features include overall daily mobility, average daily weather at the participant's location, and types of places visited in a day. The location of the different places visited is not extracted and stored.

The data gathered from study participants during the 12-week observation period can be accessed by qualified researchers through the study data portal (www.synapse.org/brighten). The portal provides detailed data descriptions for each active and passive data stream. The steps for accessing the data can be found on the study portal.

During the data cleaning and harmonization process, column names in the data files were aligned. The study portal also stores the provenance of upstream data cleaning and curation steps. To preserve participants' privacy, the self-reported zip code of study participants and the raw GPS data gathered in the V2 study were removed. However, the granular intraday GPS-derived features, including the open-source pipeline gSCAP used to featurize the GPS data, are freely available.

The source code for the tools used for data collection, such as the passive data collection app (Survetory), iPST, and HealthTips, is available on the study Github archive. The gSCAP pipeline used to featurize the raw GPS data from the V2 study and the data cleaning and curation pipeline are also available on GitHub.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: Yes, the context provides demographic information about the team who collect the data.
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects:

- Study participants
- Ginger.io app (for passive data collection in the V1 study)
- Survetory app (developed in-house for passive data collection in the V2 study)
- GPS data
- gSCAP pipeline (used to featurize the GPS data)
- Communication metadata (e.g., time of call/SMS, call duration, SMS length)
- Mobile data (activity type and distance traveled)
- Daily descriptive summary of phone-based communications
- Intraday GPS-based locations
- Individual-level geospatial semantics (derived from raw GPS data)
- Weather data (temperature, dew, cloud)
- Type of places visited in a day (coffee shop, park, shopping mall, etc.)
- Surveys completed by the participants
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

1. Study apps: The V1 study used an app developed in collaboration with Ginger.io, while the V2 study used an in-house app named Survetory. These apps collected passive data from participants' smartphones.

2. GPS data: The study app in the V2 study recorded participants' GPS coordinates every ten minutes or when there was a movement of more than 100 meters. The raw GPS data was not shared due to privacy concerns, but granular intraday level summaries of features derived from the raw GPS data were shared.

3. gSCAP pipeline: The open-source pipeline gSCAP (Geospatial Context Analysis Pipeline) was developed to featurize the raw GPS data. It generated individual-level geospatial semantics that were not identifiable in the same way as GPS coordinates. This pipeline extracted contextual features such as daily mobility, average daily weather, and types of places visited.

4. Data cleaning and harmonization: During the data cleaning and harmonization process, column names in the data files were aligned. The study portal also stored the provenance of upstream data cleaning and curation steps.

5. Study data portal: The data gathered from study participants can be accessed by qualified researchers through the study data portal (www.synapse.org/brighten). The portal provides detailed data descriptions for each active and passive data stream.

6. Online recruitment and prospective data collection: The participant onboarding process involved online recruitment and prospective data collection using smartphones. The overall schematic of the onboarding process is shown in Figure 1 of the document.

7. Communication metadata and mobile data: The passive data collected through the study apps included communication metadata (e.g., time of call/SMS, call duration, SMS length) and mobile data such as activity type and distance traveled. Personal and identifiable communication data were not collected.

8. Monetary incentives and participant validation: Both studies had monetary incentives for participants, with a maximum compensation of $75 spread over 12 weeks. Measures were taken to mitigate the possibility of individuals trying to "game the system" and acquire the research payment illegitimately.

9. Participant validation: Participants had to have a valid email and phone number to enroll in the study, reducing the ability to create multiple accounts. The study team also monitored for duplicate records and prevented individuals from enrolling if they made multiple unsuccessful attempts.

10. Data privacy: To preserve participants' privacy, the self-reported zip code of study participants and the raw GPS data gathered in the V2 study were removed.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process for the Brighten data involves several steps. First, researchers interested in accessing the data need to become a Synapse Certified User with a validated user profile. They also need to submit a 1-3 paragraph Intended Data Use statement to be posted publicly on Synapse. Additionally, researchers must agree to comply with the data-specific Conditions for Use, which include commitments to keep the data secure and confidential, not attempt to re-identify research participants, abide by responsible research use principles, and report any misuse or data release to the Synapse Access Compliance Team. 

Furthermore, users must agree to publish findings in open access publications and acknowledge the research participants and study investigators on all publications or presentations resulting from using the data. The data access process and instructions for requesting access can be found on the Accessing the Brighten Data page on Synapse.

In terms of technical validation, the data cleaning and harmonization process was conducted, aligning column names in the data files. The study portal also stores the provenance of upstream data cleaning and curation steps. Some privacy measures were taken, such as removing the self-reported zip code and raw GPS data of study participants. However, granular intraday GPS-derived features and the open-source pipeline used to featurize the GPS data are freely available. 

To prevent individuals from taking advantage of the study's monetary incentives, measures were taken to reduce the motivation and ability to "game the system." This includes spreading the maximum compensation over 12 weeks, requiring a valid email and phone number for enrollment, monitoring for duplicate records, and limiting access to subject-specific study apps with a unique password.

The initial raw data from each study were collected and stored on HIPAA-compliant servers at the University of California, San Francisco, following security standards and policies. The data records can be accessed by qualified researchers through the study data portal, which provides detailed data descriptions for each active and passive data stream.

uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. To provide metadata, batch design, and references for human brain region samples.
2. To analyze and quantify proteins present in brain tissue using a data-independent acquisition (DIA) approach.
3. To develop targeted assays and search for post-translational modifications or sequence variants.
4. To reanalyze the data for other unique features, such as isomerized peptides.

uses_data:
The collected data in this study consists of DIA (data independent acquisition) data from proteomics experiments studying the human brain. DIA is an alternative to the commonly used DDA (data-dependent acquisition) approach, which is limited in its ability to provide robust and quantitative measurements across a large number of samples. DIA acquires comprehensive MS/MS information in a single LC-MS/MS run using a repeated cycle of wide-window MS/MS scans. The DIA data in this study is available in five different categories based on the level of post-processing.

Level 0 represents the raw data in two different formats - the raw format directly from the Thermo mass spectrometer and the mzML format, which is the demultiplexed version of the raw data. Level 1 describes the zipped Skyline document grouped by batch. Level 2 is a csv file grouped by batch of the Skyline output with the integrated peak area for each peptide in each replicate. Level 3A is a csv file of the normalized peptide abundance across all batches, and Level 3B is a csv file of the normalized protein abundance across all batches.

In addition to the DIA data, quality control Skyline documents, peptide QC plots, and instrument raw files for system suitability runs are provided for each brain region. The Skyline documents and peptide QC plots for enolase and PRTC process controls are also provided for each brain region. The instrument raw files for process controls are the same as the DIA sample raw files for each brain region.

The collected data is available for download at Panorama Public with the ProteomeXchange ID: PXD034525. The data can be reanalyzed to explore other unique features, such as isomerized peptides. The feasibility of reanalysis has been demonstrated in a subset of this dataset by Hubbard et al. (reference 27).
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected using a mass spectrometry approach known as data independent acquisition (DIA). DIA is an alternative to data-dependent acquisition (DDA) and allows for the acquisition of comprehensive MS/MS information in a single LC-MS/MS run. In DIA, a repeated cycle of wide-window MS/MS scans is performed, allowing for the reproducible targeting and confident MS/MS-based quantification of peptides.

The collection process involved the analysis of brain tissue sections from four different regions. The samples were prepared and analyzed in batches of 16, with 14 individual samples per batch selected by balanced randomization. Each batch included an inter-experiment quality control sample generated from pooling portions of several individual samples from across all four brain regions sampled. Additionally, each batch included an inter-batch quality control sample generated from pooling portions of individual samples within that brain region. Protein and peptide sample processing controls were also included in all samples to track system suitability.

For each batch, an on-column data independent acquisition chromatogram library was generated from overlapping, narrow window gas-phase fractionation of an inter-batch QC. Individual samples were acquired using a single injection wider window data independent acquisition method. Peptide detection and scoring were performed using EncyclopeDIA and extracted ion chromatograms integrated with Skyline.

After the data collection, normalization and batch correction were performed on the peptide and protein group abundances. The normalization and batch correction steps aimed to reduce inter-batch variance and ensure accurate quantification of the samples.

The resulting dataset includes quantitative measurements of peptides and protein groups, allowing for the identification of differentially abundant peptides within protein coding genes. The dataset is publicly available on the Panorama web server in five different states, each corresponding to the level of post-processing.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from brain tissue sections, LC-MS/MS runs, inter-experiment quality control samples, inter-batch quality control samples, protein and peptide sample processing controls, data independent acquisition chromatogram library, EncyclopeDIA, Skyline, Panorama web server, SMTG brain region experiment, individual runs, proteomics data, sample preparation and analysis batches, normalization and batch correction, autosomal dominant Alzheimer's disease (AD) dementia (ADD) and high cognitive function (HCF)/low AD neuropathologic (ADNC) SMTG, amyloid-β and tau peptide abundances, frozen sections of brain tissue, brain donor characteristics, and DIA sampling.
collection_infrastructure: The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include data independent acquisition-mass spectrometry (DIA-MS), EncyclopeDIA, Skyline, IDPicker algorithm, mass spectrometry approach known as data-dependent acquisition (DDA), and tandem mass tags.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process done over the data involves several steps. First, the data is reanalyzed to look for unique features such as isomerized peptides. This reanalysis is possible due to the comprehensive sampling by data-independent acquisition. 

Next, sample homogenization and protein digestion are performed. Despite precautions taken to ensure equivalent sample preparation, additional post-processing is done to normalize and batch adjust the quantitative data to remove residual technical noise. This involves applying log 2 transformation and Median Deviation (MD) normalization to the peptide total area fragment values. The MD normalization calculates the deviation from the median of the sample total area fragment, without removing scale information or de-weighing outlier signals.

The DIA (Data-Independent Acquisition) method allows for comprehensive sampling, extracting information for the same transitions across all samples in an experiment. Zeros in the peptide abundance data represent signals below the limit of detection and are not treated as missing data. After protein group inference, protein abundances are batch corrected using the same method as the peptide data.

The processing and 'roll-up' of DIA data is similar to strategies used in the DDA (Data-Dependent Acquisition) field. Peptide-protein interactions are represented as a bipartite graph, and groupings are generated through the parsimony reduction of the graph. Peptide abundances are summed to estimate the abundance of peptide groups, and proteins that match the same set of peptide groups are merged into a single node in the graph, forming an indistinguishable protein group.

uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset are: refining FASTQ data based on Phred score, pre-processing sequence data by trimming step primers and filtering out low copy numbers, performing iterative data checks for accuracy, and using the data for observational and non-interventional studies.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.

This is indicated in the context where it mentions that data type 3 contains study metadata, including information about the age, sex, physical activity, BMI, and geographical locations of the participating subjects.

uses_data:
The collected data in this study consists of three data types. Data type 1 is available at the European Nucleotide Archive (ENA) portal of the European Bioinformatics Institute, while data types 2 and 3 are shared through the Supplementary Information. 

Data type 3 contains study metadata, specifically the codes of participating subjects along with information regarding their age, sex, physical activity, BMI, and geographical locations. These attributes within the metadata are useful for retrospective studies.

Before the data was locked in the database, iterative data checks were performed to ensure accuracy in data entry. The QC team also manually inspected the data integrity within the database.

For the pre-processing of sequence data, the step primers were trimmed and a minimum read length threshold of 100 bp was set. Any reads recording lengths shorter than the threshold were dropped from further processing. The read sequences were then clustered together and checked for copy number, with a minimum threshold of 10 reads. Any reads with low copy numbers (below the threshold of 10) were filtered out and dropped from further analysis.
collection_explanation: The dataset was collected through a sample collection process. Faecal samples were collected from individual subjects using a pre-labelled sterile OMNIgene®•GUT stool collection kit. This kit is designed to stabilize and maintain DNA integrity, allowing for gut microbiome profiling at an ambient temperature. Prior to collection, subjects received training and instructions on the collection process. The collected samples were stored at approximately 20 °C, following the manufacturer's instructions. Within 2 days of collection, the samples were processed for genomic DNA isolation at the central sequencing facility. Iterative data checks were performed to ensure accuracy in data entry, and manual inspection of data integrity was conducted by the QC team before the database was locked.
collection_team_type: Internal team
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from:
- Pre-processing Sequence Data
- Sample Management
- Sample Collection
- Bioinformatics Analysis
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

1. Pre-labelled sterile OMNIgene®•GUT stool collection kit (OMR-200, DNA Genotek, Ottawa, Canada): This kit was used for collecting the faecal samples. It is an all-in-one system designed to stabilize and maintain DNA integrity at ambient temperature.

2. Central sequencing facility: The samples collected in the OMNIgene®•GUT stool collection kit were processed for genomic DNA isolation at a central sequencing facility.

3. QIIME workflow on the Ion Reporter Server: The raw sequencing data were processed through a customized 16S analysis pipeline using the QIIME workflow on the Ion Reporter Server. This pipeline generated the taxonomical distribution of species and their relative abundance in an OTU table.

4. Database: A database was used for data entry and manual inspection of data integrity by the QC team.

Overall, the collection process involved the use of the OMNIgene®•GUT stool collection kit, a central sequencing facility, and bioinformatics tools such as the QIIME workflow on the Ion Reporter Server.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involved processing the raw sequencing data through a customized 16S analysis pipeline. This pipeline generated an OTU (Operational Taxonomic Unit) table, which reported the taxonomical distribution of species along with their relative abundance. The customized processing was performed using a QIIME workflow on the Ion Reporter Server. It is important to note that the content of the OTU table depends on the pipeline and parameters used for processing the data. Users are encouraged to regenerate the OTU table from the shared FASTQ data using their preferred pipeline and parameters for customized assessments.
annotation_team_type: The context does not provide information about whether the data was annotated by an internal team, an external team, or a crowdsourcing team.
annotation_infrastructure: Yes, the annotation process involved the use of the QIIME workflow and Ion Reporter Server.
annotation_validation_methods: The context does not provide information about the validation methods used to validate the labels.
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide any information about the demographic characteristics of the team who annotate the data.

uses_data:
The collected data consists of two comma-separated values (CSV) files. The first file, named "Mobility.txt", contains the hourly mobility network data. It has four columns, which are ordered by origin location, destination location, edge weight, and arriving time. The weight represents the number of movements per hour between the origin and destination locations. The second file, named "GPS.txt", contains the GPS information for each location. It has three columns, which are ordered by location identifier, latitude, and longitude.

The dataset includes more than 70 million movements and covers a one-week period starting on August 7, 2017. It captures the cellular position tracking of nearly 3 million anonymized cellular phone users among 167 divisions in Changchun City, Dehui City, Yushu City, and Nong'an County in Northeast China. The dataset covers a total geographic area of more than 20 square kilometers and had a population of nearly 8 million in 2017.

The mobility network is constructed by sequentially processing the directed movements of all individuals. Each location is represented as a node in the network, and a weighted edge represents the total number of users' movements between a pair of locations in each hour.

To facilitate the use of the data, the dataset is provided in CSV file format, with the mobility network data in the "Mobility.txt" file and the GPS information in the "GPS.txt" file. The data is organized in folders, with the first folder named "Week-Mobility-Network" containing the "Mobility.txt" file, and the second folder named "GPS-Location" containing the "GPS.txt" file.

It is important to note that the dataset has some limitations. It covers only a one-week period in summer time, and longer periods of time intervals might be needed for certain applications. The definition of a user's movement only considers when they stay in a new location for at least half an hour, which may introduce bias by ignoring quick movements. The recorded destination position of an individual might not accurately reflect their actual location during the whole period, and the recorded original position might have been unrecorded at an earlier time. Researchers are advised to be cautious when drawing conclusions from the data.

The Matlab code for data analysis of location correction and mobility network construction is available in Supplemental File 1.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected by capturing cellular position tracking data from an open-data program in Changchun city. Each location in the dataset represents a group of cellular stations in an official administrative division. The assumption is made that an individual stays at a location if their location remains the same for at least half an hour within an hour time interval. A directed movement from a source location to a destination location represents a change of location for the corresponding individual, and the time of the directed movement is recorded as the time of arrival at the destination location. The overall directed mobility network of locations is compiled by sequentially processing the directed movements for all individuals. In the network, a node represents a location, and a weighted edge represents the total number of users' movements between a pair of locations in each hour.

The dataset contains movements of nearly 3 million anonymized cellular phone users among 167 divisions (locations) in Changchun city, Dehui city, Yushu city, and Nong'an county. The dataset covers a one-week period starting on August 7, 2017. The dataset is released in two comma-separated values (CSV) files, each in a separate folder. The first file is the hourly mobility network, which includes four columns ordered by origin location, destination location, edge weight, and arriving time. The weight represents the number of movements per hour between the origin and destination locations. The second file is the GPS information for each location, which includes three columns ordered by location identifier, latitude, and longitude.

It is important to note that the dataset has some limitations. Firstly, it only covers a one-week period in the summer, so longer time intervals may be needed for certain applications. Secondly, movements are defined as occurring only when an individual stays in a new location for at least half an hour, which may introduce bias by ignoring quick movements. Thirdly, the recorded destination position may not accurately reflect the individual's actual location during the entire time period, as it is based on the last known recorded location. Finally, the individual's original position may have been unrecorded at an earlier time, as it depends on the last time the user used their phone.

Overall, the dataset provides a valuable resource for studying inter-urban interactions and human mobility within and between cities.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_speakers_demographics: No. The context does not provide information about the speech situation, such as the genre, the modality, or the topics.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from cellular phone logs and GPS information.
collection_infrastructure: The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include cellular phones for position tracking, GPS technology for capturing latitude and longitude information, and CSV files for storing and organizing the data.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process done over the data involves organizing and labeling the data in a structured manner. The dataset consists of two CSV files, each in a separate folder. The first file, "Mobility.txt," contains information about hourly movements between origin and destination locations. It has four columns: origin location, destination location, weight (number of movements per hour), and time. The second file, "GPS.txt," contains GPS information for each location, including the location identifier, latitude, and longitude.

The annotation process includes assigning numerical administrative division codes to each location, as well as recording the time of movements in ISO 8601 format. The dataset covers a one-week period in August 2017 and includes movements of nearly 3 million anonymized cellular phone users among 167 divisions in the Changchun city area.

The annotated data is organized into a dynamic and directed mobility network, where each location is represented as a node and the total number of users' movements between locations in each hour is represented as weighted edges. The dataset is made available in CSV file format for easy access and analysis.

It is important to note that the dataset has some limitations, such as covering only a one-week period, potential bias due to the definition of user movements, and potential bias in recording the individual's destination and original positions. Researchers are advised to consider these limitations when using the data.

uses_data:
The collected data in this dataset includes survey data from multiple countries. The countries in which the data was collected are summarized in Table 1, along with key metadata such as the research or development project, the lead organization implementing the survey, the number of households surveyed, and a brief summary of the sampling strategy. The dataset covers a wide geographic area, as shown in Figure 2.

The dataset also includes detailed documentation and metadata, which describe the aims of each project, the sampling strategy used, and additional data collected outside the core set of variables. These additional project-specific data can be requested from the corresponding author, in consultation with the organization that executed the survey in the field.

The total number of households in the dataset is 13,310, and the data is based on single cross-sectional survey applications. The households were chosen randomly in most applications, but some sampling strategies were aimed at evaluating project interventions.

The dataset can be found at Harvard Dataverse, and it includes 758 variables described in the file 'Raw Data code book.xlsx'. The variables included in the indicator results file are described in 'RHoMIS Data Processing Doc.docx'. The dataset is continuously updated, and the newest version can be found at www.rhomis.org.

The raw data provided in the dataset has been processed using a set of scripts in the R software environment. The data cleaning step was limited to correcting obviously unrealistic values, and the most important step was unifying crop and livestock names. The cleaned data from all survey implementations was then merged into a single raw data csv-file. Conversion factors used in the indicator calculations are based on literature resources. Intermediate output variables were generated within the calculations of some indicators. The final product of the indicator calculations is the merged RHoMIS indicator results file.

The dataset follows the FAIR principles, which ensure findability, accessibility, interoperability, and reusability of the data. This is achieved through standardized data labeling and processing approaches, extended metadata and documentation, publicly available survey and processing software, and the standardized approach of the core RHoMIS survey.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through a series of survey applications conducted in various countries. The countries in which the survey data were collected are listed in Online-only Table 1, along with key metadata such as the research or development project, the lead organization implementing the survey, the number of households surveyed, and a brief summary of the sampling strategy. The dataset includes detailed documentation and metadata that describe the aims of each project, the sampling strategy used, and additional data collected outside the core set of variables. 

The total number of households in the dataset is 13,310, and the data are based on single cross-sectional survey applications. In most applications, households were randomly chosen within the project sites, but some sampling strategies were aimed at evaluating project interventions. 

The data processing and indicator calculations were performed using a set of scripts in the R software environment. The raw data were cleaned by correcting obviously unrealistic values and unifying crop and livestock names. The cleaned data from all survey implementations were then merged into a single raw data csv-file. Conversion factors for indicator calculations were based on literature resources. Intermediate output variables were generated within the calculations of some indicators. The final product of the indicator calculations is the merged RHoMIS indicator results file. 

The dataset and the code used for processing and calculating the indicators are available at the Harvard Dataverse RHoMIS data repository. The data collection efforts adhered to ethical principles, and ethical approvals were obtained from internal ethical review committees or senior management at each organization.

collection_infrastructure: The tools and devices used during the collection process include the R software environment for data processing and indicator calculations. Additionally, literature resources were used to determine conversion factors for indicator calculations. The dataset also includes standardized data-labelling and data processing approaches, as well as extended metadata and documentation.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involves a series of standard data quality evaluation steps to assess the overall quality of the collected data. This process does not lead to the removal of individual observations. The validation information provided is meant to advise the data user on how to check the quality of the data and make informed decisions on whether to remove observations or data points. The data processing and indicator calculations are done using a set of standard scripts in the R software environment. The raw data is cleaned by correcting unrealistic values and unifying crop and livestock names. Conversion factors for indicator calculations are based on literature resources. Intermediate output variables are generated within the calculations of some indicators. The final product of the indicator calculations is the merged RHoMIS indicator results file. The annotated R code and detailed explanations of the calculations are also provided. The data management system follows the FAIR principles of Findability, Accessibility, Interoperability, and Reusability. The RHoMIS data can be found at Harvard Dataverse, and the variables are described in the code book files. The representativeness of each RHoMIS application is assessed through metadata information. The sampling procedures followed by the individual applications make it necessary to weight and/or resample households for valid statistical inferences. The RHoMIS questionnaire is administered digitally using the ODK software platform.

uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. To use the reduced version of the dataset for comparison with other power grids.
2. To use the 'with-tap' or 'without-tap' version of the dataset for detailed analysis of the physical connection topology or optimal power flow.
3. To analyze the performance and dynamic stability of power grids using the various attributes of the nodes and edges provided in the dataset.
4. To investigate the stability of new types of power grids, such as smart grid systems, distributed power generation, and renewable power generation technologies.
5. To analyze more sophisticated or realistic operation issues on power grids by using a realistic network dataset that preserves the detailed characteristics of power components.

uses_data_limits: Yes, it is mentioned that for the purpose of comparison to other power grids, it is recommended to use the reduced version of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset represents the power grid, not people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset is about the Chilean power grid, which includes information on nodes, edges, and activity. The node list includes attributes such as ID, label, owner, role, longitude, and latitude. The edge list includes information on the source and target nodes, distance, and voltage of transmission lines. The activity data is encoded into a spreadsheet with time series information about the amount of consumption or generation of activity nodes.
uses_data: The collected data is a dataset of the Chilean power grid. The dataset was created by harmonizing data from three different sources and filtering out inconsistent errors and unrealistic faults. The dataset includes three different versions: 'with-tap', 'without-tap', and 'reduced versions'. These versions preserve the physical structure of nodes' connections and incorporate various attributes such as geo-coordinates, voltage of transmission lines, and time series data of generation or consumption. The dataset includes information on nodes, edges, and activity. The node list includes attributes such as ID, label, owner, role, longitude, and latitude. The edge list includes information on the source and target nodes, distance, and voltage of transmission lines. The activity data is encoded into a spreadsheet with time series information about the amount of consumption or generation of activity nodes. The dataset is available in a data repository and is organized by versions. The dataset can be used for analyzing the performance and dynamic stability of power grids. The reduced version is recommended for comparison to other power grids, while the 'with-tap' or 'without-tap' versions are suitable for analyses related to the physical connection topology or optimal power flow. The dataset is important for analyzing realistic operation issues on power grids and investigating the stability of new types of power grids.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected by harmonizing data from three different sources to create a unified dataset of the Chilean power grid. The raw data was extensively reviewed to filter out inconsistent errors and unrealistic faults, ensuring the reliability of the data. The dataset includes three versions: 'with-tap', 'without-tap', and 'reduced versions', which preserve the physical structure of nodes' connections. 

The dataset is organized in a data repository, with files organized by versions. The node information is stored in .csv files, with each row corresponding to a node and columns providing details attributes such as ID, label, owner, role, longitude, and latitude. The edge list contains information about the transmission connection status of the power grid, including the source and target nodes, distance, and voltage. 

Activity data, which corresponds to the amount of power generation, is encoded into a large spreadsheet with time series information. The activity data is recorded on an hourly basis from September 16, 2015, to September 15, 2016. The dataset also includes various attributes of the nodes and edges, such as geo-coordinates, voltage of transmission lines, and time series data of generation or consumption.

The dataset can be easily imported using the Pandas library in Python. The dataset provides multiple indexes in the .csv file for nodes' attributes, making it convenient for users. The reduced version of the dataset is recommended for comparison with other power grids, while the 'with-tap' or 'without-tap' versions are suitable for detailed analyses related to the physical connection topology or optimal power flow.

The activity data was collected for one year from September 16, 2015, to September 15, 2016, from the official web page of CDEC-SIC. A Python code was developed to automatically parse the data from the raw file, minimizing human error. Inconsistencies in the raw data were manually inspected, and a consolidated node list was created. Nodes without activity data were assumed to be non-functioning due to maintenance, and their activity was set to zero.

To ensure the grid verifies Kirchhoff's law, the net activity of each node was adjusted to zero in the Kirchhoff-adjusted version of the activity data. The reserve capacity was canceled out from the generation activity by multiplying the activity values of generation with the ratio of the total consumption to the total generation. This adjustment process maintains the unique characteristics of the electricity generation profile of Chile.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from the Centro de Despacho Económico de Carga del Sistema Interconectado Central (CDEC-SIC), Mapa Sistemas Eléctricos de Chile, Diagrama Unilineal SIC, and Operaciόn real.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, or infrastructure used during the collection process include:

- Data repository: The network dataset is prepared and stored in a data repository.
- .csv files: The node list, edge list, and activity data are prepared as .csv files.
- Pandas library: The activity data can be imported and used with the Pandas library in Python.
- Standard packages: The activity data is prepared using standard packages, making it available in any programming language without sensitive development environment issues.
- Centro de Despacho Económico de Carga del Sistema Interconectado Central (CDEC-SIC): The agency responsible for the coordination and operation of the Central Chilean power grid provides raw data regarding the structure and operation of the power grid.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involves filtering out inconsistent errors and unrealistic faults in the raw data to make it more trustworthy. The process also focuses on preserving the physical structure of nodes' connection, specifically incorporating the 'tap' structure. Three different versions of the dataset are provided: 'with-tap', 'without-tap', and 'reduced versions'. Along with the structure, various attributes of the nodes and edges are incorporated, such as geo-coordinates, voltage of transmission lines, and time series data of generation or consumption.
annotation_team_type: The context does not provide information about whether the data was annotated by an internal team, an external team, or a crowdsourcing team.
annotation_infrastructure: No, the context does not provide information about the specific tools or infrastructures used during the annotation process.
annotation_validation_methods: Ground Truth Labels, Expert Annotations
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide any demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset include improving the identification of movement intention from sEMG maps using pattern recognition and machine learning procedures, testing algorithms for the decomposition of sEMG signals, studying regional inhomogeneities in motor unit activation, studying regional activation patterns for biofeedback purposes, testing methods for the automatic detection of innervation zones and MUAP propagation, testing the robustness of classification with smaller electrode grids and sensitivity to electrode shift, studying myoelectric manifestations of muscle fatigue, and testing outliers' detection and cleaning methods in EMG.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: Yes, the context mentions that there are limitations to using the database for classification purposes.
uses_represents_people: No. The dataset does not represent people. The dataset contains raw signals and information about the upper-limb size and measurements of the limbs of the subjects, but it does not directly represent people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset consists of raw signals collected from arrays placed on the upper arm or forearm of the subjects. The dataset includes information about the subjects' age, height, weight, and limb dimensions, but it does not specify that the subjects are humans.
uses_data:
The collected data in this dataset consists of raw signals without any further processing. The data is organized into individual folders for each of the twelve subjects (s1-s12). Each subject's folder contains four subfolders: one for torque signals and three for signals registered by each array (forearm, biceps, and triceps). The files in ASCII format are named according to the type of task and effort level.

In addition to the signal files, the dataset includes several other files. The "ReferencePoints.txt" file provides information about the final location of each array on the upper arm or forearm. It presents the distance in cm from the reference (origin of the coordinate system of the muscles) to the first electrode locating in the upper-left corner of the array. This information is provided for the x and y axis.

The "nchannels.txt" file provides the number of channels registered by each subject and array. The "forearm.txt" file contains the channels covering each of the muscles of interest in the forearm for every subject. The "SubjectsDescription.txt" file gives details of the population's age, height, weight, and dimensions of the limbs. Length and circumference measurements were taken to standardize the upper-limb size among subjects.

The dataset also includes a technical validation section, where the methods used for data collection and processing are described. The raw signals were collected using the DRL technique and analog filtered between 10-750 Hz. The different signal processing methods used for the detection of atypical signals, calculation of activity maps, and identification of volitional movement intention are briefly described. References to the original papers where these methods were described in depth are provided.

The quality of the HD-sEMG signals is also discussed. Outlier detection was used to examine the electrode-skin contact quality before signal recording. Circumferences and longitudinal distances were measured at different upper-limb segments to standardize the upper-limb size among subjects. Due to the simultaneous recording of many signals, it was expected to observe bad quality channels or outliers caused by poor electrode-skin contacts. Some cable and skin movement artifacts are also common when recording sEMG signals, even in isometric conditions.

The custom code used for reading the signals in the database was created in MATLAB R2017b and is freely available at figshare or the GitHub repository provided.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected using the DRL technique, with the raw signals being stored without any further processing. The data is organized into individual folders for each of the twelve subjects (s1-s12). Each subject's folder contains four subfolders: one for torque signals and three for signals registered by each array (forearm, biceps, and triceps). The files in each subfolder are in ASCII format and are named according to the type of task and effort level.

In addition to the signal files, the dataset includes several other files. The "ReferencePoints.txt" file provides information about the final location of each array on the upper arm or forearm. It presents the distance in cm from the reference (origin of the coordinate system of the muscles) to the first electrode locating in the upper-left corner of the array. This information is provided for the x and y axes.

The "nchannels.txt" file provides the number of channels registered by each subject and array. The "forearm.txt" file contains the channels covering each of the muscles of interest in the forearm for every subject. The "SubjectsDescription.txt" file gives details of the population's age, height, weight, and dimensions of the limbs, including length and circumference measurements.

The dataset was collected with the aim of standardizing the upper-limb size among subjects. The electrode-skin contact quality was not examined before signal recording due to the practical limitations of HD-sEMG recording. Instead, circumferences and longitudinal distances were measured at different upper-limb segments for each array. For arrays 2 and 3, distances were measured using the reference points proposed by the SENIAM project.

Given the simultaneous recording of many signals (approximately 340 per subject, task, and effort level), it was expected to observe bad quality channels or outliers caused by poor electrode-skin contacts. Some cable and skin movement artifacts are also common when recording sEMG signals, even in isometric conditions.

Overall, the dataset provides raw signals for testing new processing methods, and the methods used for signal processing, artifact detection, and movement intention identification are briefly described in the paper.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from the DRL technique, HD-sEMG signals, and anthropomorphic measurements of the subjects.
collection_infrastructure: The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include the DRL technique for collecting raw signals, analog filtering between 10-750 Hz, and arrays for recording signals from the forearm, biceps, and triceps. The data is stored in individual folders for each subject, and additional files provide information about the location of each array, the number of channels registered, and details about the population's age, height, weight, and limb dimensions.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involves the detection and identification of outliers or bad quality signals. The data records contain raw signals without any further processing. The annotation process includes the use of an expert system that achieved a precision of about 95% and a sensitivity of 93% in detecting outliers. The proportion of outliers varied between 0 and 13% for each sample in the training set, and approximately 6% of the total number of recorded signals were identified as outliers. The outlier detection methods refer these features to the neighbor channels rather than considering the bulk of data. The identification of artefacts is also done to correct bad quality channels. Overall, the quality of the signals in the database is considered excellent.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by an internal team (e.g the authors).
annotation_infrastructure: Yes, the annotation process involved the use of an expert system.
annotation_validation_methods: Ground Truth Labels, Expert Annotations
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. To predict regulatory networks downstream of expressed miRNAs and analyze miRNA-mRNA interactions.
2. To identify potential candidate miRNAs and downstream target mRNAs for future studies.
3. To study the expression and regulation of miRNAs in nephron progenitors and whole kidney during development.
4. To investigate the role of miRNAs in the pathogenesis of Wilms tumor.
5. To infer potential relationships between expressed miRNAs and cis-regulatory regions in nephron progenitors.
6. To identify putative Six2-regulated miRNAs that may play important roles in nephron progenitor maintenance and differentiation during kidney development.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people. The dataset is focused on the identification and analysis of novel miRNAs in the developing mouse kidney.
uses_collected_from_people: No, the subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset is derived from developing nephrogenic mesenchymal cells and whole kidney samples in mice.
uses_data:
The collected data in this study includes small RNA-Seq data from developing nephrogenic mesenchymal cells enriched for nephron progenitors and whole kidney. The data was analyzed using various software and tools. Adapter trimming was performed using BBmap software, and reads were aligned to the mouse genome using Bowtie2. miRNA specific analysis was performed using miRDeep2 software. Known miRNAs were quantified using miRBase v21, and DESeq2 was used to identify differentially expressed miRNAs between nephron progenitor and whole kidney samples. Novel miRNAs were annotated using miRDeep2 parameters. The read alignment data was visualized using the Integrative Genomics Viewer software. 

The quality control of the small RNA-Seq dataset showed good sequencing quality reads, as indicated by a mean value score of >30 for each sequenced base. Principal Component Analysis and hierarchical clustering were used to assess the congruence of the biological samples. The dataset also includes a heatmap representation of differentially expressed miRNAs in nephron progenitors vs. whole kidney samples.

The expression of differentially expressed miRNAs was validated using quantitative PCR. For known miRNAs, cDNA synthesis was performed using the TaqMan Advanced miRNA cDNA Synthesis Kit, and qPCR was carried out using TaqMan Advanced miRNA Assay probes. For novel miRNAs, cDNA synthesis was performed using the NCode VILO miRNA cDNA Synthesis Kit, and qPCR was performed using standard SYBR Green detection. The spatial expression pattern of miRNAs in the developing kidney was validated using Locked Nucleic Acid in situ hybridization.

The dataset also includes evidence of Six2 binding upstream of expressed miRNAs in nephron progenitors, as observed through the integration of a publicly available Six2 ChIP-Seq dataset with the small RNA-Seq results.

Overall, this dataset provides a comprehensive resource for miRNA expression in developing nephrogenic mesenchymal cells enriched for nephron progenitors and whole kidney. It can be used to predict regulatory networks downstream of the expressed miRNAs and to identify potential candidate miRNAs and/or downstream target mRNAs for future studies. The dataset can also be integrated with other published RNA-Seq data for the analysis of miRNA-mRNA interactions and can be complemented with ChIP-Seq datasets to infer potential relationships between expressed miRNAs and cis-regulatory regions in nephron progenitors.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected using a multi-step process. First, embryonic day 15.5 (E15.5) CD1 mouse kidneys were subjected to limited digestion, followed by negative cell selection through Magnetic Activated Cell Sorting (MACS). Total RNA from the isolated cells was then extracted and subjected to qPCR analysis to verify the enrichment of nephron progenitor markers. Once the enrichment was confirmed, the total RNA was used as input for the NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep to generate libraries for small RNA sequencing (sRNA-Seq).

The sRNA-Seq dataset was then analyzed using various software and tools. Adapter trimming was performed using the BBmap software, and the reads were aligned to the mouse genome (mm10) using Bowtie2. miRNA specific analysis was performed using the miRDeep2 software. Known miRNAs obtained from miRBase v21 were quantified, and miRNAs with more than 10 counts across all sample conditions were analyzed using DESeq2 to identify differential expression between nephron progenitor and whole kidney samples. miRNAs with a Benjamini-Hochberg adjusted p-value of 5% or less were reported. Novel miRNAs were annotated using the standard miRDeep2 parameters, and the read alignment data was visualized using the Integrative Genomics Viewer software.

For validation of differentially expressed miRNAs, cDNA synthesis was performed using the TaqMan Advanced miRNA cDNA Synthesis Kit, and qPCR was carried out using TaqMan Advanced miRNA Assay probes. For validation of novel miRNAs, cDNA synthesis was performed using the NCode VILO miRNA cDNA Synthesis Kit, and qPCR was performed using standard SYBR Green detection. Locked Nucleic Acid miRNA in situ hybridization was used to validate the spatial expression pattern of miRNAs in the developing kidney.

Overall, the dataset was collected by isolating nephron progenitor cells, extracting total RNA, generating small RNA libraries, performing sRNA-Seq, and analyzing the data using various software and tools. The dataset also includes validation of differentially expressed and novel miRNAs using qPCR and in situ hybridization.

collection_sources:
The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects:
- Small RNA-Seq dataset
- Mouse genome (mm10)
- miRBase v21
- FastQC analysis
- BBmap software
- Bowtie2 software
- miRDeep2 software
- DESeq2 software
- Integrative Genomics Viewer software
- Magnetic Activated Cell Sorting (MACS)
- TaqMan Advanced miRNA cDNA Synthesis Kit
- TaqMan Advanced miRNA Assay probes
- TaqMan Universal Master Mix II, no UNG
- NCode VILO miRNA cDNA Synthesis Kit
- Locked Nucleic Acid (LNA) detection probes
- Six2 ChIP-Seq dataset
- NEBNextMultiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina
- Agencourt AMPure XP beads
- NextSeq 500/550 Mid Output v2 Kit (150 cycles)
- Illumina NextSeq 550 System
- RNAfold tool
- miRBase (for naming the novel miRNAs)
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

- BBmap software for adapter trimming
- Bowtie2 for read alignment to the mouse genome (mm10)
- miRDeep2 software for miRNA specific analysis
- DESeq2 for identifying differential expression
- Integrative Genomics Viewer software for visualizing read alignment data
- TaqMan Advanced miRNA cDNA Synthesis Kit for cDNA synthesis
- TaqMan Advanced miRNA Assay probes for qPCR analysis
- NCode VILO miRNA cDNA Synthesis Kit for cDNA synthesis
- SYBR Green detection for qPCR analysis
- Locked Nucleic Acid miRNA in situ hybridization for spatial expression pattern validation
- NextSeq 500/550 Mid Output v2 Kit for multiplex sequencing
- Illumina NextSeq 550 System for sequencing
- Agencourt AMPure XP beads for size selection
- Rangos Research Center for sequencing facility
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involved several steps. First, adapter trimming was performed using the BBmap software. Then, the reads were aligned to the mouse genome using Bowtie2. Next, miRNA specific analysis was performed using the miRDeep2 software. Known miRNAs obtained from miRBase were quantified, and miRNAs with more than 10 counts across all sample conditions were analyzed using DESeq2 to identify differential expression between nephron progenitor and whole kidney samples. The miRDeep2 package was used to annotate novel miRNAs, and the read alignment data was visualized using the Integrative Genomics Viewer software. Finally, qPCR and Locked Nucleic Acid in situ hybridization were performed to validate the expression of the identified miRNAs.

uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. To analyze floodplain land use change in any of the world's major river basins.
2. To assist other researchers with the reuse of the dataset.
3. To foster new research on floodplain resilience.
4. To perform data discovery, download, and pre-processing tasks in a semi-automatic manner.
5. To reproduce the MRB floodplain land use change dataset.

uses_represents_people: No. The dataset does not represent people. It represents land use and floodplain extent.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset is derived from two input data sources: the GFPLAIN250m dataset and the annual continental United States land use data. The GFPLAIN250m dataset estimates flood energy gradients at the river basin scale using a hydrologic model, and the USGS land use data is based on a modeling framework that combines various data sources.
uses_data:
The collected data for this study is a 60-year floodplain land use change dataset for the Mississippi River Basin (MRB). The dataset was derived from two input data sources: the GFPLAIN250m dataset developed by Nardi et al., which is a high-resolution global floodplain extent dataset based on a geomorphic analysis of the Digital Terrain Model (DTM), and the annual continental United States land use data developed by USGS. 

The GFPLAIN250m dataset estimates distributed flood energy gradients at the river basin scale using a simplified hydrologic model. It assigns maximum flood depths to every channel cell based on the drainage area. The USGS land use data is based on a spatially explicit modeling framework that combines National Land Cover Databases, agricultural census information, and satellite imagery to reconstruct a temporally continuous land use. 

The dataset is publicly available at a spatial resolution of 250 meters in gridded GeoTIFF format. The coordinates are set by the World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS84) for the GFPLAIN250m dataset and the USA Contiguous Albers Equal Area Conic USGS version projected system for the USGS land use data. The land use dataset is divided into a 14-class historical land use for each year from 1938 to 1992 and a 17-class recent land use for each year from 1992 to 2005. The dataset used in this study includes land use data from 1941 to 2000.

To ensure the dataset's accessibility and reproducibility, the researchers developed four software solutions and educational products. These products assist other researchers in reusing the dataset and enable efficient analysis of floodplain land use change in other major river basins worldwide.

The MRB floodplain land use change dataset, along with the corresponding input data, intermediate calculations, and supporting information, is available through the open-access geospatial data sharing platform HydroShare. The entire dataset can be downloaded as a single zip file from the provided web address.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected using a multi-step process. The researchers used two primary data sources: the GFPLAIN250m dataset developed by Nardi et al., which provides high-resolution global floodplain extent data, and the annual continental United States land use data developed by USGS. The GFPLAIN250m dataset is based on a geomorphic analysis of the Digital Terrain Model (DTM) and estimates distributed flood energy gradients at the river basin scale. The USGS land use data is based on a spatially explicit modeling framework that combines various sources such as the National Land Cover Databases, agricultural census information, and satellite imagery.

To develop the 60-year MRB floodplain land use change dataset, the researchers included land use data from 1941 to 2000. The collection process involved six consecutive steps: reprojection of floodplain and land use data to a consistent coordinate system, land use reclassification, extraction of floodplain land use, land use change detection, formation of inter-class land transition matrix, and technical validation. These steps were performed using ArcGIS 10.5 and ENVI 5.1 geospatial analysis platforms.

The final dataset is publicly available in gridded GeoTIFF format with a spatial resolution of 250 meters. The coordinates are set by the World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS84) for the floodplain data and the USA Contiguous Albers Equal Area Conic USGS version projected system for the land use data. The land use dataset includes a 14-class historical land use for each year from 1938 to 1992 and a 17-class recent land use for each year from 1992 to 2005.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects:
- Global floodplain extent dataset (GFPLAIN250m)
- Annual continental United States land use data developed by USGS
- National Land Cover Databases (NLCD)
- Agricultural census information
- Representative satellite imagery
collection_infrastructure: The tools and devices used during the collection process include ArcGIS 10.5 and ENVI 5.1 geospatial analysis platforms.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involves several steps. First, data discovery, download, and pre-processing tasks are performed in a semi-automatic manner. The process is scalable to the floodplains in any of the world's major river basins. The land use input used in the process is obtained from various sources, including the 30-m National Land Cover Database (United States) classifications. The validation of the data is done by selecting 12 sites across the MRB (Mississippi River Basin) that represent different geophysical settings and stream orders. The validation is conducted for the common period of data availability between the USGS (input) and remotely sensed (reference) datasets. The comparison is done at an aggregated level for each site, rather than evaluating cell-by-cell correlations.

2. National Natural Science Foundation of China (41921005)
