authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset include analyzing urban carbon footprints in a temporal and spatially differentiated manner, identifying differences in consumption patterns and drivers of emissions by city, month, year, income, education, and age, understanding broader phenomena related to the environmental impacts of urban consumption, informing global reports on urban carbon mitigation, identifying priority areas for GHG emission reduction, facilitating better-informed and evidence-based mitigation actions by policy-makers, understanding seasonal emission patterns, exploring differentiated emission profiles across households with different characteristics, and generating good practices for tracking household carbon footprints.
uses_ml_approach: Yes, the dataset has been tested in a machine learning approach. The method used to develop the emissions factors in this dataset has been discussed and used in previous Urban Carbon Footprint studies.
uses_data_limits: Yes, the context mentions that there are limitations to the dataset, such as the underestimation of findings due to the exclusion of single-person households and the inability to consider emission intensities for imported goods. It also mentions that the dataset cannot be disaggregated by income level or age group.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset represents the direct and indirect emissions of urban households in major Japanese cities. It does not represent people directly.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset consists of monthly direct and indirect greenhouse gas emissions of urban households in major Japanese cities.
uses_data:
The collected data in this dataset consists of monthly direct and indirect greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions of urban households in major Japanese cities from 2011 to 2015. The dataset is based on the "Family Income and Expenditure Survey" (FIES) conducted by the Statistics Bureau of Japan, which quantifies the expenditures of Japanese households for around 500 categories of goods and services. This consumption data is combined with the Embodied Energy and Emission Intensity Data for Japan Using Input-Output Tables (3EID) for 2011 and 2015. 

The dataset includes both direct and indirect emissions. Direct emissions are the result of the direct combustion of fossil fuels in housing, transport, and other activities. Indirect emissions represent the emissions embodied in the goods and services consumed by urban households. 

The dataset covers 51-52 major Japanese cities, including all the capitals of the 47 prefectures and four other major cities. The dataset is divided into 17 excel files, with two files for each study year (one for direct emissions and one for indirect emissions). The direct emissions files also include unit prices for direct energy consumption for each city and month. 

Overall, the dataset contains a total of 1,555,512 items, with 1,543,128 items for indirect emissions and 12,384 items for direct emissions. The emissions are expressed in "per capita" terms. 

The dataset can be used to analyze various aspects of urban carbon footprints, such as differences in emissions between cities, differences in consumption structure, and differences in emissions by month, year, income, education, or age. It can also be used to understand broader phenomena related to the environmental impacts of urban consumption, such as urban tele-connections, transboundary environmental impacts, and inequalities in emissions. 

The dataset can be a valuable resource for urban researchers, practitioners, and policy-makers interested in studying and mitigating GHG emissions at the city level. It can help identify priority areas for emission reduction and inform evidence-based mitigation actions. It can also facilitate the understanding of seasonal emission patterns and the development of decarbonization measures through behavioral change. Additionally, the dataset can be used to explore differentiated emission profiles across households with different characteristics and inform the creation of targeted measures to affect consumption and emission behavior.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected using two main sources of data: the monthly "Family Income and Expenditure Survey" (FIES) conducted by the Statistics Bureau of Japan, and the 2011 and 2015 databases of the Embodied Energy and Emission Intensity Data for Japan Using Input-Output Tables (3EID). 

The FIES survey collects data on the expenditures of Japanese households for around 500 distinct categories of goods and services. This data is used to quantify the consumption patterns of urban households in major Japanese cities. 

The 3EID databases provide information on the emission intensities of different industries and sectors in Japan. These emission intensity factors are used to calculate the indirect emissions embodied in the goods and services consumed by urban households. 

The dataset covers the period between 2011 and 2015 and includes both direct and indirect greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Direct emissions are due to the combustion of fossil fuels in housing, transport, and other activities, while indirect emissions reflect the emissions embodied in the goods and services consumed by households. 

The dataset includes data from 51 or 52 major Japanese cities, including all of the prefectural capitals and four other major cities. The files of the annual FIES surveys are processed to extract the relevant data for both direct and indirect emission calculations. 

It is important to note that the 3EID databases are released every five years, so the emission intensities for the indirect emission categories are only available for the years 2011 and 2015. To estimate the indirect emission intensities for the years 2012, 2013, and 2014, linear interpolation is used. 

The dataset provides a comprehensive and high-resolution view of urban household emissions in Japan, allowing for the analysis of consumption patterns, emission drivers, and differences in emissions across different cities, income levels, education levels, and age groups. It can be used by researchers, practitioners, and policy-makers to inform decision-making and develop targeted mitigation strategies.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from the "Family Income and Expenditure Survey" (FIES) conducted by the Statistics Bureau of Japan and the Embodied Energy and Emission Intensity Data for Japan Using Input-Output Tables (3EID).
collection_infrastructure: The tools, devices, or infrastructure used during the collection process include the monthly "Family Income and Expenditure Survey" (FIES) collected by the Statistics Bureau of Japan, the 2011 and 2015 databases of the Embodied Energy and Emission Intensity Data for Japan Using Input-Output Tables (3EID), and input-output tables.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involves quantifying the direct and indirect emissions of urban households in major Japanese cities for the period between 2011 and 2015. The dataset is based on the monthly "Family Income and Expenditure Survey" (FIES) collected by the Statistics Bureau of Japan, which quantifies the expenditures of Japanese households for around 500 distinct categories of goods and services. This consumption data is then coupled with the 2011 and 2015 databases of the Embodied Energy and Emission Intensity Data for Japan Using Input-Output Tables (3EID) to calculate the direct and indirect GHG emissions of urban households. The direct emissions are due to the direct combustion of fossil fuels in housing, transport, and other activities, while the indirect emissions reflect the emissions embodied in the goods and services consumed by urban households. The dataset provides comprehensive and consistent data on both direct and indirect emissions, allowing for analysis of consumption patterns and the development of decarbonization measures.

authoring_funding_grant_id: The mentioned grant reference numbers in the context are: P4-0165, J4-4165, J4-7636, J4-8228, J4-9302, CA15110 (CHARME), and CA15109 (COSTNET).
authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset include: 
1. De novo assembly of short reads.
2. Decreasing redundancy of assemblies and annotation.
3. Filtering and validation of transcriptomes.
4. Studying variability of potato transcriptomes.
5. Improving high-throughput sequencing analyses.
6. Informing qPCR amplicon design.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any testing of the dataset using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people. The dataset is focused on potato transcriptomes and includes information about potato genes, transcripts, and microbial transcripts present in potato tissues.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The dataset consists of potato transcriptomes.
uses_data: The collected data in this study consists of input datasets, which are sequence reads, and output data, which are transcriptomes. The input datasets are depicted as blue cylinders. The data upload steps to public repositories are shaded in orange. The bioinformatics pipeline used for generating the potato transcriptomes is described. The pipeline includes steps such as de novo assembly of short reads using different software tools like Trinity, Velvet/Oases, rnaSPAdes, and CLC Genomics Workbench. Illumina and SOLiD reads were assembled separately. The assembly parameters used for CLC and Velvet are provided in Table 1. The assemblies were then filtered and annotated using biological evidence from MatchAnnot, InterProScan, and DIAMOND. Representative and alternative sets of transcripts were merged into initial cultivar reference transcriptomes. The reference transcriptomes were mapped to the DM reference genome and analyzed for matching gene models and domain assignments. Orphaned reads were re-assigned as single-end reads. The processed reads were pooled into cultivar datasets. Additional processing steps were performed for specific datasets, such as converting SOLiD reads into double encoding reads and performing digital normalization for reducing dataset size. PacBio long reads were processed using the Iso-Seq 3 analysis software. The pipeline included steps like Circular Consensus Sequence (CCS) generation, identification of full-length reads, clustering isoforms, and polishing using the Arrow consensus algorithm.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected using a combination of sequencing platforms and analysis tools. Orphaned reads were re-assigned as single-end reads, with a minimum trimmed sequence length of 15 bp and a maximum length of 1 kb. Processed reads were then pooled into cultivar datasets as properly paired-end reads or single-end reads per cultivar per sequencing platform. For the Velvet assembler, SOLiD reads were converted into double encoding reads using a perl script. To reduce the size of the datasets for cv. Désirée and cv. Rywal, digital normalization was performed using khmer from the bbmap suite prior to conducting de novo assembly using Velvet and rnaSPAdes. PacBio long reads were processed for each sample independently using Iso-Seq 3 analysis software.

After the initial assembly, representative and alternative sets of transcripts were merged into cultivar-specific reference transcriptomes. These reference transcriptomes were then mapped to the DM reference genome using STARlong. Aligned transcripts were analyzed with MatchAnnot to identify transcripts that match known gene models. Domains were assigned to the polypeptide dataset using InterProScan software.

To validate the quality of the assemblies, Illumina reads were mapped back to the cultivar-specific initial transcripts using STAR. TransRate was used to assess the quality of the transcriptomes based on size-based and reference-based metrics. Comparative metrics for coding sequences were obtained using Conditional Reciprocal Best BLAST against merged gene model coding sequences. BUSCO scores were calculated to estimate the completeness and duplicated fraction of the transcriptomes.

Multiple sequence alignments were conducted on representative and alternative sequences from paralogue clusters to check the quality of the assemblies and optimize the pipeline. Taxonomic classification was performed to estimate the proportion of transcripts originating from organisms other than potato.

All custom code and scripts used in the analysis, as well as intermediate and processed data, are available at FAIRDOMHub under a CC BY 4.0 license.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects: orphaned reads, cultivar datasets, SOLiD reads, cv. Désirée and cv. Rywal datasets, PacBio long reads, input datasets (sequence reads), output data (transcriptomes), SRA -NCBI Sequence Read Archive, PGSC -Potato Genome Sequencing Consortium, ITAG -international Tomato Annotation Group, CLC -CLC Genomics Workbench, PacBio -Pacific Biosciences Iso-Seq sequencing, Tr -transcriptome, StPanTr -potato pantranscriptome, tr2aacds -"transcript to amino acid coding sequence" Perl script from EvidentialGene pipeline, MatchAnnot, InterProScan, DIAMOND, UniProt, Solanum tuberosum, Solanaceae, plants, vector segment contamination.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:
- Perl script "denovo_preprocessor_solid_v2.2.1.pl"
- Khmer from bbmap suite v37.68
- Iso-Seq 3 analysis software (Pacific Biosciences)
- Circular Consensus Sequence (CCS) generation
- Arrow consensus algorithm
- CLC Genomics Workbench
- PacBio -Pacific Biosciences Iso-Seq sequencing
- Tr -transcriptome
- StPanTr -potato pantranscriptome
- tr2aacds -"transcript to amino acid coding sequence" Perl script from EvidentialGene pipeline
- MatchAnnot
- InterProScan
- DIAMOND
- SRA -NCBI Sequence Read Archive
- PGSC -Potato Genome Sequencing Consortium
- ITAG -international Tomato Annotation Group
- Data upload steps to public repositories
- EvidentialGene v2016.07.11
- Exonerate package
- cd-hit
- UniProt (www.uniprot.org)
- VecScreen plus taxonomy program v.0.16
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process involved several steps. First, the assemblies were reduced for redundancy and error removal. The short reads from different cultivars were assembled into potential transcripts. Then, representative and alternative sets of transcripts were merged into initial cultivar reference transcriptomes. These reference transcriptomes were mapped to the DM reference genome and analyzed with MatchAnnot to identify transcripts that match the PGSC or ITAG gene models. Domains were assigned to the polypeptide dataset using InterProScan software. 

To validate the quality of the assemblies, the percentage of correctly assembled bases was measured by mapping Illumina reads back to the initial transcripts. TransRate was used to assess the quality of the transcriptomes based on size-based and reference-based metrics. Comparative metrics for coding sequences were obtained using Conditional Reciprocal Best BLAST. BUSCO scores were calculated to estimate completeness and the duplicated fraction of the transcriptomes. Multiple sequence alignments were conducted to check the quality of paralogue cluster assignments. 

To determine the proportion of transcripts from organisms other than potato, a taxonomic classification was performed using Centrifuge and the NCBI nt database. The transcriptomes were found to include less than 1% bacterial, viral, fungal, and protozoan transcripts. 

Overall, the annotation process involved reducing redundancy, mapping to a reference genome, analyzing with MatchAnnot, assigning domains, validating the quality of the assemblies, and performing taxonomic classification.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by an internal team (e.g the authors).
annotation_infrastructure:
Yes, the following tools or infrastructures were used during the annotation process:

- MatchAnnot
- InterProScan
- TransRate
- Conditional Reciprocal Best BLAST
- BUSCO
- Centrifuge
- NCBI nt database
- Bash
- Perl
- Python
- R/Markdown
- FAIRDOMHub
- pISA-tree
- FAIRDOMHub API
- R package pisar
annotation_validation_methods: Ground Truth Labels, Inter-annotator agreement, Expert Annotations, Test re-test reliability, Proxy-labels, others
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

authoring_funding: Yes, this work has been funded by the Department of Biotechnology, Government of India.
authoring_funding_grant_id:
The grant reference numbers mentioned in the context are:
- Grant No. BT/AAQ/3/SP28267/2018
authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. Sequence data analysis, including processing and analysis of raw data generated with the PacBio Sequel platform.
2. Sample collection, preservation, and RNA preparation for studying the cobia fish.
3. Detection of simple sequence repeats (SSRs) in the non-redundant reference transcriptome of R. canadum.
4. Prediction of coding sequences and open reading frames (ORFs) in the transcriptome data.
5. Code availability for replicating the data analysis using specific software tools.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset represents transcriptome sequences from cobia, including larvae, juveniles, and various tissues of adult cobia.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are cobia (Rachycentron canadum) larvae, juveniles, and various tissues of adult cobia.
uses_data:
The collected data in this study consists of transcriptome sequences from larvae, juveniles, and various tissues of adult cobia (Rachycentron canadum). The data was obtained using a long-read based sequencing technology called PacBio Sequel II Iso-Seq3 SMRT. A single SMRTcell generated a total of 99 gigabytes of data and 51,205,946,694 bases. 

The raw data generated with the PacBio Sequel platform was analyzed and processed using the standard protocol in SMRT Link software. Subreads were obtained by removing adapters from the sequences and sorting out polymerase reads with fragment lengths less than 50 bp and a quality of 0.90. Subreads with a length of less than 50 bp were discarded, and the remaining subreads represented clean data. 

Circular consensus sequences (CCS) with full passes of ≥ 1 and a quality of > 0.90 were retrieved from the clean data. The CCS were categorized into full-length nonchimeric CCSs and non-full-length nonchimeric CCSs by determining the presence of sequencing primers and terminal polyA sequence. 

Isoseq 3 software was used to extract and polish consensus isoforms in full-length nonchimeric CCSs. The criterion for achieving high-quality, full-length transcripts was >99% post-correction accuracy. CD-HIT software was used to eliminate redundant sequences from high-quality, full-length transcripts, resulting in a final isoform set of non-redundant transcripts. 

TransDecoder v3.0.1 software was used to predict the open reading frames (ORFs) of the non-redundant transcript isoform set with the lowest coding sequence (CDS) length of 100 bp. 

Transcriptome completeness was analyzed using the Benchmarking Universal Single Copy Orthologs (BUSCO) analysis based on the Ortholog database. 

The raw full-length data were deposited in the NCBI Sequence Read Archive (SRA) under accession numbers SRR19370125, SRR19370124, and SRR19370123. The respective BioSamples accession numbers are SAMN28614395, SAMN28614396, and SAMN28614397. Data regarding the identified nutritionally important genes was deposited at the figshare platform. The file contains multiple spreadsheets with the annotated list of genes involved in the metabolism of carbohydrate, protein, lipid, vitamin, mineral, digestive function, and bone development.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through a series of steps. For the larval samples, a weight of 500-800 mg containing approximately 300 larvae of 5 days post-hatching (dph) and 15 larvae of 29 dph was collected in triplicates. These samples were immediately stored in RNA protection reagent (RNAlater) at -80 °C until RNA extraction. Tissue samples (muscle, kidney, spleen, liver, intestine) weighing 500-800 mg each were collected from 3 individuals of juvenile and adult fish. These tissue samples were also immediately stored in RNA protection reagent and maintained at -80 °C until RNA extraction.

Total RNA was extracted from each sample using the lithium chloride approach and purified using the NucleoSpin RNA clean-up kit. The quantity and integrity of the RNA samples were analyzed using the Qubit 4.0 fluorometer and the AGILENT Bio-analyser 2100.

The raw data generated with the PacBio Sequel platform was analyzed and processed using the standard protocol in SMRT Link software. Subreads were obtained by removing adapters from the sequences and sorting out polymerase reads with fragment lengths less than 50 bp and a quality of 0.90. Subreads with a length of less than 50 bp were discarded, and the remaining subreads represented clean data.

Circular consensus sequences (CCS) with full passes of ≥ 1 and a quality of > 0.90 were retrieved from the clean data. The presence of sequencing primers and terminal polyA sequence was used to categorize the CCS into full-length nonchimeric CCSs and non-full-length nonchimeric CCSs.

The full-length nonchimeric CCSs were used to extract and polish consensus isoforms using Isoseq 3 software. The CD-HIT software was then used to eliminate redundant sequences from the high-quality, full-length transcripts. The resulting full-length transcriptome was used as the final isoform set of non-redundant transcripts for further analysis.

The open reading frames (ORFs) of the non-redundant transcript isoform set were predicted using TransDecoder v3.0.1 software. Finally, the transcriptome completeness was analyzed using the Benchmarking Universal Single Copy Orthologs (BUSCO) analysis based on the Ortholog database.

In summary, the dataset was collected by sampling larvae, juveniles, and various tissues of adult cobia. RNA was extracted from these samples, and long-read sequencing technology was used to obtain complete transcriptome sequences. The data was then processed and analyzed to obtain high-quality, non-redundant transcripts for further analysis.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from PacBio Sequel platform, SMRT Link software, Isoseq 3 software, CD-HIT software, TransDecoder v3.0.1 software, Benchmarking Universal Single Copy Orthologs (BUSCO) analysis, ARRIVE recommendations, UK legislation: Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act (1986), EU Directive on animal studies, ICAR-CMFRI, Kochi, India, Marine Fish Hatchery at the Mandapam Regional Centre of ICAR-Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute, India, high-density polyethylene sea cages, RNA protection reagent (RNAlater, Sigma-Aldrich), tissue samples (muscle, kidney, spleen, liver, intestine), lithium chloride approach, NucleoSpin RNA clean-up kit, Qubit 4.0 fluorometer, AGILENT Bio-analyser 2100, NEBNext Single Cell/Low input cDNA synthesis, Pronex beads, BluePippin TM size selection system, PacBio Sequel II platform, Nucleome Informatics (P) Ltd., Hyderabad, India.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

1. PacBio Sequel platform: Used for generating raw data through single molecule real-time (SMRT) sequencing.

2. SMRT Link software: Used for analyzing and processing the raw data generated by the PacBio Sequel platform.

3. RNAlater: A RNA protection reagent used for preserving the collected samples at -80 °C until RNA extraction.

4. Qubit 4.0 fluorometer: Used for analyzing the quantity of RNA samples.

5. AGILENT Bio-analyser 2100: Used for analyzing the integrity of RNA samples.

6. PacBio's Iso-Seq3 protocol: Used for library preparation of the RNA samples.

7. NEBNext Single Cell/Low input cDNA synthesis: Used for reverse transcription of purified polyA mRNA into cDNA.

8. Pronex beads: Used for purification of cDNA preparation.

9. BluePippin TM size selection system: Used for size selection of DNA fragments.

10. PacBio Sequel II platform: Used for sequencing the SMRTbell libraries.

11. Nucleome Informatics (P) Ltd.: The facility where the PacBio Sequel II sequencing was performed.

12. CD-HIT software: Used for eliminating redundant sequences from high-quality, full-length transcripts.

13. TransDecoder v3.0.1 software: Used for predicting the open reading frames (ORFs) of the non-redundant transcript isoform set.

14. Benchmarking Universal Single Copy Orthologs (BUSCO) analysis: Used for analyzing transcriptome completeness based on the Ortholog database.

Note: These are the tools, devices, and infrastructure mentioned in the provided context. There may be additional tools or devices used that are not mentioned.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process for the data involved several steps. First, the full-length transcripts were annotated using BLASTx and BLASTp searches against various databases, including NCBInr, RefSeq, UniProtKB, KOG, and Pfam. The E-value cut off used was 1e-5. The best match for each transcript was determined based on the bit score.

Gene Ontology (GO) annotation was performed using Metascape and EggNOG analyses to classify the function of the transcripts based on cellular components, molecular functions, and biological process features.

To obtain the overall biological function of the transcriptome, the full-length transcripts were mapped into canonical reference pathways in the KEGG database using KEGG KASS. The TransDecoder software was used to find functional protein domains and predict the open reading frames (ORFs) of the non-redundant transcripts.

The transcriptome was also annotated with several databases, including NCBI nr, RefSeq, and UniprotKB, which resulted in functional assignments for 53.51% of the transcripts. The majority of sequence similarities were found in the NCBI nr database.

The KOG-annotated transcripts were grouped into 26 KOG classifications, with the highest number of transcripts in the function unknown category. For KEGG annotation, the transcripts were mainly grouped into 398 signaling pathways, with the signal transduction pathway having the highest number of transcripts.

After GO annotation, a total of 58.82% of the transcripts were allocated to multiple GO terms, including biological process, molecular function, and cellular component.

Overall, 99.62% of the transcripts were successfully annotated in at least one database, and 21.69% were annotated in all databases.

In addition to functional annotation, the data analysis also involved the detection of simple sequence repeats (SSRs) and the prediction of open reading frames (ORFs) using the MISA software and TransDecoder software, respectively.

This annotation process provided valuable information on the functional genes involved in vertebrate nutrition, as well as other biological processes such as amino acid metabolism, digestive system, lipid metabolism, carbohydrate metabolism, and endocrine system.

The completeness of the transcriptome was also analyzed using the Benchmarking Universal Single Copy Orthologs (BUSCO) analysis based on the Ortholog database.

Overall, this annotation process helped improve the understanding of the cobia transcriptome and will be beneficial for nutrigenomics and functional studies on cobia and other mariculture species.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by an internal team (e.g the authors).
annotation_infrastructure:
Yes, the following tools or infrastructures were used during the annotation process:

- BLASTx and BLASTp searches against NCBInr, RefSeq, UniProtKB, KOG, and Pfam databases
- Metascape and EggNOG analyses for Gene Ontology (GO) annotation
- KEGG KASS for mapping full-length transcripts into canonical reference pathways in the KEGG database
- TransDecoder software for finding functional protein domains and predicting open reading frames (ORFs) of non-redundant transcripts
- NCBI nr, RefSeq, and UniprotKB databases for functional annotation of the transcriptome
- MISA software for detecting simple sequence repeats (SSRs)
- TransDecoder software for predicting open reading frames (ORFs)
- Benchmarking Universal Single Copy Orthologs (BUSCO) analysis based on the Ortholog database for analyzing transcriptome completeness
annotation_validation_methods: Ground Truth Labels, Expert Annotations, BUSCO analysis, MISA software, TransDecoder software
annotation_team_demograaphic: No. The context does not provide demographic information about the team who annotate the data.

authoring_funding: The dataset was funded by the conseil régional de Bourgogne Franche Comté.
authoring_funding_grant_id: No, there are no grant reference numbers mentioned in the provided context.
authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
- Gait analysis and biomechanics research, using the recorded data in c3d file format.
- Joint kinematics and dynamics computation using the 3D Kinematics and Inverse Dynamics toolbox.
- Computing joint angles from trajectory data using the plugin gait toolbox for Matlab.
- Data analysis and visualization using the Weka workbench or the Matlab Weka interface.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: Yes, the context mentions that the computed data should be used carefully, especially for hip and knee joints.
uses_represents_people: Yes, data represents people as is collected from people
uses_collected_from_people: Yes, the subjects of the collection process are humans. This is indicated in the context where it mentions that the data collection procedure involved acquiring data from healthy volunteers and patients with hip OA.
uses_biases: No. The context does not provide any information about biases issues of the data.
uses_sensitivity: No. The context does not provide any information about the data being offensive or sensitive to some people.
uses_privacy: No. The context does not provide any information about privacy issues of the data.
uses_data:
The collected data in this study is stored in two different file formats: C3D files and Weka files. The C3D files contain the recorded data and can be easily read using c3d toolboxes such as BTK. The software Mokka can be used for 3D visualization of the data. The metadata of the C3D files store anthropometric and demographic parameters of each participant. Joint kinematics and dynamics can be computed using the 3D Kinematics and Inverse Dynamics toolbox proposed by Dumas. The joint angles can be computed using the gait toolbox for Matlab available on the Vicon website.

The Weka files also contain the data and are stored in arff file format. These files can be read using the Weka workbench or the Matlab Weka interface. The metadata of the Weka files also store anthropometric and demographic parameters of each participant.

All the data records are available from figshare and are organized in folders based on the type of data (markers, plugin gait bones, angles, CoM and GRF data). The files are named based on the participant group (Healthy or Hip OA), session (M0 or M6), and the type of data.

The data collection procedure involved acquiring the data using the Nexus software. For healthy participants, the data collection was done in a single session, while for participants with hip OA, it was done in two sessions (M0 and M6). Each session lasted approximately 2 hours and was managed by experienced operators. The procedure included obtaining consent from the participants and conducting a medical interview to collect relevant health information.

Overall, the dataset includes gait analysis data from healthy volunteers and patients before and 6 months after total hip arthroplasty.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected using the Nexus software (Vicon, UK). For healthy participants, the data collection was done in a single session, while for participants with hip OA, it was done in two sessions (M0 - from 30 to 1 days before surgery and M6 - 6/7 months after surgery). Each session lasted approximately 2 hours and was managed by the same experienced operators. 

The data was recorded and stored in C3D file format, which can be easily read using c3d toolboxes such as BTK. The Mokka software can be used for 3D visualization of the data. Anthropometric and demographic parameters of each participant are stored in the metadata of the related C3D files. 

Joint kinematics and dynamics can be computed using the 3D Kinematics and Inverse Dynamics toolbox proposed by Dumas. To compute joint angles from the trajectory data, the gait toolbox plugin for Matlab is available on the Vicon website. 

The data is also stored in Weka file format (ARFF files), which can be read using the Weka workbench or the Matlab Weka interface toolbox. Anthropometric and demographic parameters are stored in the metadata of the related Excel files on figshare. 

The data records are available on figshare and are organized in ARFF file format. The files are organized by folders related to angles, markers, plugin gait bones, and CoM and GRF data. The file names include information about the type of data, session, and axis. 

Before the data collection, participants were asked to change into tight-fitting clothes or underwear, remove shoes and socks, and tie up their hair if necessary. Participants were equipped with reflective cutaneous markers positioned following the Plug-In-Gait model. Each markerset was calibrated for each patient with a static recording where the participant stood upright in anatomical position for three seconds without any movement. The calibration was checked by the operator, and a new standing trial was performed if any marker was missing or misplaced.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from healthy participants and participants with hip OA.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the data collection process include:
- Nexus software (Vicon, UK) for data acquisition
- C3D file format for storing recorded data
- BTK (Biomechanical Toolkit) for reading C3D files
- Mokka software for 3D visualization
- 3D Kinematics and Inverse Dynamics toolbox for computing joint kinematics and dynamics
- Gait toolbox for MATLAB available on the Vicon website
- Weka file format (arff files) for storing data
- Weka workbench for reading Weka files
- MATLAB File Exchange for MATLAB toolbox for reading Weka files
- Excel files on figshare for storing anthropometric and demographic parameters
- VideoLan software for reading video files
- Vicon Nexus software for labeling marker trajectories
- Woltring spline algorithm for interpolating marker trajectories
- 4th-order lowpass Butterworth filter with a 10 Hz cut-off frequency for smoothing marker trajectories
- 2nd-order lowpass Butterworth filter with a 50 Hz cut-off frequency for smoothing ground reaction forces and moments
- Kinematic-based algorithm for determining gait cycle events (foot strike and foot off)
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process for the data involves several steps. 

1. The recorded data is stored in C3D file format, which can be easily read using C3D toolboxes such as BTK. The software Mokka can be used for 3D visualization of the data.

2. Anthropometric and demographic parameters of each participant are stored in the metadata of the related C3D files.

3. Joint kinematics and dynamics can be computed using the 3D Kinematics and Inverse Dynamics toolbox proposed by Dumas and freely available on the MathWorks File Exchange.

4. To compute joint angles from the trajectory data, the plugin gait toolbox for MATLAB is available on the Vicon website in the Advanced Gait Workflow.

5. The data is also stored in Weka file format (ARFF files), which can be read using Weka workbench or the MATLAB Weka interface.

6. Anthropometric and demographic parameters of each participant are stored in the metadata of the related Excel files on figshare.

7. The processed data (C3D) is imported and concatenated into MATLAB using the Biomechanics ToolKit. Each trial of each participant is cropped into gait cycles and resampled at 101 points.

8. One file is generated for each marker trajectory, segment kinematics, joint kinematics, and ground reaction force, containing all data for each gait cycle of each participant.

9. The files contain a header with information such as the percentage of the gait cycle, volunteer ID, side of the Osteoarthritis limb (for patients), trial number, and cycle number.

10. The dataset is provided in both C3D and ARFF file formats to facilitate benchmarking of algorithms and analysis by different scientific specialties.

11. The Weka files are organized into folders related to angles, markers, plugin gait bones, and CoM and GRF data. The files are named based on the type of data, session, and axis.

12. Metadata for each volunteer, including demographic parameters, anthropometric parameters, and clinical parameters, is available.

13. During each gait analysis, a video recording is made on the frontal and sagittal plane of the patients. Two experienced physicians visually classify disturbances in the gait analysis videos into different categories.

authoring_funding: Yes, this work was supported by Fundação para a Ciência e Tecnologia through projects “Animal Future – Steering Animal Production Systems towards Sustainable Future” (SusAn/0001/2016) and “LEAnMeat - Lifecycle-based Environmental Assessment and impact reduction of Meat production with a novel multi-level tool” (PTDC/EAM-AMB/30809/2017).
authoring_funding_grant_id: The mentioned grant reference numbers in the context are "SusAn/0001/2016" and "PTDC/EAM-AMB/30809/2017".
authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset are to apply aggregated/simplified CFs when there is no field-level data and to use more specific CFs when there is sufficient information in an LCA study. The dataset can be used to obtain more accurate impact assessment for foreground processes/elementary flows by applying foreground CFs for foreground LU inventory flows and background CFs for background LU elementary flows. The dataset can also be used to facilitate the work of LCA practitioners by providing all the CFs produced in the study in a Zenodo repository, including foreground and background CFs in multiple data formats. Additionally, the dataset includes SOC dynamic curves used for calculating the CFs and background CFs in an OpenLCA impact assessment method file.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any testing of the dataset using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people. The context does not mention anything about people or any characteristics related to individuals.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The data collected is related to land use occupation and transformation.
uses_data:
The collected data for this study includes foreground and background characterization factors (CFs) for land use (LU) occupation and transformation. The foreground CFs were obtained through the application of a model and data sources, while the background CFs were obtained from LCA databases or other sources. 

During the life cycle inventory (LCI) stage, data regarding LU occupation and transformation were compiled, including information for the initial and final LU classes. In the life cycle impact assessment (LCIA) stage, foreground CFs were applied for foreground LU inventory flows, while background CFs were applied for background LU elementary flows. This approach allows for more accurate impact assessment for the foreground processes/elementary flows, instead of using generic CFs for both background and foreground flows as is commonly done in LCIA.

The collected data is available in multiple formats in a Zenodo repository. The repository includes foreground and background CFs in raster format (tiff files) and table format (excel files). The foreground occupation and transformation CFs are available at both the UHTU level and country level. The background occupation and transformation CFs are available at the country level. Additionally, the background CFs are provided in an OpenLCA impact assessment method file.

The data used to calculate the CFs includes SOC dynamic curves obtained from a previous study. The SOC dynamic curves cover 80 LU classes, including grassland, forest, and agricultural classes. The agricultural classes include 28 individual crops with different management practices. The calculations were performed using MATLAB, and the necessary code is available in the Zenodo repository.

Overall, the collected data provides comprehensive information on LU occupation and transformation CFs, allowing for more accurate impact assessment in LCA studies.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected using a combination of field-level data and aggregated data from LCA databases. The foreground CFs (characterization factors) were obtained through the application of the same model and data sources as the background CFs. 

In the life cycle inventory (LCI) stage, data on land use (LU) occupation and transformation were compiled, including information on the initial and final LU classes. This data was used to calculate the foreground CFs for foreground LU inventory flows. The background CFs, which describe LU occupation and transformation for aggregated LU classes, were obtained from LCA databases or other sources. 

To facilitate the work of LCA practitioners, all the CFs produced in this study are provided in a Zenodo repository. The repository includes foreground and background CFs in multiple data formats. The original SOC (soil organic carbon) dynamic curves used for calculating the CFs are also included in the repository. 

The foreground occupation and transformation CFs are available in raster format (tiff file) and table format (excel file). The background occupation and transformation CFs are also available in raster format and table format. The raster format files can be opened using geographic information systems (GIS) tools. 

Additionally, the background CFs produced in this study are provided in an OpenLCA impact assessment method file, which is available in the Zenodo repository. This file can be used without adaptation for the elementary flows in the PEF database. 

The initial SOC stock for each LU class was obtained from a previous study. Other input data required for the calculations, such as soil, vegetation, and climatic data, were also obtained from the same previous study. Soil cover period, initial SOC stock, and clay content were used to characterize the soils. The soil cover period is a binary monthly variable indicating whether the soil was covered with vegetation or bare. The initial SOC stock was obtained from the European Soil Data Centre, and clay content was obtained from the Harmonized World Soil Database. IPCC methods and crop yields from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations were used to calculate carbon inputs from annual plant residues.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from Teixeira et al., Brandão and Milá i Canals, Morais et al., and Koellner et al.
collection_infrastructure: The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include geographic information systems (GIS) tools for opening raster format files (tiff files), Excel for table format files, and the Zenodo repository for accessing and downloading the CFs and SOC dynamic curves. Additionally, data from previous studies (Morais et al. 26) and LCI databases (e.g., ecoinvent 50 and GaBi 51) were used as data sources.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involved the calculation of background transformation characterization factors (CFs) at the country-level. These CFs were meant to be used in background inventory flows that are also at the country-level or a higher level of aggregation. The data used for this process included information on LU occupation and transformation, including the initial and final LU classes. The CFs were obtained through the application of the same model and data sources, ensuring consistency. The foreground CFs were applied for foreground LU inventory flows in the life cycle inventory (LCI) stage, while the background CFs were applied for background LU elementary flows obtained from LCA databases or other sources. This approach allows for more accurate impact assessment for the foreground processes/elementary flows. The CFs produced in this study, including both foreground and background CFs, are available in a Zenodo repository in multiple data formats, such as raster and table formats. The spatial aggregation used in the study divided the world into 17,203 unique territorial units (UHTUs), which are geographical regions with uniform local characteristics. LU maps used in the background transformation CFs were obtained from another source and considered four classes: cropland area, forestry area, grazing land, and urban.

uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset are to analyze RNA sequencing data, evaluate sequence quality, filter and process read alignments, and study polyadenylation sites in Magnaporthe oryzae.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The context does not mention anything about the data representing people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The collected data in this study is RNA sequencing data, which is obtained from the Illumina HiSeq2000 platform. The data is analyzed to determine the alignment to annotated 3' UTR regions of the genome and to assign polyadenylation sites (PASs) to genomic features. The study does not involve human subjects.
uses_data:
The collected data in this study is RNA sequencing data. The workflow for analyzing the data is described in Figure 1. After total RNA extraction, Illumina RNA libraries were created following the 3' T-Fill protocol. RNA sequencing was performed on the Illumina HiSeq2000 platform. The FastQ reads obtained from sequencing were processed by removing sequencing adapters and then aligned onto the reference genome. The alignments were further processed to filter out low quality mappings, mappings with high A/T content, and potential internal priming. The resulting reads were then used for further analysis.

Figure 2 provides details about the quality of the RNA sequencing data. It shows the average quality scores across all bases of the paired-end datasets for a specific sample. The quality scores are represented as a box and whisker plot, with the median value, inter-quartile range, and mean quality indicated.

Figure 3 provides details about the selection criteria used for filtering and assigning RNA sequencing read alignments. It shows the nucleotide profile of the final high-confidence polyadenylation sites (PASs), as well as the nucleotide profile around an alignment resulting from products of internal priming. It also compares the mapped location of discarded reads (due to low quality, high A/T content, and potential internal primings) with the final kept reads. Additionally, it shows the distance distribution of aligned reads from the closest annotated stop-codon, indicating the typical 3'UTR length of M. oryzae mRNAs.

Figure 4 presents a heat map representing the sequencing correlations between the samples. The correlations were calculated using the Pearson correlation coefficient from the log-transformed raw reads counting per gene.

Table 1 provides general quality statistics for the datasets and general metadata related to the individual data deposits.

The RNA sequencing and PAS detection protocol involved several steps. First, the sequence reads were evaluated for quality using FastQC. Then, the reads were trimmed to remove poly(A) tails and Illumina adapter sequences. Read-mapping was performed using STAR, and the resulting alignments were filtered to remove low-quality mappings, mappings with high A/T content, and potential internal primings. The remaining alignments were analyzed to determine their alignment to annotated 3' UTR regions of the genome. PASs were assigned to genomic features based on their overlapping positions, and ambiguous cases were assigned to the closest 3' terminal end. To account for inaccurate 3'UTR annotations, the gene annotation was extended by 400 bp. PASs with high confidence were determined based on their expression levels and the standard score calculated against the whole gene expression. PASs with less than five supporting reads in every replicate were discarded. High-confidence PASs that were within 33 bp of each other were resolved to a single PAS. The final filtered alignment files can be loaded and viewed with a genome browser like IGV.

The data files are stored on Zenodo and are available for further analysis. Additionally, a publicly accessible triplestore and a web interface have been created to enable querying and visualizing the data.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through a series of steps outlined in Figure 1 of the document. First, total RNA was extracted, followed by the creation of Illumina RNA libraries using the 3' T-Fill protocol. RNA sequencing was then performed on the Illumina HiSeq2000 platform. The resulting FastQ reads were processed by removing sequencing adapters and aligned onto the reference genome using STAR. 

After alignment, the alignments were filtered to remove low-quality mappings (MAPQ < 30), mappings with high A/T content (>80%), and potential internal primings. Potential internal primings were identified by the presence of more than seven consecutive As in the first 5' nucleotides or more than twelve As in the first sixteen nucleotides, which is the length of the oligodT primers used during the 3' T-Fill protocol. These alignments were discarded as they were suspected to be potential internal primings with genomic regions rich in As. 

The remaining alignments were analyzed and found to mainly align to annotated 3' UTR regions of the genome, indicating that they were genuine sequencing from the 3' end of mRNA transcripts. The discarded alignments usually derived from non-annotated genomic regions, possibly related to transposable elements or other highly variable nucleotide sequences. 

A total of 14,593 polyadenylation sites (PASs) were reliably assigned to the genomic features listed in the Ensembl Fungi gene annotation for M. oryzae version 27. Each read was assigned to its overlapping feature, and ambiguous cases were assigned to the closest 3' terminal end. To account for inaccurate 3' UTR annotations, the gene annotation was extended by 400 bp. This range was chosen based on the observation that reads were at most 400 bp far from the closest annotated stop codon. 

PASs were considered to be called with high-confidence if they were detected in at least two of the three replicates and met certain expression criteria. PASs with less than five supporting reads in every replicate were discarded. High-confidence PASs that fell within 33 bp of one another were resolved to a single PAS, with the most highly expressed PAS in that region being selected. 

The resulting data files were stored on Zenodo and can be accessed for further analysis. Additionally, machine-readable metadata about the data is available in VOiD format, and a Web interface and track hub have been created to facilitate visualization and exploration of the data.

- HiSeq 2000 (Illumina) for sequencing the libraries
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involves several steps. First, after total RNA extraction, Illumina RNA libraries were created following the specifics of the 3 0 T-Fill protocol. Then, RNA sequencing was performed on the Illumina HiSeq2000 platform. FastQ reads were processed by removing sequencing adapters and finally aligned onto the reference genome. Alignments were further processed, filtering out low quality mappings, mappings with high A/T content, and potential internal priming. Reads were then assigned to genomic features after an additional 400 bp was included beyond the annotated 3'UTR to compensate for incorrect genome annotations. The typical upstream A-rich region which contains the polyadenylation signal was found within 3 bp from the cleavage site. High-confidence PAS detection included the clustering of PASs closer than 33 bp.

uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset are: 
1. Data filtering: The dataset can be used to filter out temperature profiles that do not meet certain quality criteria.
2. Use of WoD CTD (2013-14) for Illustration: The dataset can be used to practice analyzing CTD temperature data from the WoD dataset.
3. Technical Validation: The dataset can be used to validate the accuracy of the ELG method by comparing fitted and observed temperatures and calculating error metrics.
4. Analysis of global ocean CTD and XBT temperature profiles: The dataset can be used to analyze temperature profiles and generate (G, h) data pairs using the ELG method.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any testing using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset does not represent people. The dataset contains sets of (G, h, H ITL , SST, T m , Q-index, I-index) which are related to ocean temperature profiles.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are temperature profiles obtained from the World Ocean Database, not humans.
uses_data:
The collected data consists of temperature profiles obtained from the World Ocean Database (WoD) for the years 2013-2014. The dataset includes 55,554 profiles, which were uploaded to the Naval Postgraduate School website. The dataset also includes derived parameters such as G, h, H ITL , SST, T m , Q-index, and I-index. 

The key parameter in this dataset is h, which represents the depth of the isothermal layer (ITL). The error in the temperature data is defined as the difference between the fitted and observed temperatures. The temperature profiles are fitted to a linear function, with separate fits for the ITL and the thermocline. The errors in the ITL and thermocline fits are represented by the sum of the square errors (SSE ITL and SSE TH , respectively). The identification index (I-index) is calculated based on these errors.

The dataset is traced back to the WoD profiles, which contain a total of 1,201,897 sets of (G, h, H ITL , SST, T m , Q-index, I-index). The exponential leap-forward gradient (ELG) method was used to extract the parameters (G, h, SST) and temperature below the ITL (T m ) from the temperature profiles. The ELG method has been verified as optimal among existing methods. The ITL heat content (H ITL ) is calculated by vertically integrating the temperature profile from the surface to the base of the ITL.

The dataset was generated by applying the ELG method to the global ocean CTD and XBT temperature profiles from 1961-2017, downloaded from the NCEI website. Out of the total CTD and XBT profiles, 446,811 CTD profiles and 755,086 XBT profiles were used to generate the (G, h) data pairs. The lower number of (G, h) data pairs compared to the observational temperature profiles is due to data quality and vertical resolution criteria used for filtering. The quality of the (G, h) data was assessed using the Q-index and the identification index.

In summary, the collected data includes temperature profiles, derived parameters, and quality assessment indices. The dataset is available for public use on the NCEI website.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected by analyzing global ocean CTD (Conductivity, Temperature, Depth) and XBT (Expendable Bathythermograph) temperature profiles from 1961 to 2017. These profiles were downloaded from the NCEI (National Centers for Environmental Information) website in May 2018. The analysis was performed using the exponential leap-forward gradient (ELG) method, which is a technique for simultaneously archiving temperature (T), salinity (S), and temperature gradient (G) below the Inverse Thermocline Layer (ITL) and sea surface temperature (SST). 

The ELG method calculates the vertical gradients of temperature from the surface (z = 0) down to the base of the ITL (z = -h). The ITL heat content (H ITL ) is then obtained by integrating the temperature profile within this depth range. The benefit of using H ITL is that it is fully determined by the upper ocean mixed layer dynamics and directly interacts with the atmosphere. 

After applying the ELG method to the CTD and XBT profiles, the dataset was filtered based on nine criteria, such as the number of data points between 10 m and 40 m, the total number of observational points, and the maximum depth. The filtering process resulted in 446,811 sets of (G, h) data pairs from the CTD profiles and 755,086 sets of (G, h) data pairs from the XBT profiles. 

The quality of the (G, h) data pairs was assessed using the Q-index and identification index. The Q-index measures the skill score of the ELG method, while the identification index evaluates the consistency of the data pairs. 

In total, the dataset contains 1,201,897 sets of (G, h, H ITL , SST, T m , Q-index, I-index). The dataset is publicly available on the NCEI website for further analysis and use.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from the WoD profiles, WOD CTD (2013-14), NCEI website, and Naval Postgraduate School website.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

1. WoD CTD (Conductivity, Temperature, Depth) profiles: These profiles were used to collect temperature data from the ocean. The dataset contains 964,942 CTD profiles from 1961-2017.

2. XBT (Expendable Bathythermograph) profiles: These profiles were also used to collect temperature data from the ocean. The dataset contains 2,303,433 XBT profiles from 1961-2017.

3. MATLAB codes: MATLAB codes were used to process the sub-dataset of temperature data from the WoD CTD profiles (2013-2014). These codes can be easily modified to process other profile data.

4. Naval Postgraduate School website: The WoD CTD temperature data (2013-2014) and the derived dataset were uploaded to the Naval Postgraduate School website for readers to access and practice.

5. NCEI (National Centers for Environmental Information) website: The global ocean CTD and XBT temperature profiles (1961-2017) were downloaded from the NCEI website for analysis using the ELG method.

6. Data filtering criteria: Nine criteria were used to filter the data, including the number of data points between 10 m and 40 m, total observational points, and maximum depth.

7. Q-index and identification index: The quality of the (G, h) data pairs was identified using the Q-index and identification index. These indices were used to assess the skill score and uncertainty of the data.

8. NCEI/WOD observational XBT profiles: The observational XBT profiles from the NCEI/WOD dataset were used for analysis, without any correction.

Overall, the collection process involved the use of CTD and XBT profiles, MATLAB codes, websites for data access, and data filtering criteria.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involves fitting temperature profiles to linear functions and calculating the errors at each data point. The maximum error is represented by the total sum of the square error (SSE T ). After identifying the depth of the isothermal layer (ITL), two lines are used to fit the observational data, one from the top to the ITL base and the second from the ITL base to the bottom of the profile. The errors in the ITL are represented by the sum of the square error in ITL (SSE ITL ) and the errors in the thermocline are represented by the sum of the square error in the thermocline (SSE TH ). The identification index (I-index) is calculated using these errors. The ELG method is used to calculate the vertical gradients and the overall feature of the thermocline gradient is represented by the median. The annotation process also involves calculating statistical parameters for variables such as the isothermal layer depth (h), thermocline gradient (G), and isothermal layer heat content (H ITL ) for different time periods.

authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset include conducting experiments where emotional stimulation is needed, training automatic systems in recognizing human emotions, studying how emotions are communicated and interpreted by humans, and expanding the database by including new stimuli and participant responses.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention about any test using a machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: Yes, the context mentions that the database is not complete and comprehensive of all possible stimuli and any generalization of the data should be limited to the stimuli tested in the database.
uses_represents_people: Yes, data represents people as is collected from people
uses_collected_from_people: Yes, the subjects of the collection process are humans. This is indicated by the presence of demographic information on each participant, as well as the collection of skin conductance recordings and self-assessment ratings from the participants.
uses_biases: Yes, the context provides information about biases issues of the data.
uses_sensitivity: No. The context does not provide any information about the data being offensive or sensitive to some people.
uses_privacy: No. The context does not provide information about privacy issues of the data.
uses_data:
The collected data includes skin conductance (SC) recordings and self-assessment ratings. The data is organized in a MATLAB data structure, which also includes demographic information on each participant and baseline SC recordings collected prior to the experiment. The quality of the SC recordings is also available as a field in the data structure. The "features" field of the structure contains SC features extracted using Continuous Decomposition Analysis (CDA) with the MATLAB toolbox Ledalab.

To assess the reliability of the data, the ratings obtained in the experiment were compared with the expected values from the IAPS and IADS manuals. The results showed high significant correlations between our data and the expected values from the manuals. The distribution of the responses for each stimulus and each self-assessment dimension was also checked for normality.

The MATLAB data structure, multisensory_emotions.m, contains several fields. The "stim" field provides information about the stimuli delivered to participants, including the stimulus identification number, modality of delivery, name of the stimulus, duration of the stimulus, author/composer, and the database on which the stimulus was tested.

The "su" field allows retrieval of information about individual participants. It is divided into sub-fields, including "demographic" which contains demographic information on each participant, and "SAM" which contains information about the ratings of each stimulus and the order of presentation.

The "SC" field contains the SC recordings collected throughout the experiment. It includes the raw SC data, the downsampled and cleaned SC data, the baseline SC recordings, the quality of the SC recordings, the extracted SC features, and an indication of the participant's responsiveness to the stimuli.

In addition to the MATLAB data structure, an R list is also provided, which has the same architecture as the MATLAB structure. The R list can be used with the open-source software R for future studies.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected through an experimental set-up designed by E.G. The data collection was carried out by E.C., with support from E.M. and M.O. The data includes SC recordings and self-assessment ratings obtained during the experiment. The data is organized in a single MATLAB data structure, which also includes demographic information on each participant and baseline SC recordings collected prior to the experiment. The quality of the SC recording is also available as a separate field in the data structure. The SC features extracted from the data were obtained using Continuous Decomposition Analysis (CDA) with the MATLAB toolbox Ledalab.

The dataset can be used for various applications in the fields of human emotional reaction and automatic emotion recognition, such as psychology and computer science. The stimuli in the database, including haptic, abstract art pieces, and instrumental pieces, are not conventional and validated stimuli, making them of particular interest for experiments requiring emotional stimulation. The dataset can also be used to train automatic systems in recognizing human emotions based on the sensory modality of the stimulus. The relationship between self-assessment ratings, SC features, and sensory modality can provide insights into how emotions are communicated and interpreted by humans.

To facilitate access to the data, a MATLAB function (SCR_statistics.m) and its equivalent R function (SCRstatistics.R) have been prepared. These functions allow users to compute mean and standard deviation of selected SC features across all participants for each stimulus. The functions also provide the option to select participants based on the quality of their SC recordings for computing descriptive statistics. Additionally, an R-based graphic user interface has been developed to allow other researchers to merge their own data with the database.

However, there are some limitations to the current database. The number of conditions tested was limited to maintain a reasonable duration for the experiment, so any generalization of the data should be limited to the stimuli tested in this study. The authors encourage other scientists to expand the database while maintaining the same experimental design. The database also includes SCR computed over different timeframes depending on the duration of the stimulus. Lastly, the authors note that the haptic stimuli used may not have been identical across participants due to variations in hand size.

The data collection was carried out by a post-doctoral level researcher with over 5 years of experience in behavioral research. Participants were instructed to maintain a comfortable position and not move their left hand during the experiment to avoid movement artifacts in the SC signal.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: Yes, the context provides demographic information about the team who collect the data. The demographic information includes the participant's ID number, gender, hand dominance, and age.
collection_sources:
The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects:

- SC recordings
- Self-assessment ratings
- Demographic information on each participant
- Baseline SC recordings
- Stimuli delivered to participants during the experiment
- Ratings of each stimulus
- Skin conductance values collected with the Shimmer3 GSR+ Unit
- Features extracted using the Ledalab toolbox for MATLAB
- Phasic responses of participants throughout the experiment
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

1. Shimmer3 GSR+ Unit: This device was used to collect skin conductance values (SC) during the experiment.

2. MATLAB: The data collected during the experiment was organized and stored in a MATLAB data structure. MATLAB was also used for data analysis and feature extraction.

3. Ledalab Toolbox: This MATLAB toolbox was used for artifact correction and feature extraction from the SC recordings.

4. R: An R list (multisensory_emotions_R.rda) was also provided, which has the same structure as the MATLAB data structure. R can be used to access and analyze the dataset.

5. Graphic User Interface: An R-based graphic user interface was developed to facilitate the inclusion of new data and merge it with the existing dataset.

Overall, the collection process involved the use of the Shimmer3 GSR+ Unit for SC recordings, MATLAB for data organization and analysis, Ledalab Toolbox for artifact correction and feature extraction, and R for data analysis and visualization.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process done over the data involves organizing the data into a MATLAB data structure called multisensory_emotions.m. This structure contains various fields that provide information about the stimuli, participants, ratings, skin conductance (SC) recordings, and SC features. The multisensory_emotions.m structure includes the following fields:

1. multisensory_emotions.stim: A 50x6 MATLAB array that contains information about the stimuli delivered to participants during the experiment. The columns represent the stimulus identification number, modality of delivery (audio, video, or haptic), name of the stimulus, duration of the stimulus, author/composer, and the database on which the stimulus was tested.

2. multisensory_emotions.su: This field allows retrieval of information about a particular participant. It is divided into sub-fields, including .su.demographic, which is a 1x4 MATLAB vector containing demographic information such as participant ID number, gender, hand dominance, and age.

3. multisensory_emotions.su.SAM: A MATLAB array of size 50x5 that provides information about the ratings of each stimulus and the order of stimuli presented to the participant.

4. multisensory_emotions.su.SC: A MATLAB matrix containing the SC recordings collected throughout the experiment. It has n samples and 2 columns. The first column represents the skin conductance value (μS), and the second column represents the presentation of the stimulus as an SC trigger.

5. multisensory_emotions.su.SC.clean: A nx2 MATLAB matrix containing the downsampled and cleaned SC recordings using the Ledalab artefact correction toolbox.

6. multisensory_emotions.su.SC.baseline: A 1xn MATLAB vector including the SC recordings from the participant prior to the experiment.

7. multisensory_emotions.su.SC.quality: A single value ranging from 0 to 2, indicating the quality of the SC recordings (0 = unusable, 1 = partially complete, 2 = complete).

8. multisensory_emotions.su.SC.features: A 50x12 MATLAB array representing the 12 SC features extracted using the Ledalab toolbox. Each row corresponds to a stimulus, and missing values are reported as NA.

9. multisensory_emotions.su.SC.responsiveness: A single value (0 or 1) indicating whether the participant showed any phasic response throughout the experiment. A value of 0 suggests a possible non-responder.

In addition to the MATLAB structure, an R list (multisensory_emotions_R.rda) is also provided, which has an equivalent architecture to the MATLAB structure. The R list can be accessed and used for future studies using the R software.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by an internal team (e.g the authors).
annotation_infrastructure: No
annotation_validation_methods: The context does not provide information about the validation methods used to validate the labels.
annotation_team_demograaphic: Yes, the context provides demographic information about each participant in the study.
