authoring_maintenance_policies: No, there is no mention about maintenance policies of the dataset in the context.
uses_uses: The recommended uses of the dataset are volumetric analysis of parcellated hypothalamic nuclei for clinical applications and research purposes, and image processing and template generation for standardized output and group averages.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention of the dataset being tested in any machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: Yes, the context mentions that the authors do not recommend the employment of the atlas as a tool for direct surgical targeting.
uses_represents_people: No. The data of the dataset represents MRI scans, not people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are not humans. The data was collected from structural magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) datasets from the Human Connectome Project (HCP) S1200 subject release.
uses_data: The collected data in this study consists of two data records. The first data record includes high-resolution templates and segmentations of the hypothalamic region. These templates are age-and population-averaged and feature minimal deformation. The templates are provided in both ultra-high (voxel size: 0.25 × 0.25 × 0.25 mm) and high (voxel size: 0.5 × 0.5 × 0.5 mm) resolution. The second data record features an atlas of the hypothalamic region, which includes 25 subcortical gray and white matter regions per hemisphere. Thirteen of these regions are hypothalamic nuclei, while the remaining regions are adjacent structures. These structures were segmented due to their clinical importance and their use as targets for deep brain stimulation (DBS) surgery. The high contrast and resolution of the templates greatly facilitated the segmentation of the hypothalamic region and allowed for visualization of tissue boundaries that would not have been otherwise distinguishable. The data records also include volumetric measurements of mean hypothalamic volumes stratified by gender, laterality, and major hypothalamic subdivisions. Additionally, the data contribution includes three example datasets that were used for validation of the hypothalamic atlas. These datasets feature volumes of tissue activated (VTAs) of two DBS patients and the delineation of a solitary metastasis. The data records are provided in NIfTI-1 format and can be opened with standard visualization software. The data acquisition for the atlas was done using structural magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) datasets from the Human Connectome Project (HCP) S1200 subject release. The scans were obtained using a 3.0 Tesla MRI scanner, and the images were preprocessed using the Minimal Preprocessing Pipeline (MPP). The final dataset consisted of 990 individual scans that were used for further processing. The multi-sequence average templates were generated using the Minimum Deformation Averaging (MDA) technique, which utilizes inter-individual variations to generate an unbiased, high-resolution, high-contrast population average. The templates were generated through iterative model building, where single-subject data was aligned to capture the average morphology of the population. The labeling of the templates was done, and the dice similarity coefficient (DSC) was calculated for each label to determine the extent of inter-rater agreement. Labels with a DSC < 0.35 were reevaluated and amended to reduce neuroanatomical differences. The final diencephalic atlas was generated using an OR logical, where the label that was deemed more accurate overall was implemented in the final atlas build.
collection_explanation:
The dataset used in this study was collected from the Human Connectome Project (HCP) S1200 subject release. The source data for the dataset were structural magnetic resonance image (MRI) datasets. The scans were obtained using a 3.0 Tesla MRI machine with specific acquisition parameters for each scan type. The T1-MPRAGE scans had a TR of 2400 ms, TE of 2.14 ms, TI of 1000 ms, flip angle of 8 degrees, FoV of 224 × 224 mm, and voxel size of 0.7 mm isotropic. The T2-SPACE scans had a TR of 3200 ms, TE of 565 ms, variable flip angle, FoV of 224 × 224 mm, and voxel size of 0.7 mm isotropic.

The Minimal Preprocessing Pipeline (MPP) was applied to all structural imaging files, which included spatial/artifact distortion removal, crossmodal registration, surface generation, and alignment to standard space. The dataset consisted of T1- and T2-weighted scans of young, healthy individuals aged 22-35 years. A total of 1000 datasets were downloaded from the S1200 subject release, but 10 incomplete or corrupted files were excluded from further analysis. If a patient dataset had multiple versions of the same modality, the version with the best image quality was selected.

After data acquisition, image processing and template generation were performed. The T1- and T2-weighted scans were processed independently. A hierarchical image registration algorithm was used, which involved four rounds of registration. In the first step, an affine registration was performed to scale the 990 individual scans to MNI space using a MNI152 NLIN 2009b template. The individual subject scans were upsampled to the target resolution using B-spline, but the spatial information remained unchanged. Subsequently, three rounds of non-linear registration were performed, with each round using the average generated from the previous round as the target for registration.

An iterative, non-uniform correction of field inhomogeneities was performed using the ANTs N4 correction tool. The BEaST brain extraction software was then used to process the brain masks and skull strip both the T1- and T2-weighted images. Finally, the image axis was aligned to MNI152 NLIN 2009b space and the field-of-view was cropped to achieve a standardized output.

The antsMultivariateTemplate builder was applied to the imaging dataset to generate group averages. This involved a hierarchical image registration algorithm with four rounds of registration, performed independently for the T1- and T2-weighted scans.

The data used in this study were provided in part by the Human Connectome Project, WU-Minn Consortium, funded by the NIH Blueprint for Neuroscience Research. The work was also supported by the German Research Foundation and the Canada Research Chair in Neuroscience.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an external team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from the Human Connectome Project (HCP) S1200 subject release.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

- Structural magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) datasets from the Human Connectome Project (HCP) S1200 subject release.
- 3.0 Tesla MRI scanner.
- T1-MPRAGE and T2-SPACE acquisition parameters.
- The Minimal Preprocessing Pipeline (MPP) for preprocessing the structural imaging files.
- ANTs N4 correction tool for non-uniform correction of field inhomogeneities.
- BEaST brain extraction software for processing brain masks and skull stripping.
- MNI152 NLIN 2009b space for image alignment and cropping.
- antsMultivariateTemplate builder for generating group averages.
- Hierarchical image registration algorithm for registration of imaging data.
- Minimum deformation averaging (MDA) technique for generating multi-sequence average templates.
- Minc-bpipe-library pipeline for initializing MRI datasets.
annotation_explanation:
The annotation process for the data involved several steps. First, the source data for the atlas were obtained from structural MRI datasets from the Human Connectome Project. The scans were preprocessed using the Minimal Preprocessing Pipeline, which included distortion removal, registration, surface generation, and alignment to standard space. 

Next, the data records were created, which included high-resolution templates and segmentations of the hypothalamic region. The templates were available in ultra-high and high resolution, and the segmentations included 25 subcortical gray and white matter regions per hemisphere, with 13 of them being hypothalamic nuclei. These structures were segmented based on their clinical importance and their use as targets for DBS surgery. The high contrast and resolution of the templates facilitated the segmentation process.

The labeling of the hypothalamic nuclei was done based on specific criteria, and the inter-rater agreement was assessed using the dice similarity coefficient. Labels with a DSC below 0.35 were reevaluated and amended to minimize neuroanatomical differences. The final atlas was generated by implementing the labels that were deemed more accurate.

Overall, the annotation process involved data acquisition, preprocessing, template generation, segmentation, labeling, and assessment of inter-rater agreement.

- antsMultivariateTemplate builder
- Display software
annotation_validation_methods: Inter-annotator agreement, Dice similarity coefficient (DSC)

uses_uses:
The recommended uses of the dataset include: 
1) Analysis or visualization tools that can work with HGVS formatted files like VCF can be used to analyze the CSV formatted files.
2) The RDF files can be uploaded to a triple store and queried using the SPARQL query language, and the links to external RDF data sources can be exploited for further integration queries.
3) The dataset can be visualized in genome browsers, such as UCSC, by accepting HGVS variant descriptions.
4) The dataset can be used for variant pathogenicity prediction vs. curated datasets.
5) The FAIRified data allows for integration with other interoperable data and enables reusability for other research studies.
uses_ml_approach: No, there is no mention of the dataset being tested in any machine learning approach.
uses_data_limits: No, there is no mention about non-recommended uses or generalization limits of the data.
uses_represents_people: No, the data of the dataset does not represent people.
uses_collected_from_people: No. The subjects of the collection process are genetic variants, not humans.
uses_data:
The collected data consists of genetic variant information from multiple databases related to Rett Syndrome (RTT). The data was selected and retrieved from eight databases, including ClinVar, DECIPHER, EVA, EVS, ExAC, KMD, LOVD, and RettBASE. Additionally, an anonymized dataset from local RTT patients was included. The data was downloaded or extracted from HTML using the integrated download function or manual extraction. 

To ensure compatibility and comparability, the MECP2 genetic variant descriptions from different sources were made compatible using the HGVS nomenclature and the same reference sequence (NC_000023.11). The Mutalyzer position converter webtool was used for liftover, which converts the variants to the same reference build. Manual correction was performed on genetic variant descriptions that did not have the correct format for conversion.

The genetic variants were then categorized based on their linked phenotype information into three categories: RTT causing, benign, and unknown evidence. The RTT causing dataset included data from DECIPHER, Maastricht Rett dataset, ClinVar, RettBase, and KMD. The benign dataset included data from ClinVar and RettBase. The unknown evidence dataset included data from EVS, EVA, LOVD, and ExAC.

The prepared genetic variant and phenotype data were made more Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) by using a semantic data model and a general-purpose FAIRifier tool. The data was made machine-readable in RDF format using the OpenRefine data cleaning and wrangling tool and an RDF plugin. Machine-readable metadata was also generated using the Metadata Editor.

The machine-readable metadata and the RDF and CSV files for each of the nine sources were made available on a FAIR Data Point, which can be accessed via the provided URL. The CSV files contain the genetic variants described in the HGVS nomenclature format, along with the source and classification of the variations. The RDF files are serialized in the Turtle format and can be uploaded to a triple store for querying using the SPARQL query language. The RDF files are also linked to external RDF data sources such as Ensembl RDF and Orphanet Rare Disease ontology for further integration queries.
collection_explanation:
The dataset was collected by retrieving MECP2 genetic variant data from multiple databases. The researchers selected eight databases that met specific requirements for data integration. These databases included ClinVar, DECIPHER, EVA, EVS, ExAC, KMD, LOVD, and RettBASE. The researchers downloaded all MECP2 genetic variants with available linked phenotype information from each of these databases. They also included an anonymized dataset from local RTT patients.

To ensure compatibility and comparability of the genetic variant descriptions, the researchers used the HGVS nomenclature and the same reference sequence (NC_000023.11). They used the Mutalyzer position converter webtool to convert the genetic variant descriptions to the HGVS nomenclature and the reference sequence. Manual correction was performed on genetic variant descriptions that did not have the complete and correct format for conversion.

The genetic variants were then assigned to three different categories based on their linked phenotype information: RTT causing, benign, and unknown evidence. The RTT causing dataset included data from DECIPHER, Maastricht Rett dataset, ClinVar, RettBase, and KMD. The benign dataset included data from ClinVar and RettBase. The unknown evidence dataset included data from EVS, EVA, LOVD, and ExAC.

The researchers made the prepared genetic variant and phenotype data more Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) by using a semantic data model and a general-purpose FAIRifier tool. They converted the data to RDF format and generated machine-readable metadata. The FAIRified data was distributed at a new location to enable reusability by other researchers.

The dataset is available in CSV format, with the first column containing the genetic variants described in the HGVS nomenclature, the second column indicating the source database, and the third column classifying the variations into RTT causing, benign, or NA. The dataset is also available in RDF format, serialized in the Turtle format. To use the RDF files, they need to be uploaded to a triple store, and SPARQL query language can be used to query the data.

The dataset contains unique MECP2 variations from each investigated database, with different databases having different numbers of unique variations. Some databases focus on collecting pathogenic variations, while others focus on general population sequencing results. There are also databases that focus on curated collections of disease-causing variants or hospital-derived collections. The dataset includes shared variations between databases, which can be explained by the occurrence of the variation in multiple patients, data exchange between databases, or recruitment from the same resources.
collection_team_type: The data was collected by an internal team.
collection_team_demographic: No, there is no mention of demographic information about the team who collects the data.
collection_sources: The data has been collected from the following sources or subjects: ClinVar, DECIPHER, EVA, EVS, ExAC, KMD, LOVD, RettBASE, and the Maastricht Rett dataset.
collection_infrastructure:
The tools, devices, and infrastructure used during the collection process include:

1. Genotype-phenotype databases: Thirteen genotype-phenotype databases containing RTT-specific MECP2 variation data were identified and evaluated for data integration. These databases include ClinVar, DECIPHER, EVA, EVS, ExAC, KMD, LOVD, MECP2 collection, and RettBASE.

2. Download functions and HTML extraction: The data from the selected databases were downloaded using integrated download functions or extracted from HTML.

3. Mutalyzer position converter webtool: The MECP2 genetic variant descriptions from different sources were made compatible and comparable by using the HGVS nomenclature and the same reference sequence. The Mutalyzer position converter webtool was used for this purpose.

4. RDF format and FAIRifier tool: The prepared genetic variant and phenotype data were made more Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) by using the RDF format and a general-purpose FAIRifier tool based on the OpenRefine data cleaning and wrangling tool.

5. Metadata Editor: Machine-readable metadata about the data was generated using the Metadata Editor.

6. Semantic data model: A semantic data model of a genetic variant was applied and extended to convert the prepared data to RDF. The model describes the important data elements of the datasets, including the genetic variant (HGVS nomenclature, start/end position, and genome build) and the phenotype information.

7. CSV formatted files: The genetic variant data were also provided in CSV formatted files, with the first column containing the genetic variants described with the HGVS nomenclature, the second column indicating the source (name of the database), and the third column classifying the variations into RTT causing, benign, or NA (not applicable).

8. RDF files: The RDF output of the dataset was serialized in the Turtle format, which can be uploaded to a triple store for querying using the SPARQL query language. The RDF files were also linked to external RDF data sources such as Ensembl RDF and Orphanet Rare Disease ontology for further integration queries.
annotation_explanation: The annotation process done over the data involved several steps. First, the HGVS corrected variants were used to integrate custom scripts with the HGVS conversion tool to generate VCF files for annotation. These VCF files were then annotated using the Ensembl Variant Effect Predictor (VEP) with the GRCh38 assembly. The annotation included all available features, as well as optional plugins to estimate variant pathogenicity. The resulting VEP annotated data was processed with R scripts to compare RTT causing and benign variants and generate summary statistics. The annotation features used for comparison included variant frequency in the population, estimated variant consequence, and conservation score of the genomic location. Additionally, the annotation focused on exonic missense variants and used VEP information about the amino acid change and position within the MECP2-e2 transcript to visualize the variation distribution across protein domains and conserved regions.
annotation_team_type: The data was annotated by an automatic analysis pipeline using custom scripts and the Ensembl Variant Effect Predictor (VEP) with the GRCh38 assembly.
annotation_infrastructure:
Yes, the tools or infrastructures used during the annotation process are:
- HGVS conversion tool from https://github.com/counsyl/hgvs
- Ensembl Variant Effect Predictor (VEP) with the GRCh38 assembly
- R scripts
- Cytoscape 29 (network visualization and analysis software)
